item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): A New Arrival from Montana
item.description:
I recently received a Beogram 4002 (Type 5523) turntable from a customer in Montana who purchased it in the 1970s. He wants a complete restoration. This post provides an initial assessment, and a follow-up will detail the work done.

The turntable arrived safely in a protective Beolover shipping container. Upon opening it, the turntable appeared to be in good overall condition, with the aluminum surfaces and plinth corners looking particularly well-preserved.

However, there’s damage to the coating on the START button of the keypad. Finding a consistent way to restore these pads is challenging. For now, I’ll proceed with the restoration and hope a solution emerges soon, as keypad replacement is thankfully straightforward.

Internally, the unit appears original, with no signs of previous tampering – an ideal starting point for restoration. As expected, the usual degradation is present in the transport lock bushings. These will be replaced with Beolover parts during the restoration. Similarly, the carriage pulley shows the typical cracking caused by the setscrew and will be replaced with a precision-machined Beolover pulley.

Overall, this Beogram 4002 is an excellent candidate for a complete functional restoration. The goal is to return it to like-new performance and reliability. Stay tuned for a follow-up post detailing the work done.

item.title: Beogram 4000: New Main Capacitor Array with Integrated Efficient 24V Power Supply
item.description:
The Beogram 4000 is known to get quite hot, primarily due to its outdated voltage regulator-based power supply. To address this, a modern PCB design with a buck converter-based 24V supply was created as a replacement for the original power supply and capacitors.

The new design features high-quality Panasonic electrolytic capacitors, Samsung ceramic capacitors for the motor phase, and a buck converter for the 24V power supply. It’s designed to be easily installed in place of the original components. Replacing the old capacitors is straightforward, requiring only desoldering and reattaching wires to labeled pads.

The 24V rail is the primary power source for the Beogram 4000, powering the motors, lights, and control circuitry. The original design used an inefficient voltage regulator, leading to significant energy waste as heat. A buck converter offers a more efficient alternative by chopping the input voltage into a high-frequency signal, reducing heat dissipation.

Measurements comparing the original setup to the new design showed a nearly 50% reduction in power consumption while the turntable is in use and an 80% reduction in standby mode. This significant improvement is largely attributed to the removal of the inefficient Zener diode voltage divider.

The temperature measurements confirmed the reduced power consumption, with the Beogram 4000 equipped with the new board running considerably cooler. The new board brings the Beogram 4000’s power supply into the modern age, significantly reducing energy waste.

item.title: Beo4 Enabled Commander Remote Control: Seamless Integration of Beogram 4002 or 4004 with More Recent B&O Systems
item.description:
Dirk, a Beolover from Berlin, recently reached out about controlling his Beogram 4004 turntable with a Beo4 remote. He wanted to seamlessly integrate the turntable with his existing Beosound 9000 system.

I found his idea intriguing and decided to modify the Beolover Commander remote to make it compatible. This involved adding a 455kHz IR receiver for Beo4 communication and deciphering the Beo4’s code system to rewrite the Commander’s firmware accordingly.

The Beo4’s complexity made this a challenging task. However, the result allows the Commander-equipped Beogram to function remarkably like a Beolink-connected device.

Dirk even discovered a way to incorporate a Beoremote One into this setup. A video showcasing the system, including Dirk’s contributions, is available.

The Beo4 Commander is ready to purchase from the Beolover Store for those interested in replicating this setup.

item.title: Another Surprise Addition To The Workshop Beogram 4004
item.description:
In 2021, I refurbished my Beogram 4004 turntable, which I call the “Workshop Beogram 4004”. Later that year, I added the Beolover Remote Commander and have enjoyed using it to play records.

This year, I made another enhancement to my Beogram 4004: a Beolover SyncDrive Platter Motor. I was eager to try it out after reading about it on the Beolover Blog.

My Beogram 4004 was already restored and in regular use, with a perfectly functional DC platter motor restored by Beolover in 2021.

However, I was drawn to the concept of a self-calibrating, highly accurate platter motor and decided to experience it firsthand.

To establish a baseline, I measured the original DC platter motor’s performance using the Beolover RPM Tool v2, aiming to compare it with the SyncDrive.

[Image]

This screenshot captures the Beolover RPM Tool v2 measurements being recorded on a PC.

[Image]

I conducted these measurements over twenty hours, exceeding the typical usage duration. This extended timeframe aligns with the comparison standards used on the Beolover Blog.

After documenting the original platter motor’s data at 33.33 RPM, I replaced it with the Beolover SyncDrive.

The motor swap is remarkably straightforward.

[Image]

[Image]

This is the Beolover SyncDrive as received.

[Image]

Here’s the connection point to the Beogram 4004 main board.

[Image]

Here’s the installed SyncDrive.

[Image]

…and activated by initiating platter rotation and pressing a SyncDrive control button.

[Image]

Upon activation, the SyncDrive indicated that my existing 33.33 RPM setting was slightly too fast, unsurprising given the lack of prior calibration.

This image shows the Beogram 4004 platter speed measurement with the SyncDrive installed, post-calibration at 33.33 RPM.

[Image]

The ease of use is remarkable.

The SyncDrive’s control buttons are a standout feature, particularly the automatic self-calibration for 33.33 and 45 RPM.

I also value the ability to disable the Beogram control panel’s speed adjustments.

Now for a performance comparison. Using the Beolover RPM Tool v2, I measured the Beogram 4004 platter’s 33.33 RPM with the SyncDrive installed, again over twenty hours.

[Image]

As evident from the results, both platter motors maintain consistent and controlled platter speed for twenty continuous hours.

This was anticipated, given the Beolover restoration of my original DC platter motor in 2021, which should ensure its longevity.

However, the graph demonstrates the SyncDrive’s superior RPM measurement consistency.

It’s worth noting that the original platter motor’s mean speed had slightly decreased since its 2021 adjustment, measuring 33.24 RPM. While the Beogram 4004 main board’s 33 RPM trimmer and a tool like the Beolover RPM Tool v2 could rectify this, the SyncDrive eliminates the need for such adjustments. A simple press of the Auto-Cal button, and the platter speed calibrates and locks in within two minutes.

Both a Beolover-restored DC platter motor and a Beolover SyncDrive can revitalize a Beogram 4002/4004 turntable. I simply admire the technical accomplishment and performance of the SyncDrive.

Now, back to enjoying my records.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (Type 5513): Full Upgrade with SyncDrive Platter Motor, Commander Remote Control and Internal RIAA Pre-Amplifier
item.description:
A customer from Kentucky requested a full upgrade for their Beogram 4002 turntable, including three modifications: a SyncDrive motor for enhanced speed stability, a Commander remote control system for convenient operation and keypad protection, and a Beolover RIAA pre-amplifier for direct connection to modern audio equipment.

All upgrades were installed without soldering. The SyncDrive replaced the original DC motor, connecting to existing mounting points and the main circuit board. The Beolover RIAA pre-amplifier replaced the output board, using compatible connectors for easy installation. The Commander remote control board connected to the keypad header. An auto-repeat indicator was added and the keypad was reassembled.

After the upgrades were finished, a test record (“Olinga” by Milt Jackson) was played to assess the improvements. The record was cleaned using a CleanerVinyl ProXL system beforehand.

The upgraded Beogram 4002 will undergo further testing before being returned to its owner in Kentucky.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (Type 5513): Full Functional Restoration and a Test Spin with Stanley Turrentine and Milt Jackson
item.description:
This article details the restoration of a Beogram 4002 turntable from Kentucky. The unit, pictured below, was in excellent condition, making it ideal for a complete refurbishment.

As is typical with DC motor Beograms, the platter motor was the starting point. These motors commonly suffer from dried-out bearings, leading to speed instability. The extracted motor is shown here:

The motor was disassembled to access the bearings:

The bearings, visible as two small rings on the black pad, were then submerged in motor oil under a vacuum:

The resulting bubbles indicated air being pulled from the bearings, allowing oil to penetrate. This process typically lasts 48 to 72 hours. Other restoration tasks were addressed while this took place.

The arm lowering and carriage transport mechanisms were rebuilt, starting with the original setup:

All parts were removed:

and cleaned ultrasonically:

The parts, now clean, were ready for reassembly:

A new rubber gasket replaced the old one in the damper assembly:

This addressed potential arm lowering inconsistencies. The reassembled setup is depicted here:

The old, cracked plastic carriage pulley was replaced with a new aluminum version:

An LED assembly replaced the incandescent bulb in the tracking sensor. This is the original setup:

The housing was removed, exposing the tracking sensor aperture:

The old and new assemblies are shown side-by-side:

The new LED assembly was installed:

A trimmer on the assembly enables brightness adjustment for calibration.

The damper-to-arm linkage, crucial for smooth operation, was then lubricated. This linkage is attached to the sensor arm assembly, visible here:

The sensor arm was removed, followed by the linkage:

The small copper plate was cleaned, reattached with epoxy, and the linkage’s pivot point was lubricated before reassembly.

Attention turned to the electronics. The aging power Darlington transistors on the main PCB were replaced with TIP102 and TIP107 transistors to ensure stability. Here’s the original TIP120:

A 100nF capacitor was added between the emitter and ground to address potential high-frequency oscillations:

The board was then removed, revealing its original state:

A closer look at the ‘RPM section’:

All electrolytic capacitors, power transistors, the RPM relay and trimmers, and the sensor arm transistor and resistor were replaced:

The refurbished RPM section now included a new relay and trimmers:

[](https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhPkphXwDH-F-YQKMz8dx3BB

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): A New Arrival from Kentucky
item.description:
A Beogram 4002 (Type 5513) turntable from Kentucky arrived safely thanks to its secure packaging. The turntable was in excellent cosmetic condition, with minimal scratching on the dust cover and un-cracked hinges.

Upon removing the cover, the aluminum surfaces appeared nearly flawless, showing only minor signs of wear. The keypad was also well-preserved, exhibiting only slight deterioration on the START key and a few insignificant marks. The pristine condition of the keypad made it an ideal candidate for the Beolover Commander remote control system, which protects such keypads from further wear.

The wooden base was also in excellent condition, with both corners showing minimal signs of age.

Beneath the surface, the unit appeared largely original, providing a solid foundation for a successful restoration. However, one of the plinth guidance washers was missing, and orange plastic fragments, indicative of degraded transport lock bushings, were scattered within the casing. Additionally, the original plastic carriage pulley was cracked at the shaft collar, a common issue caused by the set screw. This problem could be easily remedied by installing a precision-machined Beolover aluminum replica pulley.

An initial functional test showed promising results. While the platter motor exhibited rattling indicative of dry bearings, a common issue with DC platter motor Beograms, the carriage moved consistently towards the LP set-down point, and the solenoid engaged properly. These positive signs suggested a potentially straightforward restoration process.

Further updates on the restoration progress will be shared in a follow-up post.

item.title: Beogram 4002: Restoration of Short Circuited Solenoid Coil and Repair of Main PCB
item.description:
I recently received a faulty solenoid coil and the main circuit board from a Beogram 4002 turntable belonging to a customer in Texas. I requested the circuit board be sent along with the coil because there’s usually an underlying reason why these coils fail, especially in later models of the Beogram 4002 and 4004 turntables.

The components arrived as shown in the image:

My first step was to measure the coil’s resistance to verify the customer’s diagnosis:

As suspected, the resistance was significantly lower than the typical 9 ohms found in a functioning coil, measuring only 1.6 ohms.

Interestingly, this coil assembly differed slightly from those I had previously worked on. The typical assembly (left) uses a locking washer to secure the tube within the coil:

In this instance (right, plunger already removed), the assembly appeared to be press-fit. This difference was also apparent at the back end of the assemblies, with the current one on the right:

Lacking a clear view of the tube’s mounting from the front, I opted to remove the coil with the assembly intact, hoping for clues on how to disassemble it. Unwinding the coil with the assembly in place was impossible, so I used a Dremel with a cutting wheel to make a cut:

With a bit of careful force, I removed most of the coil windings:

With the coil mostly gone, I discovered I could press the tube out using an arbor press. Here are the separated parts:

The tube was essentially riveted into the mounting bracket’s opening:

In the future, I will likely drill out the front of the pressed-in tube before using the arbor press. I then installed a new coil I had made using a 3D-printed plastic core:

These replacement coils are available for purchase in the Beolover Store.

I installed the refurbished coil assembly into my Beogram 4002 workbench:

I also installed the main circuit board that accompanied the coil. Upon plugging in the Beogram, the coil immediately activated. I swiftly unplugged the unit to prevent the coil from overheating. This suggested a blown 1IC4, the component responsible for regulating the solenoid current:

I replaced the original TIP125 Darlington transistor with a more robust TIP107, hoping for increased longevity:

This resolved the issue, and the Beogram functioned correctly, lowering the tonearm at the designated point on the record.

In my experience, many Beogram 4002 and 4004 turntables have problems with their power transistors, so I generally replace them as a preventative measure during restoration.

The main circuit board is now fully capable of controlling the solenoid. Time to send everything back to Texas!

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): A new Arrival from Nebraska
item.description:
A Beogram 4002 (Type 5513) turntable from Nebraska arrived for a complete restoration. It was securely shipped in a Beolover container. This is my first look at the unit.

Upon unboxing and bench inspection:

The turntable is in relatively good cosmetic condition. The dust cover is in good shape, though it would benefit from polishing.

The aluminum surfaces show only minor imperfections:

The base has one slightly worn corner on the right side:

while the left side remains in excellent condition:

There is also damage to the back right corner:

The control panel is still in fairly good shape with only minor fingerprints, noticeable only under certain lighting:

Adding a Beolover Commander remote will help preserve the control panel. The Commander allows for complete wireless control, eliminating the need to touch the panel. It also provides an auto-repeat function.

Under the aluminum covers:

This Beogram 4002 has the orange transport lock bushings, known to deteriorate. The remnants of these bushings are visible within the unit.

The turntable appears largely untouched, with no clear signs of prior servicing:

An initial power-up test was conducted. When started, the tonearm moved to the record placement position, and the solenoid activated. The platter motor also started, though it rattled a bit, indicating the typical dried-out bearings. These are all positive signs! This restoration appears to be straightforward. Updates to come!

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): A New Arrival from Texas
item.description:
I recently received a Beogram 4002 (Type 5513) turntable from a Texas customer. It was shipped securely in a Beolover container. This post will provide an initial assessment of the turntable’s condition. A follow-up post will detail the restoration process to bring it back to like-new performance.

Upon unboxing and inspecting the unit:

The dust cover shows typical signs of wear:

The hinges are intact, suggesting either polishing for extended use or replacement with a new reproduction from the Beoparts-store in Denmark.

The control keypad exhibits moderate wear:

To prevent further deterioration, a Beolover Commander remote control system could be installed. This allows full functionality through an Apple remote (or a Beo4 for integration with a modern B&O system).

The plinth is in fair condition. While the right corner requires re-gluing and has a minor chip at the base:

the left corner remains in good shape:

Additionally, there are a few minor dents and scratches:

Overall, this is expected for a turntable of its age.

Removing the aluminum panels and platter revealed the internal components:

The turntable appears to be mainly in its original state, with no evident modifications. This is ideal for restoration, as prior repair attempts can introduce unforeseen complications.

The 4002 has the common issue of deteriorated transport lock bushings, as evidenced by the orange plastic fragments:

Fortunately, this is easily addressed by installing new Beolover transport lock bushings.

When powered on, the platter motor started immediately, suggesting a malfunctioning off-switch. Upon examining the small circuit board beneath the carriage, the issue was apparent:

The plastic extension needed for actuation by the carriage assembly when reaching the home position was missing. While I haven’t located it within the enclosure yet, it’s possible it’s lodged under the floating chassis or circuit boards. If not found during disassembly, a 3D-printed Beolover replacement part will be used.

In conclusion, this Beogram 4002 provides a solid foundation for complete functional restoration. Updates to follow!

item.title: Beogram 4000: Full Functional Restoration and a Test Spin with the Bill Evans Trio
item.description:
This article details the restoration of a Beogram 4000 turntable from a Massachusetts customer. The initial evaluation can be found here.

The restoration began by addressing the carriage system. This involved cleaning hardened lubricants from various parts like the arm lowering mechanism, rods, spindle, linkages, and damper, and applying modern synthetic lubricants.

A key aspect of the Beogram 4000 is its solenoid-activated switches, which frequently experience oxidation and require attention. The contact terminals were removed and re-plated with nickel and gold-cobalt alloy for optimal performance and corrosion resistance. A cracked circuit board related to the solenoid current was repaired with epoxy.

The turntable’s MMC cartridge mount, known to be fragile, was replaced with a 3D-printed nylon and flex-PCB assembly. The tonearm was carefully removed, the old mount extracted, and the new one installed and secured using a specialized tool.

The existing solenoid arm, exhibiting a common crack, was fitted with a durable replacement extension. The carriage’s original rubber damper gasket was also switched out to ensure smooth arm lowering.

Next, the electronic components and platter motor were addressed. The main, motor, and reservoir capacitors were replaced, along with the RPM relay, trimmers, and record sensor transistor. The AC motor was disassembled, its bearings treated with oil, and then reassembled. A more robust Zener diode was installed in the power supply for voltage stability.

The power transistors in the AC motor driver were upgraded for better performance, and the sensor transistor bias was meticulously calibrated.

The keypad cluster was then restored. The bulbs illuminating the RPM trimmers and carriage position scale were replaced with LEDs for longevity and efficiency. The keypad switch terminals underwent a cleaning and plating process to combat oxidation. The sensor arm’s incandescent bulb was also replaced with a custom LED assembly.

The signal path was optimized by installing a switch to connect the signal and system grounds, mitigating potential hum issues. The aging DIN5 plug was exchanged for a modern, gold-plated one.

Worn plinth guidance washers were replaced with robust nylon versions. After these replacements, the floating chassis, platter height, arm parallelism, and platter-to-arm distance were meticulously adjusted. A nut was added to the counterweight adjustment screw to maintain calibration.

The arm lowering limit was set to safeguard the stylus from contacting the platter, and the tracking weight was calibrated for optimal performance. The tracking feedback was fine-tuned to ensure correct arm alignment during playback.

The platter drive’s RPM stability was rigorously assessed using the BeoloverRPM device, revealing excellent results. Oscilloscope measurements confirmed the motor’s proper function.

Finally, the restored Beogram 4000 was tested with a pristine vinyl record, delivering exceptional sound quality.

The original, scratched turntable hood was also replaced with a pristine version from Beoparts-store. This involved refurbishing and repainting the hood hinge and meticulously aligning and attaching a new aluminum trim to the new hood.

The Beogram 4000, now fully restored, is ready to return to its owner for years of listening enjoyment.

item.title: Beogram 4000: A New Arrival from Massachusetts
item.description:
It’s always wonderful to see a returning customer! Earlier this year, I restored a Beogram 4000 for a client in Massachusetts. Now, I’m excited to work on another Beogram 4000 he’s sent my way. It seems one can never have too many Beograms!

The Beogram 4000 arrived safely, shipped securely in a Beolover box. It was accompanied by a thoughtful gift for Beolover, for which I am incredibly grateful.

This beautiful reissue of “Waltz for Debby” by the Bill Evans Trio, a legendary jazz record, is a 180g pressing. What better way to commemorate the restoration of this Beogram 4000 than with this timeless recording, captured live at the Village Vanguard in 1961?

My initial assessment of the Beogram 4000’s exterior is positive. The aluminum surfaces are well-maintained.

Similarly, the plinth corners appear sharp, exhibiting only minor imperfections.

Upon removing the platter and panels for an internal examination, the unit appears largely original. A common issue – a stress fracture in the carriage pulley – is beginning to emerge.

Fortunately, the red position indicator remains undamaged.

I connected the Beogram 4000 to a power source and initiated playback. The RPM adjustment strobe light flickered to life with a robust orange hue.

This is a great sign! Additionally, the deck accurately located the LP setdown point, and the solenoid activated. These are all positive indicators. This restoration appears to be straightforward. Keep an eye out for updates!

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Complete Functional Restoration and Installation of a Beolover Commander Remote Control
item.description:
This article details the comprehensive restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable. The initial evaluation of this unit is detailed in a separate post.

The turntable was first disassembled, revealing the need for bearing lubrication in the platter motor, a common issue in these models. This process typically takes a few days.

While the bearings were being re-lubricated, the intricate carriage mechanism, responsible for raising and lowering the tonearm, was addressed. Hardened lubricants were replaced, ensuring smooth operation and preventing potential damage to the tonearm.

Next, the electronics were painstakingly restored. Key components, including capacitors, transistors, and relays, were replaced with modern equivalents to enhance performance and longevity. The incandescent bulbs were also upgraded to LED assemblies for improved lifespan and a modern aesthetic.

The turntable was then meticulously reassembled, paying close attention to critical adjustments. This included setting the platter height and parallelism, aligning the floating chassis, and calibrating the tracking weight for optimal playback.

Finally, a Beolover Commander remote control was installed, allowing for full functionality without using the delicate keypad. After rigorous testing and a final cleaning, the Beogram 4002 was ready to return to its owner, fully restored to its former glory.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): A New Arrival from Tennessee
item.description:
A Beogram 4002 (Type 5513) turntable arrived from a Tennessee customer for a complete restoration. The turntable was shipped safely in a Beolover container. This post focuses on the turntable’s initial condition upon arrival.

The first photo shows the turntable as it was unpacked.

The dust cover has numerous scratches and a spot that appears to be chemical damage. Replacing the existing cover with a new one from Beoparts-shop in Denmark is recommended, along with a new reproduction of the aluminum strip.

The dust cover hinge also exhibits corrosion, as seen in the photo.

The paint in these areas will soon flake off, exposing the aluminum underneath.

The dust cover was removed to assess the cosmetic condition of the turntable.

The aluminum surfaces are in good shape with no significant damage. The keypad is also well-preserved, with only faint fingerprints visible under specific lighting.

The turntable is a good candidate for a Beolover Commander remote control system installation. This system allows for complete operation without touching the keypad. It’s best to avoid using the keypad if it’s in good condition, as the oils in skin can degrade the keys’ coating. Alternatively, a soft cloth can be used to press the keys.

The plinth remains in good condition, showing only slight damage on the bottom corners.

These imperfections can be concealed with a color-matched crayon.

Two of the enclosure’s plastic feet are absent, replaced with glued-on rubber bumpers.

Hopefully, these can be removed without damaging the paint and replaced with appropriate rubber feet.

After the visual inspection, the aluminum panels were removed to examine the internal components.

The unit seems to be all original, which is ideal for restoration purposes. As is typical with 4002s of this age, the orange transport lock bushings are beginning to deteriorate.

When powered on, the carriage moved slowly towards the LP setdown point, successfully engaging the solenoid. The platter motor is also operational. These are all positive signs.

This appears to be a fairly straightforward restoration project. The next update will detail the work completed.

item.title: Beogram 4002: Installation of a Brand New Hood and Aluminum Trim
item.description:
I recently obtained a Beogram 4002 hood hinge from Florida to use in the installation of a new hood. The first photo shows its condition upon arrival.

A closer look revealed the problem:

The mounting holes on the hood had developed a fracture. This is a common issue caused by the original design choices made by B&O. The use of flat head bolts placed lateral stress on the plexiglass, leading to cracks and eventual breakage.

Fortunately, new hoods with improved bolt design are available, promising better durability. These replica hoods, faithful to the original design, are available for purchase from the Beoparts store in Denmark.

This image showcases the new hood alongside a reproduction aluminum trim for the 4002. The photo captures the trim being centered on the hood using a pair of custom-designed alignment brackets.

After marking the alignment on blue tape, the new hood can be attached to the hinge. Removing the sliding pads beneath the springs provides better lateral movement for the hinges, simplifying bolt installation.

Once the bolts are secured, the pads can be put back in place.

Finally, the aluminum strip is glued to the hood. This completes the installation of a brand new hood for this nearly 50-year-old Beogram 4002!

The hood will soon be returned with a Beolover internal RIAA pre-amp and a Beolover Commander remote control system. What a fantastic upgrade! Truly Beolovely!

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5503): Installation of Upgrades - Internal RIAA Preamp, Commander Remote Control and a New Hood
item.description:
Following the functional restoration of a Beogram 4002 (Type 5503) from Oklahoma, the next step was to add the customer’s desired upgrades. These included an internal Beolover RIAA pre-amplifier (designed for AC motor Beogram 4002s), a Beolover Commander remote control system, and a new hood for a pristine appearance.

The first upgrade was preparing the keypad for the Commander remote system. AC motor Beograms primarily use directly soldered wiring harnesses, so Commander installation isn’t “plug and play” like the DC motor version. It requires creating a breakout for keypad signals, allowing the Commander to interface with the Beogram’s control system.

This involved accessing the keypad PCB, identifying the solder pads connecting to the wiring harness responsible for keypad signals, and carefully creating a “corridor” by removing some solder. A keypad breakout adapter was then soldered onto these pads, ensuring a precise and secure connection. This adapter essentially mirrors the keypad pad connections to a small white connector.

Before proceeding with the Commander installation, the Beolover RIAA preamp board was installed, taking advantage of the exposed area with the keypad removed. This involved a straightforward swap of the original output board with the new green RIAA board, utilizing the same connectors for ease of installation.

With the modified keypad board back in place, the Commander board was installed using an existing main PCB bolt hole. A quick test with an Apple Remote confirmed the Commander’s functionality, successfully moving the carriage. The grounding connector of the RIAA board was then secured to the plastic fixture that holds the output board, utilizing the enclosure itself as a grounding point.

The final step was replacing the existing scratched hood. After removing the aluminum trim and hinge assembly from the old hood, the hinges were inspected for damage using a template to ensure they were straight. The hinges passed inspection, and the new hood installation involved attaching the hinges, aligning and securing the replacement aluminum trim strip, and admiring the results. The Beogram was now ready for its trip back to Oklahoma!

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5503): Complete Functional Restoration
item.description:
This document details the refurbishment process of a Beogram 4002 (Type 5503) turntable with an AC motor. The unit was received from a customer in Oklahoma, and an initial evaluation was documented previously here.

Upon arrival, the unit was partially disassembled, revealing its internal components. One of the first tasks involved addressing a loose spring in the shut-off switch, which was successfully reinserted to restore functionality.

The restoration began with the carriage assembly. This involved cleaning and re-lubricating all moving parts. The carriage PCB was rebuilt with a new capacitor, solenoid resistor, and a white LED replacing the original incandescent bulb in the position sensor. The solenoid arm extension, often prone to cracks, was replaced with a 3D-printed part. A new rubber damper gasket was also installed to ensure smooth arm lowering.

Attention was then given to the damper-to-tonearm linkage, requiring the sensor arm to be detached from the carriage for cleaning and lubrication. A small copper plate, essential for lateral arm movement, was re-attached with epoxy after cleaning. Both arms were then carefully realigned to be parallel to each other and orthogonal to the carriage rods. Finally, the original, fragile carriage pulley was exchanged for a more durable aluminum replica.

The AC platter motor underwent a revitalization process. Following extraction from the unit, the motor was disassembled. The enclosure halves were then submerged in motor oil and subjected to a vacuum to draw out air and allow for thorough oil penetration.

Concurrent with the motor oil infusion, other areas of the Beogram received attention. The output board was removed, and both the output relay and its associated capacitor were replaced. As a preventative measure against potential hum issues, a switch was added to enable the connection of system and signal grounds, a common solution when pairing the Beogram with amplifiers using RCA inputs.

The main PCB underwent a comprehensive restoration, which included replacing all electrolytic capacitors, power transistors, RPM trimmers, and the sensor arm circuit’s high gain transistor. Two aging tantalum capacitors on the PCB’s copper side were also replaced. New reservoir and motor capacitors were installed, neatly arranged with a custom-designed 3D-printed fixture.

Next, the three incandescent bulbs were replaced with LEDs. The two bulbs within the RPM adjustment panel were replaced first. The bulb covers were found to be deformed from heat exposure, a common issue due to frequent 33 RPM playback. Beolover LED assemblies were soldered directly to the existing bulb terminals. The last bulb to be replaced, located within the sensor arm compartment, was also swapped with a Beolover LED assembly.

The plinth guidance washers, exhibiting typical cracking, were replaced with 3D-printed nylon replicas. A black washer was used at the front for aesthetic purposes, while white washers were installed on the sides.

The restoration process culminated in a series of meticulous measurements and calibrations. The motor’s AC signal was verified, confirming the correct frequencies for both 33 and 45 RPM. The tracking feedback was then fine-tuned, uncovering a crack in the sensor assembly circuit board that hindered tracking functionality. This issue was resolved by soldering two bridges. The sensor arm transistor’s bias was adjusted by replacing the fixed resistor with a 5MOhm trimmer. Following the platter’s reinstallation, sensor response was measured and found to be within acceptable parameters.

The platter arm distance was carefully adjusted, and the platter was leveled in relation to the arm’s movement. The floating chassis was then meticulously aligned to ensure the platter sat flush with the surrounding aluminum panels.

After these adjustments, the tonearm’s tracking weight was calibrated. This involved replacing the counterweight adjustment screw’s circlip with an M3 nut. The tracking weight dial was then calibrated for accuracy at 1.2g, the optimal weight for most B&O cartridges. The arm lowering limit was set as a safety measure to prevent the arm from being lowered onto a platter without a record in place, especially in cases of record detection circuit malfunctions.

Addressing a common aesthetic issue, the 33 RPM adjustment scale, exhibiting a wavy background due to heat damage from the original bulb, was replaced with a new white background using 3M white electrical tape, resulting in a pristine appearance. Lastly, the original, corroded DIN 5 plug was replaced with a new, all-metal version featuring gold-plated terminals.

A 24-hour RPM test using the BeoloverRPM device yielded exceptional results, showcasing the stability of the classic synchronous motor design.

With the restoration complete, the Beogram 4002 played flawlessly. The next phase of the project will involve integrating the Beolover Commander remote control system to preserve the existing keypad and installing a Beolover RIAA preamp. This internal preamp will bypass the output board, allowing the Beogram to connect to a wider array of modern amplifiers that lack a dedicated phono input, ensuring this classic turntable can be enjoyed for years to come.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5503): When Disaster Strikes! - Replacement of the Solenoid Switch and Restoration of a Melted Solenoid
item.description:
It seems my Beogram 4002 customer in Arizona is having arm lowering issues again, just a short time after my last repair in December 2022. Upon opening the unit, I discovered the solenoid had completely melted down due to a faulty arm extension I had previously installed. This prevented the solenoid switch from deactivating, leading to overheating and ultimately, failure.

To fix this, I crafted a new solenoid coil and replaced the melted one. However, I soon realized the solenoid wasn’t activating at full power because of a faulty solenoid switch. Replacing this part proved challenging, as the original switches are no longer available.

As a solution, I decided to use a 3D printer end switch to control a power transistor. This setup significantly reduces the electrical load on the switch, making it a viable replacement. I carefully mounted and wired the new components onto the solenoid switch PCB.

For the arm extension, I opted for a more robust design using a self-tapping screw and epoxy to reinforce the connection points. I tested the new setup and found that the voltage measurements across the solenoid during operation were comparable to a properly functioning unit.

With the new switch and reinforced arm extension, the arm lowering mechanism is now back in working order. Despite these setbacks, I remain committed to achieving perfection in my Beogram restorations.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Repair of a Broken Sensor Arm Photocell with Three SMD Photodiodes
item.description:
During the restoration of a Beogram 4002 turntable, a broken photocell presented a challenge. This component, crucial for record detection, was no longer available. While a previous solution involved using a modern phototransistor with circuit modifications, a simpler approach was considered.

Recognizing the functional similarity between photovoltaic cells and the original photocell, a test was conducted using readily available photodiodes. Initial results with a single photodiode proved insufficient, but connecting three in parallel yielded a promising voltage output.

The photodiode assembly, mounted without the original insulator tubes, produced a robust signal, successfully replicating the function of the obsolete photocell. This allowed for the restoration to be completed without modifying the turntable’s circuitry, and the Beogram was returned to its owner fully operational.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5503): A New Arrival From Oklahoma - A First Look
item.description:
A Beogram 4002 (Type 5503) turntable arrived for a complete restoration. The turntable was packaged well and arrived in good condition.

While the dust cover is intact, it does have some scratches and might need polishing or replacement. The turntable itself is in good shape, with only minor blemishes on the aluminum surfaces and minimal wear on the keypad. Using a soft cloth to operate the keypad or installing a remote control module would help preserve its condition.

The plinth is in excellent condition with nearly perfect corners. However, an internal inspection revealed the transport lock bushings had deteriorated, leaving fragments inside. One of the lock bushings is missing entirely, and the plinth guiding washers are cracked.

Previous work on the turntable is evident. A replacement tracking sensor light source is installed, and the plexiglass ruler used for carriage position detection was removed, although included with the turntable. The carriage end switch metal strip was also bent, but hopefully salvageable.

Initial testing showed promising results with the carriage and platter motor functioning. As expected without the ruler installed, the carriage did not stop at the correct position. This restoration appears straightforward. Updates to follow!

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Brand New Hood Fatally Damaged Due to Bent Hood Hinges! - Straightening Hinges Out and Installation of Another Hood
item.description:
I recently refurbished a Beogram 4002 (Type 5513) for a Florida-based client and installed a new dust cover purchased from beoparts-shop in Denmark. These dust covers are remarkable replicas, made with the same die-cast process as the originals, resulting in a seamless finish.

However, a problem arose with this particular dust cover. When closing it, there was slight friction on the hinge approximately halfway through its movement. While I initially dismissed it as an insignificant tolerance issue common in older manufacturing, the issue escalated.

Days later, my customer sent me a concerning photo showing the dust cover had cracked at the hinge, near one of the screws. It was evident the friction was the likely cause, stressing the hood, but the source of the friction remained unclear. The metal components appeared fine upon initial inspection.

After contacting Martin Olsen, the designer of the replica dust covers, he mentioned a similar encounter with a customer’s dust cover that wouldn’t fit correctly. He discovered the hinges were misaligned, with one sitting too high and forward, resulting in a 2mm gap.

Intrigued, I examined the hinges from the damaged hood against those from a properly functioning one. The comparison revealed a discrepancy in the angle between the two shanks – the problematic hinges had a smaller angle, confirming Martin’s observation.

To rectify this, I used a 3D-printed template, meticulously iterated for a precise fit, to reshape the flawed hinges. Using a vise and adjustable pliers, I carefully bent them until they aligned with the template’s alignment hole.

With the hinges reshaped, I reassembled the hinge mechanism, incorporating a 3D-printed replica for a missing plastic slider block. The next steps involved installing the repaired dust cover and a new replica aluminum strip, ensuring perfect centering with alignment tools.

Finally, I attached the dust cover and secured the strip. I’m pleased to report this dust cover no longer had friction issues.

The root cause of the hinge deformation remains uncertain. However, based on the dust cover’s design, it’s plausible that forcefully opening it beyond its limits could have caused the hinges to bend and the angle to decrease. This experience underscores the importance of handling delicate equipment with care.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): Repair of an Intermittent Sensor Arm Light Source
item.description:
A Beogram 4002 turntable, which I had previously restored in May 2022, recently came back to my workshop due to a malfunctioning sensor arm LED. This was concerning because I had implemented a redesigned LED assembly for this particular unit.

To my relief, the LED functioned correctly when I powered up the turntable in my workshop. This suggested an intermittent problem that resolved itself during transport.

I tried manipulating the plugs and cables, but the LED remained illuminated. The LED would only flicker and turn off occasionally when I applied pressure on the main PCB near the sensor arm light power supply components (located around P4).

A thorough examination of the solder joints connected to the sensor arm circuitry exposed a faulty solder point on the collector of TR5, the transistor responsible for powering the light. The collector of TR5 supplies power to the LED via a 1R36 resistor connected to the 24V power rail.

Re-soldering this point rectified the issue.

Prior to this restoration, I hadn’t realized the importance of preemptively replacing the H-bridge power transistors of the carriage drive. These transistors tend to fail after a period of use, so I have incorporated their replacement into my standard Beogram 400x restoration process.

Therefore, I seized this opportunity to upgrade the main PCB by substituting the original BC144/143 transistors with contemporary 2N3019 and 2N4033 components, which have identical packaging and can be directly swapped.

Before returning the Beogram to my Colorado-based customer, I will thoroughly test its functionality to ensure no further issues exist.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Full Functional Restoration and Installation of Beolover Commander Remote
item.description:
This document details the restoration of a Beogram 4002 (Type 5513) turntable. Initial assessment of the unit can be found on a separate blog post.

The restoration began with the platter motor, as its bearings require a lengthy oil treatment. The motor was extracted, disassembled, and its bearings were submerged in oil under a vacuum to allow for optimal oil diffusion.

Concurrently, the carriage assembly was cleaned. All “motion critical” parts, including the arm and its associated mechanisms, were removed, ultrasonically cleaned, and reassembled. The damper gasket and tracking sensor light source were replaced with new components. The damper-to-arm linkage was also lubricated, requiring the removal and reattachment of the sensor arm assembly. A small copper plate, essential for smooth arm movement, was re-glued.

Next, the PCBs underwent restoration. The main PCB’s power Darlingtons were replaced with stronger TIP107 transistors. After removing the PCB, the RPM section was updated with a new Siemens RPM relay and adjustment trimmers. All electrolytic capacitors and power transistors on the board were replaced. The output board was also restored with a new output relay, a timing capacitor, and a ground switch for reducing hum.

The main reservoir capacitor was then replaced with a custom 3D-printed assembly housing two standard capacitors. The decayed transport lock bushings were replaced, and the plinth was reattached using 3D-printed nylon replicas of the original guidance washers.

All remaining incandescent bulbs were replaced with LED-based assemblies for improved longevity and performance. This included the sensor arm compartment bulb and the bulbs on the RPM adjustment panel.

The turntable underwent mechanical adjustments to ensure the platter was parallel to the arm’s travel and at the correct height. The floating chassis was also calibrated to ensure the platter was flush with the aluminum panels. The tracking weight was set to 1.2g, and the arm lowering limit was adjusted to prevent damage to the stylus.

Electronic adjustments included setting the sensor transistor bias and the tracking sensor feedback. The platter motor’s RPM stability was tested over a 24-hour period, demonstrating excellent performance. However, the sensor response test revealed a malfunctioning photocell with a detached electrode, which will require further repair. A functional sensor compartment was temporarily installed to enable testing.

Finally, the original DIN5 plug was replaced, and a Beolover Commander remote control module was installed for enhanced usability. A new hood, sourced from Denmark, was installed with a reproduction aluminum trim strip.

After a final test using a meticulously cleaned vinyl record, the restored Beogram 4002 awaits the photocell repair and its return to California.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (Type 5513): A New Arrival from California - First Assessment
item.description:
I recently received a Beogram 4002 turntable (model 5513) from a California customer. The turntable was shipped in a container provided by Beolover, ensuring a smooth transit process. This article details my initial assessment of the unit.

Upon unboxing, the turntable appeared to be in fair cosmetic condition. However, there were noticeable fingerprints on the keypad and a few minor scratches on the aluminum panel. The plinth corners, on the other hand, were well-preserved. Unfortunately, the hood had detached from the hinges, a common issue caused by stress on the bolts that secure the plexiglass, leading to cracks over time. Thankfully, replacement hoods are now readily available from a supplier in Denmark.

Internally, the turntable’s components were mostly original and showed minimal signs of prior repairs. However, there were remnants of deteriorated transport lock bushings near the platter motor. The bushings themselves were missing entirely, and the plinth’s original guidance washers had been substituted with standard washers, which lack the necessary guiding function.

When powered on, the turntable’s carriage began to move, and the platter motor produced a rumbling sound, suggesting dry bearings. This is a common problem in these models due to years of use. Positively, the arm reached the LP setdown point, indicating a functional carriage position detection system.

In conclusion, this Beogram 4002 appears to require a straightforward functional restoration. Updates to follow!

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5503): Repair of a Dead H-Bridge and Some Other Updates
item.description:
A Beogram 4002 turntable, previously restored in 2020, returned for repair. The issue was a familiar one: the carriage wouldn’t move towards the platter, suggesting a faulty power transistor in the carriage motor’s H-bridge.

This recurring problem has become a pattern, leading to a routine replacement of the H-bridge transistors during restorations. However, this wasn’t standard practice in 2020, necessitating the turntable’s return for transistor replacement.

Along with the H-bridge transistors, other known problematic components were also updated. This included replacing the AC platter motor drive’s power transistors – the TIP31/32 pair – with more robust TIP41/42s. The solenoid transistor, a TIP41, was upgraded to a higher voltage TIP41C.

The original light bulb in the carriage position sensor assembly was also replaced with a white LED. Precise LED placement was crucial, ensuring proper operation of the ‘run-off-stop’ mechanism.

Another common weakness in these turntables, a soldered fuse (F1) with high resistance, was addressed. The faulty fuse was removed, and a new one with soldered wires was installed.

The solenoid lever, another vulnerability, had a plastic extension with stress cracks around the rivet. This extension is vital to prevent solenoid overheating. The damaged part was removed and replaced with a 3D-printed version.

Finally, the hardened damper gasket was replaced, ensuring smooth arm lowering. With these updates, the Beogram 4002 now meets the latest restoration standards. After a period of testing, it will return to its owner in California.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Repair of a Cracked Solenoid Arm, Replacement of the Damper Gasket and Re-Glueing of a Plinth Corner
item.description:
This Beogram 4000 required a few final adjustments before it could be returned to its owner following a wiring sleeve replacement on the carriage harness and a fix for an intermittent solenoid.

During its initial restoration in 2020, I was unfamiliar with some common problems that these turntables develop. One such issue involves the damper gasket, which tends to harden over time. This hardening can lead to uneven arm lowering due to inconsistent airflow around the gasket.

The original gasket and the newly installed replacement are shown in the images.

Another characteristic of this Beogram 4000 is its solenoid lever. This lever, commonly found on AC motor 4002 models, has a plastic extension that activates the solenoid switch. Over time, these extensions are prone to developing cracks and breaking off entirely at their rivet attachment point. A complete break can result in a damaged solenoid. To prevent this, the original lever was swapped with a 3D-printed replacement. Photos depict the original lever with a hairline crack, the new 3D-printed lever, and the lever in both its resting and extended positions, successfully engaging the solenoid switch.

Another issue I encountered is that the BC142/143 power transistors commonly drift out of spec with age. This has, in the past, led to carriage drive H-bridge failures and repeat repairs. To address this, I’ve made it standard practice to preemptively replace these transistors in my Beogram restorations. This Beogram required an update with new, compatible transistors. Images show both the original and replacement transistors within the H-bridge circuit.

The remaining power transistors were also replaced as a preventative measure.

Lastly, one corner of the plinth had become unglued. The plinth was removed and re-glued to rectify this.

With these adjustments, the Beogram 4000 is functioning well again. Hopefully, this repair will provide a lasting solution, keeping it off my workbench for a good while.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Repair and Exploration of an Intermittently Oscillating Solenoid
item.description:
This section details the work done on the Beogram 4000’s oscillating solenoid, and what was learned about winding solenoid coils and comparing them to the original.

The arm lowering mechanism is shown here:

When the control logic initiates arm lowering, the solenoid pushes the solenoid lever forward. The lever opens the solenoid switch when fully extended, decreasing the current flowing through the solenoid to a level just enough to keep it engaged.

This electronic operation is depicted in the circuit diagram snippet below:

Lowering Q1’ from 6V to 0V activates the solenoid. This action turns off RT10 through 1R25 and 1D3, which in turn activates 1TR11. This pulls up 0TR4’s base, and maximum current flows through the solenoid because its lower end is directly connected to GND via the solenoid switch. The solenoid switch opens once the solenoid is fully activated, forcing current to flow solely through the solenoid power resistor 7R1. This significantly reduces the current passing through the solenoid.

Q1’ rises to 6V when it’s time to lift the arm, and the current through the solenoid stops, allowing it to return to its starting position due to the solenoid return spring. This also closes the solenoid switch, preparing the solenoid for the next time Q1’ goes low.

Therefore, a solenoid oscillation usually indicates a problem with the GND connection via the solenoid switch: Q1’ activates the solenoid, but insufficient current causes the return spring to drive it back. Because the spring is slack again, the solenoid extends again, and so on, causing the oscillation.

Based on previous experience, all connections and wires were checked, but the wiring and solenoid switch appeared to be fine. The intermittent nature of the oscillation suggested this was not a typical case. A broken wire usually produces this behavior reliably.

As a result, a more in-depth investigation was required. An oscilloscope was connected to 0TR4’s collector (yellow trace) and base (blue), and the ’normal behavior’ was measured when the solenoid was not oscillating.

As you can see, the base voltage struggles to rise during the initial current burst and only reaches full magnitude after the current settles.

At this point, the ‘brrrr’ behavior could be induced approximately every 50 arm lowering activations. After repeated pressing of the up and down buttons, the ‘brrrr’ sound was finally heard and measured:

After an initially normal activation, the solenoid begins to oscillate. Because 0TR4’s base appeared to follow a similar pattern as during the initial lowering, it was concluded that Q1’ itself, the control logic, may have been the source of the oscillation. The fact that the initial lowering was executed flawlessly and that the next lowering sequence was only carried out after maybe 20ms supported this theory.

As a result, the Q1’ signal (blue) and the 0TR4 collector (yellow) were measured. These are the traces for a typical arm lowering sequence:

When Q1’ goes low, the solenoid is activated, and the solenoid switch opens, lowering the voltage at the collector.

The following traces were measured during a ‘brrr’ moment after more ups and downs with the buttons:

This confirmed that the issue was not with the control system because Q1’ did not change during the ‘brrr’ event. This was a positive discovery because a faulty logic chip would have added a new layer of complexity to the project. This result at the very least indicated that a component or connection after Q1’ must have triggered the issue. TR10/11/0TR4, as well as the spark snubber diode connected across the solenoid leads, were replaced:

This, however, had no effect. After a series of ups and downs, the (now dreaded) ‘brrrr’ returned.

After reviewing all of the oscilloscope measurements taken at various points in the solenoid circuit, it became clear that 0TR4’s collector going to zero during the ‘brrr’ moments meant that the connection between 0TR4 collector and the top of the solenoid, which is hardwired to ~40V, must be open circuit! Because Q1’ remained constant during the oscillation events, 0TR4 remained on, and the collector was no longer pulled up.

In the absence of bad solder joints, the solenoid itself was the most likely source of the problem. The original solenoid was replaced with one borrowed from a Beogram 4004:

The oscillation could no longer be replicated with this new solenoid in place, despite numerous attempts. With this replacement solenoid, however, an intriguing curve was measured:

The yellow trace represents 0TR4’s collector, and we can observe a brief dip in collector voltage about 5 ms after the arm makes contact with the solenoid switch. This was interpreted as switch bounce caused by mechanical oscillation of the switch terminal. This is supported by the fact that the phenomenon did not always occur, and when it did, the timing varied slightly. Bouncing is a normal occurrence in mechanical switches. It could have been caused by the replacement solenoid’s slightly different actuation speed.

Because the replacement solenoid belonged to a perfectly functional Beogram that needed to be reinstalled soon, it was decided to build a replacement coil for the original solenoid. The first step was to disassemble it. It is depicted here after being removed from the arm lowering mechanism:

The first step is to remove the plunger. The bent extension is screwed into the magnetic field-driven plunger.

It can be easily unscrewed by holding the plunger with pliers (protect the plunger from being damaged by using tape for the jaws) and turning the extension:

The tapped plunger end and the separated extension are shown here:

Following the removal of the locking ring, the next step was to press out the metal tube from within the solenoid coil core. This was accomplished with an arbor press and a small screwdriver bit:

The coil can be removed once the tube is removed:

A replica of the plastic spool was designed and 3D printed:

Then, a stepper motor with two 3D-printed centers to hold the spool was set up,

and a basic program was written to control the stepper motor’s speed and count the turns it accumulates during spool winding. Then began the process of winding a new coil with 28 gauge ‘magnet wire,’ which appears to be very similar to the original wire. After a few attempts, sufficient skill was developed to wind the windings in a ‘homogeneous enough’ manner. By guiding the wire between fingers while the motor rotates the spool, the first three layers can be made nearly perfectly:

[![](https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEheLsEbBogzgicuMwAbPL9WT-nXy7jKFmVtaRxkIYViMCksWQ-6nIC4hsmieY9KbF-MeMv9pkTCkRNV0XB_dzZjOjtcUwrncy9ihHUlT6acKHX-uN_YA1TISc1rNneAHLr2ssla9f8HrzWAGPOfUUrWvMvgl1_UOx6Llwn1p7

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacement of Wiring Sleeve of Carriage Harness
item.description:
A Beogram 4000 turntable, previously restored in 2020, was brought in for repairs due to an oscillating solenoid issue. However, upon inspection, a more critical problem was discovered: the wiring harness sleeve was severely damaged, exposing the wires.

This level of damage had never been encountered before. Thankfully, the wires themselves were still intact. The timing of the solenoid problem was fortunate, as further use could have led to wire damage.

Replacing the sleeve was intricate, as it required disconnecting numerous wires connected to the carriage and a separate terminal board. To simplify future repairs, the wiring was meticulously documented.

During disassembly, the solenoid switch was found coated in oil and debris from the damaged sleeve. This contamination was initially thought to be the cause of the solenoid issue. The switch was cleaned and its resistance measured to ensure proper function.

The damaged sleeve was removed, and its length was determined to be approximately 160mm. To replace it, a new braided expandable sleeve was used. A 3D-printed tube was created to aid in feeding the wires through the sleeve.

After successfully threading the wires, the sleeve was secured at both ends using clamps and electrical tape, mimicking the original design. Continuity checks were performed on all wires before soldering them back to their respective terminals.

With the new sleeve in place, the carriage moved smoothly. However, the original issue of the oscillating solenoid still remained and required further investigation.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5524): Full Functional Restoration and Installation of Beolover Commander Remote
item.description:
This article details the restoration process of a Beogram 4002 turntable from Texas, following an initial assessment. The author mentions a slight delay due to relocating to Albuquerque.

The turntable was mostly original, suggesting a straightforward restoration. The process began with the DC platter motor, which is typical for these units. After nearly 50 years of use, the motor’s Oilite bearings needed re-lubrication. This involved disassembling the motor, immersing the bearings in oil, and creating a vacuum to help the oil penetrate.

While the bearings were being serviced, the restoration of the carriage began. The arm lowering mechanism was disassembled, cleaned in an ultrasonic cleaner, and reassembled with a new damper seal. A frequently stuck linkage in the arm lowering mechanism, responsible for transferring damper movement to the tonearm, was addressed. This required removing the sensor arm, re-attaching a loose copper pad, realigning the arms, and ensuring smooth operation.

A cracked plastic pulley on the carriage was replaced with a new aluminum version, and the original tracking sensor light bulb was swapped for a longer-lasting LED assembly.

Next, the PCBs were refurbished. The main PCB’s power Darlingtons were replaced, along with a stabilizing capacitor to eliminate ripple. All electrolytic capacitors, power transistors, the RPM relay, trimmers, and the sensor arm transistor were replaced as well. The output PCB received a new output relay, a capacitor for time constant adjustment, and a switch to connect signal and system grounds for hum reduction.

With the PCBs and keypad removed, the degraded transport lock bushings were replaced with 3D-printed replicas. The floating chassis was cleaned, and a new reservoir capacitor was installed. The remaining incandescent bulbs were replaced with LED assemblies, including those in the RPM adjustment panel and the sensor arm.

Adjustments were made to the tonearm height, platter alignment, arm weight calibration, arm lowering limit, tracking feedback, sensor transistor bias, and sensor signal. Finally, the RPM stability was checked and a new DIN5 plug was installed.

The customer also requested the installation of a Beolover Commander remote control for preserving the keypad’s delicate coating. The restoration concluded with a successful test play using a thoroughly cleaned vinyl record. The restored Beogram 4002, paired with the chosen album, exemplified a harmonious blend of aesthetics and audio.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Installation of a Brand New Hood
item.description:
Before returning the recently restored Beogram 4002 (5513) to its owner, one final detail needed attention: the original dust cover showed early signs of cracking around the hinges.

The owner opted for a brand new replacement dust cover from Beoparts-shop in Denmark. These reproduction dust covers are made using the same injection molding process as the originals, resulting in a seamless look, unlike previous versions made by fusing laser-cut panels. The result is indistinguishable from the original.

Here is the new dust cover alongside a matching reproduction aluminum trim:

Installing the new dust cover involved removing the hinge from the old one. This required prying off the aluminum trim to access the hinge bolts. With the bolts removed, the hinge came off easily.

Alignment helpers ensured accurate placement of the aluminum trim:

And here’s the finished product, complete with the secured hinge and glued aluminum trim:

This Beogram 4002 is now absolutely ready to be returned to its owner.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5524): A New Arrival from Texas - A Wrong Hood and Some Blown Fuses
item.description:
I recently acquired a Beogram 4002 (Type 5524) turntable from Texas. This particular model features a universal voltage DC motor and a power switch located beneath the unit.

The turntable arrived securely packaged in a specialized container, ensuring it was free from any shipping damage. Here’s a photo of the turntable as I received it:

B&O enthusiasts might immediately notice something peculiar about this image. The hood’s color seems to suggest it belongs to a Beogram 4000, not a 4002. A closer look at the aluminum trim confirms this suspicion:

Unlike the later gray-tinted Beogram 4002/4 hoods, this one has a brownish hue. I removed the unbolted hood to reveal the aluminum surfaces beneath, which were in decent condition with no major damage. Even the keypad was well-preserved, with only a minor scratch at the top center.

The plinth was in good shape as well. The right corner had some slight damage on the bottom,

while the left corner appeared almost untouched:

Upon removing the panels and platter, I discovered numerous transport lock fragments scattered within the turntable’s housing. Additionally, one of the hood bolt springs was stuck behind the left lock:

The other spring seemed to be missing, but I have suitable replacements. Overall, the turntable appeared to be largely original, with no obvious modifications:

When I connected the unit to power and pressed START, nothing happened. Closer inspection revealed both fuses were blown. To avoid blowing more fuses, I connected the turntable directly to a bench power supply via the reservoir capacitor leads:

Slowly increasing the voltage to 30V (ensuring correct polarity), I observed a low current draw (around 10mA), indicating a short circuit likely caused the blown fuses.

With power restored, pressing START brought the turntable to life. The platter motor made a rattling sound, suggesting dried-out bearings, and the arm moved to the LP setdown point. However, the solenoid couldn’t lower the arm, likely due to hardened lubricant impeding the mechanism.

Confident that the fuses wouldn’t immediately blow again, I replaced them with 250mA slow-blow fuses:

Powering on the turntable through the fuses produced the same results as the bench power supply test.

In conclusion, this Beogram 4002 project seems to be relatively straightforward. Stay tuned for a detailed restoration report.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Installation of a Brand New Beautiful Solid Oak Plinth! - Very Beolovely!!
item.description:
It’s another great day for a Beogram enthusiast like myself! I recently received two new Beogram plinths from Matt Spangler of Vintage HiFi Nut in Oregon. He’s an expert in restoring and replacing vintage HiFi wood cabinets.

I had sent him a Beogram 4000 and a Beogram 4002 plinth a while back. Both had been damaged in transit because of inadequate packaging, a frequent problem as people often don’t realize how rough shipping can be.

I got these two plinths back a few days ago and examined them today.

The top one is for a 4002 and the bottom one for a 4000. While similar in appearance, the metal frames on the 4000 and 4002/4 models differ due to variations in the keypad clusters and aluminum plates. Here’s a closer look at the precisely crafted corners:

The top frame is crafted from solid Granadillo (also known as ‘Mexican Rosewood’), while the bottom one is made from solid Oak. Due to overharvesting, the original hardwoods used by B&O, Brazilian Rosewood and Teak, are now protected species. Consequently, alternative hardwoods are necessary to achieve a similar aesthetic.

B&O did utilize oak in some of their Beogram models, making oak replacements a period-appropriate choice. I believe there’s room for flexibility with wood cabinets—if it looks fantastic on these classic designs, it’s a win!

This is the unfortunate condition of the Beogram 4000 I recently acquired:

I purchased this Beogram 4000 from a seller in Germany who, despite my guidance on packaging (including my video), opted against double-boxing and sufficient foam padding. As a result, the unit suffered damage to one corner. The minimal padding he used made this outcome sadly unsurprising.

While the right side only detached, the left side sustained irreparable damage:

Upon receiving the new frames from Matt, I opted to try the solid oak 4000 frame on this unit. I removed the aluminum panels, platter, and keypad to detach the damaged plinth:

Next, I installed the solid oak plinth with the 4000 metal frame. Here are some glimpses of this new plinth’s impressive look:

I’m incredibly pleased with the fresh and appealing oak finish. It complements the gleaming aluminum plates perfectly. Dare I say, I prefer it to the original teak frame! Matt’s work on this cabinet is truly exceptional! I’m excited to install the Granadillo frame on a 4002 in need.

This Beogram 4000 is well on its way to looking and performing like new! Once I’ve fully restored it, it will be ready for another B&O enthusiast to enjoy. Stay tuned!

item.title: Beogram 4002 (Type 5513): Complete Functional Restoration and a Spin with the Cal Tjader Quartet!
item.description:
This article details the restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable. The restoration began with addressing the motor, a common procedure for these models. After removing and disassembling the motor, the Oilite bearings were submerged in oil and placed under a vacuum for several days to replenish lubrication.

Next, the carriage and arm mechanisms were disassembled, cleaned, and re-lubricated. This included taking apart and servicing the damper. The main PCB was removed, and both power transistors were replaced. The PCB’s ‘RPM section’ was then refurbished: electrolytic capacitors were replaced, the H-Bridge’s power transistors were replaced, and the RPM relay and trimmers were replaced. Additionally, the transistor responsible for amplifying the record sensor signal was replaced to address potential record detection issues.

The keypad was then removed, revealing the output PCB. The output relay and its activation timing capacitor were replaced on this board. A switch was added to connect signal and system grounds, which can help resolve hum issues. The RPM adjustment panel’s light bulbs were replaced with Beolover RPM LED boards, offering improved longevity and visibility.

Before reassembling the carriage, the tracking sensor’s light bulb was replaced with a Beolover tracking sensor LED assembly, allowing for adjustable light intensity and more precise tracking feedback. The linkage connecting the arm lowering damper and the arm itself was cleaned, re-lubricated, and a new rubber gasket was installed in the damper plunger to enhance arm lowering consistency. The original plastic pulley, showing signs of wear, was replaced with a machined aluminum version.

The fragmented transport lock bushings, another common issue in these models, were replaced with new Beolover bushings. The main capacitor, a discontinued ‘dual-capacitance’ type, was replaced with a Beolover dual capacitance assembly, consisting of two individual capacitors. A 20k resistor was added for safety, ensuring the capacitor discharges appropriately when the turntable is unplugged.

The final bulb was replaced with a Beolover LED assembly, providing a plug-and-play upgrade for improved reliability. The record detection circuit was then calibrated, achieving a strong signal response. The RPM panel sockets, also prone to cracking in this model, were replaced with newly manufactured replicas.

The non-original and bulky RCA output cable was replaced with a period-appropriate DIN5 cable. The original board header was carefully preserved and soldered to the new cable. A 3D-printed replacement part was created for the cable retainer, ensuring proper fit and functionality. Finally, the motor bearings were reinstalled, and a 24-hour test demonstrated excellent RPM stability.

After final adjustments, including platter tilt, chassis alignment, tracking weight calibration, and tracking feedback sensitivity, the turntable was tested with a vintage Cal Tjader album. The restored Beogram 4002 performed flawlessly, showcasing its restored functionality and classic design.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (Type 5513): A New Arrival from Florida - First Assessment
item.description:
A local customer brought me a Beogram 4002 (5513) for restoration last year, opting for the safety of personal delivery. The unit is in decent condition, as seen upon arrival.

[Image]

The dust cover is nearly flawless, with one common hinge crack just starting to form.

[Image]

This makes it a perfect candidate for Beolover hinge patches to reinforce the area, especially since the crack hasn’t fully developed. Of course, new hoods are an option now as well. I carefully removed and stored the hood. The aluminum surfaces are in great shape, with a few minor imperfections but no significant damage.

[Image]

The keypad shows the typical marks from use.

The cartridge was still installed but thankfully protected by its cap, preventing damage to the cantilever during transport.

[Image]

I removed and stored the cartridge safely in a Beolover MMC storage box.

[Image]

Inspecting the plinth corners revealed them to be in excellent condition.

[Image]

[Image]

Next, I took out the aluminum panels and platter for an internal check.

[Image]

It mostly appears original, aside from an oversized RCA cable installation.

[Image]

The preference for such thick cables on turntables puzzles me. Cartridges produce minimal current (microamps), so resistance is less critical than shielding for the weak phono signals. Standard 26-28 gauge wires are more than sufficient for the current and offer superior flexibility for routing and installation. The original B&O DIN cables, with their full wire mesh shielding, are far superior to any RCA setup, in my opinion. Sadly, this quality and design are impossible to find in modern cables. While RCA cables often utilize the signal return as a shield, it’s a less effective method.

The transport locks, upon inspection, were the ‘orange’ type, known to deteriorate over time and requiring replacement.

[Image]

After this assessment, I powered on the unit and pressed START. The carriage began moving, and the platter motor started with a noisy indication of dried bearings. Continuing past the LP setdown point, the carriage hit the end-of-travel switch and returned to base, switching to 45 RPM during the initial inward movement. This confirmed a functioning carriage position sensor, while bypassing the setdown point suggested an issue with the record detection mechanism, which I’ll investigate further.

Overall, this Beogram offers an excellent base for complete restoration, promising like-new performance and aesthetics.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (Type 5513): Replacement of Carriage Position Sensor Photocell
item.description:
Over many years of working with the Beogram 400x, I’ve encountered a wide array of issues, but these turntables never cease to present new challenges. In this instance, a Beogram 4002 exhibited inconsistent behavior when attempting to locate the record’s setdown point after pressing start. This pointed to a potential fault in the carriage position sensor.

Initially, I suspected the IR LED, a common culprit in later models like this 5513 Type. I replaced the LED, adjusted the brightness, and achieved the desired 5V output at the photo sensor cathode. The unit seemed to function correctly, successfully finding the setdown point.

However, the issue resurfaced. The voltage fluctuated, and the setdown point was no longer reliably detected. I replaced the brightness adjustment trimmer, suspecting oxidation, but the problem persisted. With other components ruled out, I began to consider the photocell, despite never having had to replace one before. Testing the photocell with a multimeter revealed intermittent responsiveness, confirming its failure.

Because this specific photocell functions as a photoresistor in the circuit, I opted to replace it with a standard photoresistor. This required modifying the photocell housing to securely accommodate the new component. After redesigning and 3D printing a new insert, I was able to install a standard GL5539 photoresistor.

After experimenting with different photoresistor types, I found that the GL5539 provided consistent performance under various lighting conditions. It’s important to note that adjusting the LED intensity using R88 might be necessary to ensure reliable switching of TR17 based on the presence or absence of a black stripe in front of the sensor. Monitoring the collector voltage of TR17 with a voltmeter is recommended during this adjustment process.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (Type 5513): A New Arrival From California - First Impressions
item.description:
I recently began working on a Beogram 4002 Type 5513 from California, which needs a complete technical overhaul.

This post will provide an initial evaluation of the unit. It was delivered in excellent shape thanks to the customer’s careful packaging in a Beolover-provided shipping container. I was relieved because this device is in fantastic cosmetic shape. In the past, Beolover had a lot of “heartbreaking” experiences with units that arrived damaged because of inadequate packaging despite initially seeming pristine. This is particularly problematic when buying Beograms for repair on eBay or from other “uninitiated” vendors.
