Record Boost: With a Type II (Cr) tape loaded, I applied a 333 Hz, 30 millivolt sine wave from a signal generator and adjusted the record potentiometers until test points 1TP7 and 1TP8 measured 100 millivolts. I noted the measurements at test points 1TP3 and 1TP4. After switching the test signal to 19 KHz (keeping the amplitude at 30 millivolts), I adjusted the record potentiometers to match the readings at 1TP3 and 1TP4 to those previously noted. Finally, I adjusted variable inductors 1L201 and 1L401 until test points 1TP7 and 1TP8 measured 1.4 volts.

PPM Adjustment: I applied a 333 Hz, 300 millivolt sine wave and put the Beocord into Record (paused) mode. Adjusting the record potentiometers to achieve 660 millivolts at test points 2TP5 and 2TP6, I then fine-tuned trimmer 1R133 until the first red LED on the PPM display just began to glow.

Dolby Filter: Using the same test points (2TP5 and 2TP6), I temporarily connected 10 MΩ resistors between test points 1TP1 and 1TP2 to their respective tape head connections. With the Beocord in Record (paused) mode and the record potentiometers centered, I adjusted variable inductors 2L101 and 2L201 to minimize voltage readings at their corresponding test points.

Skewing: With the Dolby switch set to Dolby C, I applied a 19.9 KHz (±200 Hz) sine wave at 300 millivolts. Setting the Beocord to Record (paused) mode, I adjusted the record potentiometers until test points 2TP5 and 2TP6 measured 300 millivolts. Finally, I minimized deflection at the same test points using the Dolby Skewing adjustment variable inductors.

Bias and Recording Current: With the Dolby switch off, I set the Cr bias trimmers 3/4 turn to the right of center and the Recording Current trimmers to their center positions.

Bias Amplifier and Filter: I adjusted variable inductors 1L202, 1L402, 1L203 and 1L403 to minimize the DC voltage readings at test points 1TP9 and 1TP10 (measured with respect to -15 VDC).

Recording Current: Using a Type II (Cr) cassette, I applied a 333 Hz, 300 millivolt sine wave. With the Beocord in Record (paused) mode, I adjusted the record potentiometers until test points 2TP5 and 2TP6 measured 200 millivolts. After recording and playing back the signal, I adjusted trimmers 1R270 and 1R470 until the playback level also measured 200 millivolts.

Cr (Type II) Bias: With the same test setup, I recorded a 333 Hz signal at 20 millivolts (measured at 2TP5 and 2TP6). I then recorded a 15 KHz signal at the same level. Using the Cr Bias trimmers, I made adjustments until the playback levels of both the 333 Hz and 15 KHz signals matched at 20 millivolts.

Fe (Type I) Bias: Following a similar process to the Cr bias adjustment, I used a Type I (Fe) cassette and adjusted trimmer 1R159 until the playback levels of a 333 Hz and 15 KHz signal matched the previously established 20 millivolts.

MP (Type IV) Bias: Repeating the process again with a Type IV (MP) cassette, I adjusted trimmer 1R162 until the playback levels of the 333 Hz and 15 KHz signals matched. Notably, the playback levels for the MP tape were lower than those observed with the other tape types, but consistency between the 333 Hz and 15 KHz signals was the goal.

Advance: While I believe it is functioning correctly, the Advance adjustment using trimmer 1R182 yielded unexpected results. I need to investigate further to fully understand this adjustment.

With the electrical adjustments completed (except for the Advance), I can now move on to testing the Beocord 5000 with the Beomaster 5000 by recording and playing back music.

item.title: Beocord 5000 Type 4923: Tapehead cleaning and playback testing
item.description:
This update on the Beocord 5000 Type 4923 focuses on mechanical adjustments and tape head maintenance.

The post begins by addressing the sluggish opening and closing of the cassette drawer. While the belt had been replaced, the issue was traced to friction in the drawer slide mechanism. After disassembling and cleaning the mechanism, applying dry lubricant to the metal posts, and reassembling it, the drawer now operates smoothly.

The cassette assembly also underwent a thorough cleaning. Alcohol was used on the tape heads and metal capstan, while the rubber wheels were treated with CaiKleen. Molykote DX white grease was applied to specific components in the tape head slide assembly and roller bearings.

Following these mechanical adjustments, a series of tests were performed. Although the Beocord 5000 did not require extensive repairs or replacement parts, a basic speed drift and WOW & Flutter test was conducted using a Genn Lab calibration cassette and a Leader LFM-39A WOW & Flutter Meter.

The Beocord 5000 required minor adjustments to its motor to achieve optimal speed accuracy, as indicated by the Drift meter. Subsequently, WOW & Flutter measurements were taken using a DIN 3.15kHz test tape, revealing impressive results.

The author acknowledges that their testing methods might not precisely replicate those used by B&O. However, the results obtained using high-quality, non-B&O test equipment significantly surpass the performance specifications outlined in the Beocord 5000 service manual.

To conclude the restoration, the author plans to evaluate the recording capabilities of the Beocord 5000. Using TDK-MA (Metal) and TDK-SA (Chrome) tapes, as recommended by the service manual, test tone signals will be recorded and analyzed using an audio analyzer to assess the playback quality.

item.title: Beocord 5000 Type 4923: New power supply capacitors and belts
item.description:
In the last update on this Beocord 5000 (Type 4923), I was about to install new belts and replace the power supply’s electrolytic capacitors.

This post covers the completion of those tasks.

The original power supply capacitors are shown below.

…and the replacement capacitors are here.

Next up are the belts.

First is the tape counter belt.

Now for the clutch wheel and flywheel belts. Replacing these requires disassembling some brackets.

The clutch wheel belt is shown here.

And here is the flywheel belt.

Like its Beosystem 5000 counterparts, this Beocord 5000 needed new cabinet feet.

After reassembly, I connected the Beocord to its Beomaster 5000 for a quick test.

The Beocord is now functional again. Further functional testing is necessary, which will be the subject of the next post.

item.title: Beogram 4000: A New Arrival from Germany En Route to California
item.description:
I recently acquired a Beogram 4000 turntable from Germany, intended for a customer in California. My task is to refurbish the unit and deliver it to its new owner.

The turntable was poorly packaged for shipment, resulting in the keypad plates becoming detached during transit. This led to minor damage to the plates themselves and some cosmetic imperfections on other internal surfaces.

The aluminum surfaces are in surprisingly good shape considering the loose keypad plates.

There is, however, a post adhered to the main plate, potentially a remnant of a wet-play brush mount. I will need to attempt its removal, hopefully without causing any damage.

On a positive note, the plinth is in quite good condition, with the front corners appearing nearly pristine.

The hood requires polishing but doesn’t seem to have any cracks around the hinges, suggesting it can be restored to a presentable state.

The MMC mount is chipped, a common issue with the 4000 model, and will necessitate replacement with a reproduction part.

Upon removing the aluminum plates, I discovered that the red position indicator is still intact. These are frequently found broken or cracked, so this is a positive discovery.

As is typical, the plinth guidance washers are cracked.

Evidence of previous repairs is apparent in the reservoir and motor capacitor area, where some components have been replaced in a somewhat crude manner.

Additionally, the strobe light had become dislodged from its mounting points on the underside of the enclosure.

After connecting the unit to a 110V power supply, the AC platter motor immediately began running, and the strobe light illuminated. Remarkably, it endured transportation despite the potential for internal movement.

Despite these signs of functionality, the turntable did not respond to any keypad inputs. The scale and RPM trimmer illumination were also non-functional.

Voltage checks revealed that the 6V rail was not active. This voltage is responsible for powering the turntable’s control functions, managed by a hardwired logic circuit within the keypad cluster. Further examination indicated that the reed relay, which controls the 24V and 6V rails (excluding the AC motor) during startup, was only engaging the 24V circuit. Bypassing the 6V relay restored power to the control system.

Overall, this Beogram 4000 appears to be a promising candidate for restoration.

item.title: Beocord 5000 Type 4923: Initial assessment of another Beosystem 5000 companion component.
item.description:
This Beocord 5000 is the second cassette deck from Bang & Olufsen to bear this name. The original Beocord 5000, a Type 47xx model, was manufactured in the late 1970s. While distinct, both are high-quality cassette decks.

[Image]

[Image]

The Beocord 5000 Type 4923 aligns with the Beomaster 5000 Type 2323 and the CD50 Beosystem 5000 components in terms of size and design. Control and display access are provided both on the front panel and through a master remote control. The audio components within the system were designed to stack neatly.

A convenient mechanical feature allows for the removal of the top cover for maintenance. Loosening two screws at the back, sliding them upward, and then retightening them releases the cover.

[Image]

Here’s the Beocord with the cover removed.

[Image]

Four plastic transport locks are located on the bottom cover of the Beocord 5000. These locks secure the sliding cassette deck unit during transportation.

[Image]

The locks are turned to their “Open” position, removed, and stored in their designated slots.

[Image]

It’s not uncommon to find these transport locks missing in used Beocord 5000 Type 4923 units. Therefore, it’s a positive aspect that this particular unit retains its original locks.

Once the transport locks are removed, the sliding chassis of the Beocord 5000 becomes operational. As previously noted, the Beosystem 5000 components were designed for stackability. To accommodate this, the Beocord 5000 slides forward, extending from the cabinet to expose the controls and cassette tray. A motor and belt mechanism within the Beocord 5000 facilitates the movement of this sliding chassis.

[Image]

This Beocord arrived in a non-functional state, presenting the task of restoration.

Similar to other Beosystem 5000 components, the Beocord incorporates a service position that allows technicians to work on the unit conveniently.

The first step in placing the Beocord 5000 into its service position involves removing the plastic panel covering the cassette control area. Pressing in two plastic tabs on either side of the panel allows it to be lifted.

[Image]

With the panel lifted and a single cable unplugged, it can be set aside.

The next step is to remove the bright red plastic clips, as shown, to release the main circuit board for servicing. There are a total of six clips; in the photo below, one has already been removed.

[Image]

With the plastic panel removed, two screws on each side of the Beocord’s front panel become accessible. Removing these allows the front display panel to tilt forward.

[Image]

[Image]

The bundle of cables connecting the cassette mechanism’s tape heads to the main circuit board is secured by a couple of plastic clips, highlighted in the photo above. These cables need to be released from the clamps to allow for movement when the main circuit board is tilted upward into its service position.

Additionally, two metal rods securing the circuit board need to be released from their locked positions and tilted out of the way. The front connector to the display panel also needs to be disconnected.

Finally, the main circuit board can be lifted and placed into slots on the cabinet’s side, putting it into the service position.

[Image]

On the backside, two metal braces can be tilted forward to lock the main circuit board upright.

[Image]

Now, the cassette transport assembly can be removed for inspection.

Unsurprisingly, a broken belt is found. Fortunately, the belts haven’t degraded into a sticky, tar-like substance, which would have required extensive cleaning. The task at hand is simply to replace the old belts with new ones.

[Image]

Here’s the belt responsible for opening and closing the Beocord 5000’s sliding chassis. This will be replaced as well.

[Image]

The owner of this Beocord 5000 originally purchased it, along with the other Beosystem 5000 components, back in the 1980s. The system appears well-maintained. Therefore, no major electrical problems are anticipated. The electronic restoration plan for this cassette deck is to replace the electrolytic capacitors in the power supply. This area has been known to cause failures in some units after thirty-five years.

[Image]

As I didn’t have the specific axial electrolytic capacitors in stock, I’ll begin cleaning the interior and replacing the belts while waiting for the new capacitors to arrive from Mouser Electronics.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Platter Motor: Replacement of Spark Snubbers
item.description:
A Beogram 4002 (5513) DC platter motor, previously restored in 2016, displayed RPM fluctuations and required attention. Although the motor’s bearings had been treated with oil at that time, the spark snubbers were not replaced. The motor had functioned correctly following the initial restoration.

Initial testing involved installing the motor in a 4002 turntable and monitoring its RPM stability over 24 hours. The results are represented by the blue line in the provided graph. The irregular spikes in the blue line suggested potential issues with one or more spark snubbers.

To address this, the motor was disassembled, and the rotor was examined. The commutator end of the rotor, equipped with the original spark snubbers (blue components), is shown.

The original snubbers were then replaced with modern bidirectional TVS devices.

The TVS units were carefully soldered between the rotor poles.

After reassembly, another 24-hour RPM test was conducted. The results, depicted by the red line in the graph, closely resembled the performance observed in 2016. This confirmed the motor’s successful restoration.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5503): Repair of a Cracked Solenoid Lever
item.description:
A customer asked for help with a broken part, a solenoid lever, from their Beogram 4002 Type 5503 turntable. The AC-powered versions of this model use a mechanical switch to control the solenoid’s current after the arm lowers. To accomplish this, the solenoid arm has a tab that depresses the switch once the arm is down. Some later AC versions use a plastic extension riveted to the lever to achieve this, a design change I observed to be problematic in my experience.

My past Beogram restoration photos show several examples of this plastic lever extension being repaired with epoxy. It seems the attempt to simplify manufacturing with this plastic part had some drawbacks. This lever is crucial because if the switch isn’t activated, the solenoid overheats and could suffer permanent damage.

The part I received was indeed broken at the rivet hole, a common issue. I removed the rivet, then designed and 3D-printed an improved replacement, reinforcing it around the new bolt hole for strength. After installing this redesigned part in one of my Beograms, it functions as intended, both in the ‘arm up’ and ‘arm down’ positions. Only time will tell how durable this updated part will be, but it’s a promising solution to a known flaw.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Platter Motor: Some Microsurgery on Disconnected Pickup Coils
item.description:
I recently obtained a DC platter motor from a Beogram 4002 located in Norway. The motor required repair. The owner had already performed the ‘oil infusion’ procedure for the Oilite bearings. However, after reassembling and reinstalling the motor into the Beogram, the platter’s speed was excessively high and could not be adjusted.

This image displays the motor, without the pulley, in the condition I received it:

Uncontrollably high speed in a DC platter motor usually indicates a problem with one or both of the RPM feedback pickup coils within the motor, assuming the motor control circuit is functioning correctly. This occurs when the coils become disconnected during the removal or reinsertion of the bottom bearing. Verifying this is straightforward: use an Ohm meter to measure the resistance between the red and white leads on the plug. An infinite resistance reading confirms damage to one or both coils.

This is depicted here:

A resistance between 35 and 45 Ohms signifies proper function. This can differ slightly based on the specific motor generation. To proceed, I disassembled the motor and removed the brush carrier, which also houses the two pickup coils.

This image illustrates that:

A close inspection reveals the small, disconnected wires on both sides. This issue necessitates delicate repair work. The process involves carefully unwinding a section of wire under a microscope until a resistance of roughly 15-25 Ohms is achieved between the coil’s two ends. In this instance, it appears previous repair attempts had been made, as the coil windings were cut to a certain depth. Consequently, I dedicated time to unwinding, tinning the end with solder (essential due to the insulating coating on the “magnet wire”), measuring open circuit resistance, continuing to unwind until reaching the cut portion, and then starting again. Eventually, I located the intact end of the wire and successfully measured the correct resistance.

This photo shows the reconnected coil:

And this image shows the removed wiring:

The second coil underwent a similar repair process. Following the successful restoration of both coils, I reattached them to the brush carrier.

Here is the brush carrier after being reinstalled:

This is the final resistance reading between the red and white wires:

With the motor reassembled, I installed it in a Beogram 4002 for testing. I used my BeoloverRPM device to measure the RPM.

This graph shows the results:

The results are optimal for the Beogram DC platter motor. The motor is once again functional.

item.title: Beogram 4002 551x: Exciting!! Replica DC Motor Bearing Prototypes from Beoparts Successfully Tested
item.description:
I received another set of Beogram 4002 platter motor components and an RPM panel from a customer in the Netherlands to restore. My work started with the motor, as it usually does.

I disassembled the motor to get to the bearings.

Typically, I would show a picture of the bearings being oiled in a vacuum chamber, but I received new Oilite bearings from www.beoparts-shop.com specifically for these DC motors, which I am testing. Here is a comparison of the original (top) and new bearings:

I am very excited to install and test these new bearings!

Next, I restored the main PCB. I replaced every electrolytic capacitor, the RPM relay, the RPM trimmers, and the TR3 transistor with a high-gain version. Here is the restored board:

I also swapped out the incandescent bulbs in the RPM panel with LEDs:

Finally, I tested everything on one of my Beogram 4002s. First, I adjusted the TR3 bias with the 5M precision trimmer that replaced the fixed R26 resistor. I temporarily installed it on the solder side to adjust the collector voltage to 4V:

Then, I moved it to the component side:

Next, I checked that the sensor was working correctly using my oscilloscope:

Each dip in the trace represents one of the platter’s black ribs passing by the sensor.

After confirming that the sensor was working, I used a BeoloverRPM device to run a 24-hour RPM stability test on the motor and new bearings:

These are the results of the test:

This is great! These results are some of the best I’ve seen from Beogram DC platter motors, demonstrating that the new bearings from Beoparts perform as well as the restored original bearings. This will significantly simplify the restoration process!

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5501): Return of an Old Friend from Australia - Dead Solenoid Transistor and a Carriage Motor with a Corroded Lead
item.description:
Unfortunately, I recently received a well-used Beolover Beogram shipping container from Australia. Inside was a Beogram 4002 (5501) that I had previously restored in 2016. The 5501 model is unique because it represents a short-lived transitional version produced during B&O’s shift from the Beogram 4000 to the 4002. Although the 5501 features the analog control system of the 4002 series (unlike the 4000’s more sophisticated hard-wired digital logic system, which was sadly simplified in the 4002), it retains the mechanical carriage position switches found in the 4000. It also boasts an intriguing rotary encoder for detecting the end groove. You see, the Beolover has a certain fondness for the 5501, but encountering it for a third time brought a tinge of sadness.

The reason for its return to my workbench was a malfunction. The problem was evident upon plugging it in: the solenoid immediately activated, and the deck became unresponsive to any keypad input except for 33/45 RPM adjustments.

To investigate, I removed the hood and aluminum panels:

A little exploration revealed a short circuit in the TIP41 transistor responsible for driving the solenoid:

Replacing it with a new one restored normal solenoid operation and responsiveness to the arm lowering key. This image displays the newly installed component:

I also replaced the discolored 8.2 Ohm solenoid resistor (4R1),

with a modern 2W rated one:

These images illustrate the voltage measurements across the activated solenoid

and the resistor:

These readings indicate the resistor operates at approximately 1.2W. The original resistors have a 1W rating, slightly insufficient for this application.

Despite these fixes, the deck remained unresponsive to the four keys controlling carriage movement. After examining some transistors in the electronic switch, I realized the carriage motor itself had failed. I removed and opened it, discovering a corroded wire disconnected from its motor tab. The other wire also detached easily with slight movement:

I cleaned the terminals, soldered 22AWG wires to them, and replaced the deteriorated soundproofing with a custom-cut piece of self-adhesive neoprene rubber:

After reinstalling the motor,

all functions were restored. As a preventative measure, given my experience with AC motor type Beograms since 2016, I decided to address the AC motor driver transistors located beneath the main PCB, which are prone to issues. This image shows the original transistors, 0TR2 and 0TR3:

I also discovered a missing hood attachment bolt spring near the transistors, explaining its absence during disassembly. Here’s one of the original transistors, the PNP TIP32 (0TR3, on the right):

I replaced it with a modern BD438, noting the reversed emitter and base leads on these types:

The NPN TIP31 was also replaced with a complementary BD437 (also with reversed wiring). Both new transistors are shown installed here:

I will conduct further testing on this Beogram. If no other issues arise, it will journey back across the ocean to Australia!

item.title: Bay Area Beogram 8002: Cabinet Work Completion to First Record Play
item.description:
I finally set up the Beogram 8002 turntable in a listening room to test its functionality.

While reassembly took a bit longer than expected due to a slight detour to repair chipped rosewood trim on the front panel.

Although fixing the trim wasn’t part of the initial restoration plan, I decided against leaving the front panel chipped.

Repairs involving glue, like this one, often take longer than expected due to the curing time.

Multiple repair attempts also contributed to the delay.

My first attempt involved patching the two chipped areas, one large and one small.

The larger chip was patched with a piece of rosewood veneer, achieving a good fit and pattern match.

After gluing and trimming the patch, I sanded and applied boiled linseed oil as a finish.

However, the smaller patch became too dark, and the remaining chip was too small for a successful repair, even with wood filler.

While an improvement over the chips, the result wasn’t satisfactory.

The larger patch, though well-fitted, darkened considerably, and the remaining chip remained noticeable.

For the second attempt, I removed the previous repair and opted for a single rectangular patch to cover both original chips.

Using a lighter shade of rosewood veneer resulted in a better outcome, although not perfect.

The patch darkened slightly, but the overall result was an improvement over the original chips.

I explored using rosewood trim from a spare Beogram 800x cabinet and other spare cabinets but found them to be darker than the project’s trim. Therefore, the veneer remained the best match.

Next, I focused on the tonearm compartment, installing a clean replacement hinge piece for the lid.

Kilopoise grease was applied for damping, and the hinge was temporarily held with the original hinge bar.

With that, the Beogram 8002 cabinet was ready for component reassembly.

The initial step involved reinstalling the main turntable components, including the circuit board, transformer, control panel, and floating chassis.

I prefer this order because it allows me to close the cabinet halves, providing stability when handling the dust cover and tonearm compartment lid.

I didn’t photograph the reinstallation process this time. However, you can refer to this link for a detailed guide from a previous Beogram 8002 project.

Here’s the Beogram 8002 with its internal components reinstalled, prepped for the dust cover and tonearm compartment lid.

For the dust cover, I secured the dust cover and tonearm compartment hinge assembly using the Beogram 8002 bar hinge.

Removing the bar hinge earlier eliminated the need to remove the cabinet’s backplate, which often results in a loose fit due to fragile plastic clips.

After securing the dust cover and tonearm compartment, I attached the dust cover damping spring assembly.

The dust cover was then installed and adjusted to lower slowly using the damping spring.

The dust cover’s rubber bumper pads, located on the front part of the lid, were deteriorated.

After cleaning the residue, I installed 3D-printed replacements.

With the dust cover in place, I used it as a guide to install the tonearm compartment lid using 3M VHB double-sided tape, similar to the Beogram 8002 metal deck.

The Beogram 8002 was now assembled and ready for record play testing in my office.

To celebrate, I chose to listen to Quincy Jones’ “Walking In Space” and Lonnie Liston Smith’s “Live!” jazz records.

These listening tests tend to last a while.

item.title: Bay Area Beogram 8002: Some cabinet work
item.description:
The Beogram 8002’s internal components are ready to be placed back into the cabinet, but the cabinet needs some attention first.

While this Beogram’s cabinet is in good condition overall, there are a few things that need to be fixed, as mentioned in the initial assessment (linked in the original text).

The first step was to remove the aluminum deck lid. The previous re-attachment used overly thick double-sided tape that created too much space. The tape resembled the kind used for insulating windows and doors.

To remove the residue from the old tape and glue, I applied Goo-Gone to all affected surfaces and let it sit overnight.

Upon removing the metal deck, I noticed the small metal spring was missing. It likely got lost during the previous attempt to reattach the deck. I will have to use a spare spring. This spring is important for preventing static buildup on the metal deck.

The images in the original post show the parts after cleaning off the old tape and glue, followed by the dimensions of the missing spring.

Next, the images show the new 3M RP32F VHB tape applied to the deck, along with the replacement spring. This type of double-sided tape is well-suited for the Beogram 800x deck because it’s strong, easy to work with, and 0.81mm thick. This ensures a secure attachment and a nearly seamless connection.

The following pictures display the reinstalled metal deck. The last photo in the sequence reveals a small nick in the cabinet’s front rosewood trim. I will try to minimize its appearance using a sliver of rosewood veneer I keep for such restorations.

Another cabinet piece that needed attention was the metal deck lid inside the tonearm compartment. It also had double-sided tape that needed replacing, for which I used 1mm thick VHB tape.

The post then shows the tonearm compartment deck lid back in place for a test fit.

Moving on, there’s a small metal bracket on the dust cover where the damper spring assembly attaches. This bracket helps to gently lower the dust cover.

Originally, this bracket was attached using the same double-sided tape found on the metal deck, which deteriorates over time. I cleaned off the old residue and reattached it using epoxy. To ensure proper alignment during the gluing process, I used the Beogram’s bar hinge. I placed some weight on the bracket for proper epoxy setting and will let it cure for 24 hours.

The next issue involved the tonearm compartment’s top lid. The Beogram arrived with a broken hinge lever on this lid, with evidence of a previous, unsuccessful repair attempt. The glue residue from this attempt is visible and could interfere with the bar hinge.

Fortunately, I have a potential replacement lid with an intact hinge lever.

This hinge lever fits into a slot on the cabinet, which has a corresponding lever to control the lid’s opening and closing. The cavity where these levers connect should be filled with Kilopoise damping grease. As most of it is gone in this Beogram, I will refill the compartment with fresh Kilopoise grease.

With the dust cover damping spring bracket’s epoxy set to fully cure tomorrow, I can begin reassembling the turntable parts within the cabinet.

item.title: Bay Area Beogram 8002: Oscilloscope Measurements
item.description:
This document summarizes the functional testing performed on a Beogram 8002 turntable, using oscilloscope captures of critical signals as a reference for comparison with other Beogram 8002 turntables.

The testing involved connecting test leads to six key points on the Beogram 8002’s main board: Position Sensor 1, Position Sensor 2, Detector Arm, Speed Sensor, Servo Motor Forward, and Servo Motor Reverse. Due to the oscilloscope’s four-channel limitation, the initial focus was on the servo motor and position sensors.

The oscilloscope images illustrate the signal behavior during various turntable operations. Images were captured for Standby mode, Play button press (showing the tangential arm assembly movement and the delayed position sensor cycling), record detection and tonearm setdown, tonearm movement through the lead-in groove, record play (demonstrating position sensor and servo voltage activity), end-of-record detection and tonearm return, Stop button press during playback, fast forward to the maximum position and subsequent return to Standby, and the tangential arm assembly’s return to the Standby position with SO switch engagement.

Additional images showcase the platter speed sensor and arm detector sensor signals. One image depicts the turntable scanning an empty platter, highlighting the position sensor activity indicating arm movement, the speed sensor confirming platter rotation, and the arm detector sensor indicating the absence of a record.

Further testing involved incorporating the Tracking Sensor signal, which measures the tonearm’s deviation from the tangential path. The captured images demonstrate the Tracking Sensor signal’s influence on the forward motor drive during playback initiation, typical record play over time, and the end-of-record run-out groove event.

The functional testing concluded with these observations, paving the way for cabinet restoration and final assembly for listening tests.

item.title: Bay Area Beogram 8002: Checking the Forward/Reverse Scanning LDR Devices
item.description:
My previous work on this Beogram left me concerned about a potential issue with one of the forward/reverse scanning LDRs (Light Dependent Resistors).

Testing the resistance of both LDRs with +15 VDC on the light source, I noticed a significant difference between them, leading me to believe one was faulty. However, upon removing and re-testing them, the resistance values were much closer.

It’s important to note that my testing method involved a simple setup with an LED work light as a light source. This allowed for a relative comparison between the two LDRs.

While the measurements weren’t identical, the discrepancy wasn’t as large as initially thought. Despite this, I decided to replace both LDRs and the light source to ensure optimal performance, especially considering the shipping costs involved.

With the new components in place (a new LED lamp with a 1KΩ resistor and two new LDRs), I repeated the adjustment process. This time, both LDRs had ample room for adjustment and successfully reached the desired neutral voltage level.

Unfortunately, a new problem arose: the forward scan button’s activation mechanism felt sluggish and didn’t return to its original position promptly. To investigate, I disassembled the button panel and compared it to those from other Beogram 8000 and 8002 units.

The scanning buttons on the Beogram share a single spring mechanism similar to a seesaw. Pressing one button depresses its side of the spring while the other side attempts to rise, but is stopped by the button panel. Ideally, each button should operate independently within this mechanism, with the spring returning to neutral upon release.

My observations revealed that the spring’s portion with the aperture, responsible for controlling light to the LDR, wasn’t fully returning to its neutral position. This explained why the light source control screw for the reverse scanning LDR needed significant adjustment.

In a well-functioning setup, the LDR should have full light exposure in the neutral position, with the control screw set to achieve a voltage between 620mV and 700mV. Pressing a scanning button partially covers the LDR with the spring’s aperture, increasing resistance and voltage. Fully depressing the button completely blocks the light, resulting in maximum voltage across the LDR and initiating the fast scan function.

Further examination showed that the spring mechanism sits loosely on a central pivot point, allowing it to teeter-totter freely. This surface mates with the underside of the button panel.

To address the spring’s sluggishness, I carefully removed and adjusted it. Through several bending adjustments at both the pivot point and ends, I achieved a significant improvement in the scanning button action.

With these adjustments, both LDRs now reach their neutral values smoothly and, importantly, return to those positions after use.

All Beogram 8002 functions are operating as intended, and the scanning buttons feel much better. I’ll continue monitoring their performance during listening tests.

item.title: Bay Area Beogram 8002: Service Manual Adjustments and Record Play Test
item.description:
To complete the remaining service manual adjustments, the platter motor connector needs to be disconnected for both the tracking force and tracking sensor adjustments.

To adjust the tracking force, an MMC phono cartridge is required, and it’s recommended to set the sliding tracking force knob to 1 gram.

With the platter motor disconnected, the tonearm can be placed over the stationary platter. A tracking force scale is used to measure the cartridge’s tracking force, aiming for a reading of 1 gram. If the measurement differs from the slider setting, the tonearm counterweight needs adjustment.

The tonearm counterweight, located on the back of the tonearm assembly, is adjusted by loosening its screw and sliding it forward or backward to increase or decrease the tracking force.

Achieving the correct 1-gram measurement may require a few adjustments.

After securing the counterweight, the next step, with the platter motor still disconnected, is to adjust the record tracking sensor.

When in Play mode and the tangential arm assembly is moved towards the platter, the tracking sensor lamp should glow.

The sensor’s adjustment screw is located on the side of its housing. To adjust it, place the tonearm with a cartridge on a record. While a specific Bang & Olufsen test record is recommended, any vintage record can be used. Manually rotate the platter and adjust the screw until the servo motor starts advancing the spindle within 2 ± 1 revolutions, and then continues advancing with each revolution.

Finally, the forward and reverse scanning LDR devices require adjustment.

The service manual recommends a 620mVDC reading on each LDR after five minutes of operation, but a setting of 650mVDC is preferable.

In this Beogram 8002, the two LDRs were reading slightly over 700mVDC. While this is still functional, adjustments were made to bring them closer to 650mVDC.

After adjustments, all functions, including the Pause, were tested and worked as expected.

However, the scanning LDR devices posed a concern. While adjustable to the desired values, the two LDRs have significantly different settings.

As shown in the photo, one LDR’s adjustment screw is much higher than the other.

Although not expected to be identical, the LDR settings should be closer. The higher screw appeared to be at its limit.

Further inspection confirmed that one of the LDR adjustment screws had reached its limit, leaving no room for future adjustments as the sensor lamp ages.

This situation is not ideal, as it restricts future adjustments. While the lamp appears to function correctly, the large discrepancy in LDR settings requires attention.

The scanning sensors operate by using the lamp to illuminate each LDR through separate metal apertures controlled by the scanning buttons. Pressing a button closes the aperture, changing the LDR’s resistance, and directing more voltage to the corresponding side of the servo motor, moving the arm.

When neither button is pressed, the LDRs are in a neutral state, ideally within the 620mVDC to 700mVDC range. The two large black screws regulate the amount of light reaching the LDRs in this neutral state.

To test the LDRs’ response, both adjustment screws were opened fully to maximize light exposure.

With +15 VDC applied to the lamp and the scanning buttons in neutral, the resistance on each LDR was measured. The readings were around 16kΩ and 43kΩ, indicating a significant difference.

While some variation is expected, this discrepancy is too large. The LDR measuring 43kΩ is the one requiring adjustment to its limit during the previous procedure.

The next step is to find a matching pair of LDR devices with closer readings.

Additionally, it’s advisable to replace the sensor lamp while replacing the LDR, ensuring optimal performance.

item.title: Bay Area Beogram 8002: Trying Out the Restored Components
item.description:
Following the capacitor replacement from the last update, a test connector was added to make it easier to work with the scanning LDRs. The button control panel was removed from its circuit board, revealing a typical amount of dust accumulation, which was easily wiped away. The test connector was soldered on, and the button panel was reassembled.

Another task involved cleaning and lubricating the tangential arm assembly. The drive spindle and nut were in good condition.

The spindle and nut were cleaned, and the rubber ends of the rear shaft (found on 60 Hz models) were treated with a rubber protectant to prevent drying.

To ensure the fixed arm and tonearm were horizontally parallel, the arm assembly was installed without the spindle and nut. This allowed for manual movement and adjustment.

The fixed arm was initially positioned too high and had to be lowered. It was adjusted to the correct height of 19.5mm from the platter surface.

With the fixed arm adjusted, the tonearm required a slight upward adjustment to achieve parallelism. The adjustment screw’s location on the underside of the assembly made it necessary to flip the assembly over.

After adjusting the arm height and parallelism, lubrication was applied to the tangential arm components during reinstallation. A Rocol MTS 2000 and ESSO NUTO HP32 mixture (1:1) was used on the spindle. A thin layer of white D.C. M-kote paste was applied to the front and rear shafts. Tri-Flow synthetic grease was used on the spindle’s mounting points on the floating chassis. Additionally, a new servo belt, reproduced by Martin Olsen, replaced the old one, which was showing cracks.

With the floating chassis components ready, they were connected to the Beogram 8002’s electrical components for a functional test.

The initial test was positive, with the Standby indicator lit. Pressing Play initiated the expected movement of the tangential arm assembly over the platter. The platter speed switched from 33 RPM to 45 RPM at the 17 cm mark, indicating correct functionality.

The platter speed adjusted accurately, and the Turn, Stop, and speed selection buttons worked as intended. The forward and reverse scanning buttons functioned, but further adjustments will be made according to the service manual.

Next steps include service manual adjustments, finalizing functional testing, and examining sensor signals using an oscilloscope.

item.title: Bay Area Beogram 8002: Capacitor Replacement
item.description:
In this Beogram 8002 turntable restoration, I began by replacing the capacitors and the phono muting relay.

I started with the two electrolytic capacitors on the floating chassis, which are part of the +5 VDC power supply regulation. I replaced them with WIMA MKS capacitors (for values 4.7uF and under) and high-quality Japanese 105°C electrolytic capacitors (for values over 4.7uF).

The old muting relay was replaced with a fully sealed Omron relay.

Next, I replaced the 4C1 capacitor in the transformer box. This bipolar capacitor is used in the tangential drive platter motor circuit. As the original 4C1 capacitor is large, the modern, smaller replacement was mounted on a 3D printed plate.

Moving on to the circuit boards, I began with the microcomputer board (PCB2). I replaced the single electrolytic capacitor, 2C28, which filters the +5 VDC to the microcomputer IC. To make this easier, I cut the leads of 2C28 before desoldering it. I also took this opportunity to replace the microcomputer IC’s 40-pin socket with a more robust tulip-style pin socket.

Remember that the negative lead of 2C28 needs to be soldered on both sides of the board.

After reinstalling the microcomputer IC, being sure to take necessary precautions against static electricity, I focused on replacing the capacitors on the main board (PCB1).

An important point to note is that I reflowed the solder points for all board connector pins on both PCB1 and PCB2 to prevent potential connection issues.

Although the main electrical work is complete, I still need to add a test connector to the button control panel for easier adjustment of the scanning LDR devices. After that, I will clean the floating chassis, lubricate and adjust the tangential arm assembly, and replace the servo motor belt.

item.title: Bay Area Beogram 8002: Initial Assessment
item.description:
This Beogram 8002 turntable, sent from California, is the next restoration project. I prefer working on the same type of audio equipment consecutively because it minimizes workbench setup time.

The owner followed our packing advice and packaged the turntable very well, using double boxes and protective foam. The turntable arrived without damage.

Upon opening, I noticed the metal tonearm lid wouldn’t stay up. The part that connects to the hinge with damping grease was detached, a problem I haven’t encountered before. The lid’s attachment to the hinge plate also appeared to be the original, surprisingly intact double-sided tape.

An initial electrical check showed the Beogram powered on and the platter turned when prompted. However, the tonearm wouldn’t move forward or backward during playback, and the Stop button didn’t return the arm. These are common issues I’ll address during restoration. I managed to return the arm to its resting position by tricking the sensor with a platter.

The tonearm compartment’s deck lid had deteriorated double-sided tape that will need replacing. The dustcover’s opening mechanism functioned correctly, but the back panel hinge assembly, although secure, raised concerns about potential damage during disassembly. To avoid this, I removed the dustcover and tonearm compartment lid by detaching the hinge bar. Interestingly, glue residue suggests prior repairs in this area.

I removed the transformer assembly and found a spider, a common occurrence in Bang & Olufsens! I proceeded to disassemble the Beogram into its service position for a complete assessment.

The internal components looked good, mostly original with only one capacitor appearing replaced. The usual areas, like the microcomputer box’s thermal grease, will be refreshed during restoration. The transformer compartment was fine, but the platter motor drive capacitor will be replaced, as will the two capacitors on the floating chassis.

I plan to check the scanning sensors and install a test connector for adjustments. The phono output board appeared fine, but I’ll replace the muting relay. The servo motor pulley was cracked and needs replacing. The tonearm wasn’t horizontally aligned – a problem for the service manual adjustments.

The subplatter (rotor) was unexpectedly glued to the hub with epoxy and required careful separation. I’ll use a removable adhesive when reassembling. The aluminum deck around the platter, while secure, was attached with a makeshift foam tape. I plan to replace it with VHB tape for a cleaner look.

Overall, this Beogram 8002 is in good condition. The electronic issues are typical and should be resolved by replacing capacitors, reflowing solder joints, and performing standard adjustments.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Complete Restoration and Test Drive with Cal Tjader and Claus Ogerman
item.description:
I recently began restoring a Beogram 4002 (Type 5513) turntable for an Australian customer who purchased it on eBay. The turntable arrived in poor condition.

My initial evaluation is documented here.

This post details the unit’s restoration, excluding the dust cover, which will be covered separately.

I began with the DC platter motor, as is customary, since the bearing lubrication process requires a few days. Here’s the motor after removal:

Disassembling the motor allowed me to access the bearings:

The small, donut-shaped components on the black pad in the front are the bearings. I submerged these in motor oil and created a vacuum. The immediate appearance of bubbles indicated that air was being drawn out of the porous Oilite bearing material:

Fresh oil can enter the bearing thanks to the air being expelled. I concentrated on other parts of the turntable while this procedure was running. The arm lowering mechanism was the first thing I fixed. Hardened lubricants frequently cause it to become clogged. It is shown installed in this image:

I disassembled the moving components

and cleaned and re-lubricated them:

After reinstalling the mechanism, I removed the sensor arm assembly. Here’s a view of it from the back:

To re-lubricate the pivot point, I detached the damper-to-arm linkage:

I discovered that the double-sided tape securing the arm lowering limit “skid plate” had deteriorated while I was working on the assembly:

After removing the old tape and reinstalling the arm assembly, I used epoxy to reattach it to the arm base:

I replaced the tracking sensor’s incandescent bulb with an LED-based solution while I was working on the carriage. The original lamp housing is depicted here in place:

The aperture in charge of the tracking feedback is visible in this image after the aperture has been removed:

The LED-based Beolover substitute and the original bulb are shown here:

I secured the replacement in place and soldered the wires to the carriage’s PCB:

Replacing the fragile carriage pulley was the last step in repairing the carriage mechanism.

with a precisely machined aluminum component and a new belt:

Rebuilding the electronics was the next step. The main board is shown in its initial state in this image:

All of the electrolytic capacitors, the platter sensor transistor, the RPM trimmers, and the RPM relay were replaced with modern equivalents:

The RPM area is shown in this image with the new, sealed relay and 25-turn trimmers for precise and dependable RPM adjustment:

After that, I concentrated on the output board:

I changed the output grounding relay and the capacitor that determines its time constant on this board (to delay the relay action until the needle touches the grooves). Additionally, in case of a hum problem, I added a switch that allows for the connection of system and signal grounds (the red switch in front of the black cable jack):

The main reservoir capacitor that regulates the power rail is another crucial component to replace. It frequently deviates from specifications and/or leaks:

I installed my two single capacitor replacement assembly because this 4002 included a double capacitance unit to enable a potential future 4-channel CD-4 upgrade. These dual caps are no longer offered. The smaller 1000uF unit is intended for the CD-4 board if it is ever installed, while the larger capacitor (4700uF) is for the main PCB. I typically put a 20k bleeder resistor between the CD-4 power rail and GND to ensure that the 1000uF capacitor discharges correctly after the deck is unplugged:

I changed the remaining incandescent lights after finishing the boards. The sensor arm bulb was the first to be replaced with a flex-PCB-based drop-in substitute that featured a warm-white LED and a bypass resistor to boost the current to the level of a light bulb. This is required to guarantee that the record detection circuitry identifies the LED as a “valid light bulb” and permits arm descent. This safety element guards against the arm unintentionally dropping if the bulb burns out. The initial bulb and the replacement assembly are shown in this image:

And with the bulb out:

and after installation:

[](https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEg9POU2cNdTIFSbjtZHsAuweR42ZMa986hx

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): A New Arrival from Seattle en Route to Australia
item.description:
An Australian customer purchased a Beogram 4002 on eBay from the US and sent it to me for restoration. Upon its arrival, I discovered it was in poor condition, likely due to storage in a basement or attic. The dust cover was particularly damaged, with scratches on the aluminum trim and the surface itself.

Despite the dust cover’s condition, the internal components appeared undamaged, including the hinges, suggesting a successful restoration is possible. The aluminum trim can be replaced with a replica.

Unfortunately, the cartridge was left on the tonearm and suffered damage, requiring either a rebuild or replacement. On a positive note, the aluminum surfaces beneath the dust cover were in good condition, although the keypad showed significant wear.

The plinth was in relatively good condition, with only one minor chip on a corner. I was pleased to find the internal components untouched, indicating a lack of prior repair attempts.

One of the springs on the floating chassis was rusty, suggesting exposure to humidity. Initial testing yielded positive results: the platter motor spun despite requiring lubrication, and the carriage moved correctly to the LP setdown point. This suggests the functional restoration of this Beogram 4002 should be straightforward.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Motor Restoration: A New Tool on the Bench and the Importance of the Orientation of the Top Bearing
item.description:
A Beogram 4002 DC platter motor was acquired for restoration. Evidence suggested prior repair attempts on the motor, including scratches on the bearing assembly and damaged brushes.

Upon disassembly, it was clear the bearings hadn’t been properly oiled. A vacuum oil infusion process was conducted on both the top and bottom bearings. After cleaning and reassembly, a short circuit was detected, pointing to faulty spark snubbers.

The old spark snubbers were replaced with modern TVS devices. However, RPM stability testing revealed spikes in the motor’s speed. Past experience suggested that maintaining the original rotational orientation of the top bearing could resolve this. A hypothesis was formed that uneven wear on the bearing over time might be causing inconsistent friction.

To address the unknown bearing orientation, a “burn-in tool” was designed to accelerate the wear-in process. This tool applied increased rotational force to the motor, simulating prolonged use. After a period of burn-in, the motor’s RPM stability significantly improved, indicating the effectiveness of this method. The motor was deemed ready for use.

item.title: A Pair of Beomaster 1900 Receivers for Restoration: Unit #2 Wrap Up
item.description:
The second Beomaster 1900 restoration project is finished.

After a night of playing music, the Beomaster 1900 was ready for the cabinet to be put back together.

The Bass, Treble, and Balance indicator masks were reattached to their slide controls.

The touch control panel was then placed onto the cabinet frame, carefully aligning the button actuators with the sensor posts.

All touch buttons were tested to ensure functionality before continuing the reassembly.

The tone control and FM tuning panel followed, with fresh Nyogel damping grease applied to the lid damper before securing the panel.

The deteriorated rubber stops for the control panel lid were replaced with a 3D-printed bumper pad.

Four new cabinet feet, ordered from Martin’s Beoparts store, were installed on the base plate.

Lastly, the polished smoked plexiglass was slid back into place over the touch panel indicator lamps.

The Beomaster 1900 is now ready for testing in a listening room.

item.title: A Pair of Beomaster 1900 Receivers for Restoration: Unit #2 Performance Testing and a Volume Control LDR Problem
item.description:
Today, I completed some service manual adjustments on the Beomaster 1900 and started evaluating its performance by measuring THD and Frequency Response.

The first adjustments involved setting the tuning voltage for FM 1 and FM 5 according to the Beomaster 1900 service manual. The procedure involves setting the FM 1 tuning potentiometer (4R3) to the 88MHz dial position and adjusting trimmer 4R2 to achieve a reading of 4.5 VDC at test point 4TP1 with FM 1 selected as the audio source.

Similarly, the FM 5 tuning potentiometer (4R7) is set to 88MHz. Then, trimmer 4R8 is adjusted to obtain a reading of 4.6 VDC at test point 4TP1 with FM 5 chosen as the audio source.

Images of these measurement and adjustment points are provided below.

The final service manual adjustment involved setting the output level using trimmer 2R136. This required feeding a 200mVrms, 1KHz sine wave signal into the Beomaster 1900’s Tape input. With the volume preset at the midpoint and the Beomaster 1900 turned on via the Tape source button, the output at the speaker terminals should measure 100mV. Trimmer 2R136 is adjusted to reach this level.

I set up the test using a QuantAsylum QA401 Audio Analyzer to generate the 200mVrms, 1KHz test signal. After verifying the signal with an oscilloscope, I applied it to the Beomaster 1900 tape inputs. I set the volume preset to the middle position and selected the Tape source to power on the Beomaster 1900. Finally, I measured the voltage at the speaker outputs.

The test setup and measurement results are shown below.

There was a 20mVrms output discrepancy between the left and right channels, which, while not ideal, was acceptable.

The balance control was confirmed to be centered, and the no-load current adjustments were nearly identical. I suspected the issue stemmed from the Beomaster 1900’s volume control LDR (Light Dependent Resistor).

This LDR is controlled by the varying intensity of a lamp. The lamp’s light level alters the resistance of the photoresistors, thereby controlling the Beomaster 1900’s volume.

To delve further, I measured the Beomaster 1900’s THD at 30 Watts using 8-ohm dummy speaker loads.

Although the THD values were good, the left channel was outputting approximately 20 Watts, while the right channel was outputting around 30 Watts.

This discrepancy indicated a need to examine the volume control LDR.

Photos of the LDR are shown below.

The disassembled volume control LDR is depicted below. A centrally located lamp illuminates four LDRs.

With no light, the LDRs have maximum resistance, corresponding to full volume from the Beomaster 1900 amplifier. As the lamp brightens, the LDR resistance decreases, attenuating the audio signal.

The photo reveals four LDRs surrounding the lamp within the volume control unit.

The left channel utilizes two LDRs, and the right channel employs the remaining two. One set (left and right) manages voltage levels within the tone control circuit, while the other (left and right) handles voltage levels in the output amplifier.

To test the LDR, I connected its lamp terminals to a DC power supply set to 5 VDC. Subsequently, I measured the resistance of all four resistors to ascertain their value consistency.

My findings indicated that the four LDRs within this Beomaster 1900 unit’s volume control did not exhibit uniform resistance values at the test voltage.

I proceeded to measure numerous LDRs using this setup and selected four that displayed the closest resistance values to one another.

After installing these LDRs into the volume control housing and reinstalling the assembly back into the Beomaster 1900, I repeated the Tape input level adjustment.

The difference between the left and right channels was reduced to approximately 7mVrms, a significant improvement from the prior 20mVrms discrepancy.

Next, I examined the left and right channel outputs at maximum power.

The Beomaster 1900 specifications state a maximum amplifier output of 2 x 20 W/8 ohms and a total harmonic distortion of less than 0.2%. The touch-sensitive volume control’s nature made it challenging to achieve a precise volume setting for this test. Ultimately, I took measurements at output levels of 15W, 28W, and 32W.

All three measurements fell well below the 0.2% THD target.

The THD measurement at 28 Watts across the 8.1 Ohm dummy speaker loads is shown below.

These distortion percentages were excellent, especially at an output exceeding the specifications. Notably, the left and right channel output levels were now much closer after addressing the volume control LDR. These results were satisfactory.

Lastly, I conducted a frequency response test. I set the output to 26W across the 8.1-ohm dummy speaker loads.

The QA401 Audio Analyzer measurements are depicted below.

These findings align with my observations of the Beomaster 1900 and 2400 amplifiers. The frequency response remained within ±1.5dBV from 20Hz to 20KHz. Notably, this Beomaster 1900 achieved ±1dBV across the entire frequency spectrum, surpassing its anticipated maximum output.

The next steps involve reassembling the Beomaster’s cabinet and conducting listening tests.

Concurrently, I will commence the restoration of a couple of Beogram turntables and replace the belts on a Beogram CD50.

item.title: A Pair of Beomaster 1900 Receivers for Restoration: Unit #2 Reassembly and Power Supply Checks
item.description:
This Beomaster 1900 is almost ready for final testing after reassembly and initial power supply checks.

The power transistor heatsinks, crucial for cooling, have been reinstalled using Sil-Pad insulators for thermal protection. This process started with the power transistors in their original state before any capacitor replacements. After restoration and the addition of new thermal insulation, they were carefully mounted back onto the unit.

To prepare for the upcoming No-Load Current adjustments, test leads were soldered onto the board. This step was performed while the Beomaster 1900 was still inverted for easier access.

Next, the indicator lamp boards were reassembled. This involved installing a combination of dual LED assemblies for the Bass, Treble, and Balance indicators, while using traditional incandescent lamps for the remaining indicators. As a preventative measure, the touch button posts were cleaned and treated with Deoxit to ensure optimal conductivity.

Reconnecting the power transformer secondary wires, which were intentionally disconnected during capacitor replacement, was the next task. This allowed for the application of power, confirmed by the glowing standby lamp indicating a healthy +15VDC power supply.

Following the service manual’s instructions, the +15VDC supply voltage was tested and adjusted. The initial voltage from the transformer secondary measured over 22VDC, which was then carefully regulated down to the target +15.0VDC. A quick verification confirmed the presence of the +-31VDC rail voltages, indicating the power supplies were functioning correctly.

Finally, the initial No-Load Current adjustment was performed. With the speakers disconnected and volume set to zero, the no-load current for the output amplifier emitter resistors was meticulously adjusted until the DC voltage across them reached the desired 12mVDC.

This marks significant progress in the Beomaster 1900’s restoration. The next steps involve completing the remaining service manual checks and performing a series of performance tests to ensure optimal functionality.

item.title: A Pair of Beomaster 1900 Receivers for Restoration: Capacitor Replacement and Slider Controls on Unit #2
item.description:
The second Beomaster 1900 unit is prepped for reassembly after completing the capacitor replacements and slider control repairs.

The Volume Control board was addressed first, requiring six capacitor replacements. Here’s the board before:

And after the replacements:

The Tone Control and FM Tuning board came next. While it only needed ten capacitors replaced, the Bass, Treble, and Balance sliders needed attention. This involved cleaning and repairing the Bass and Treble controls, which had broken slider bridges impacting the switch contacts. A Beoparts repair kit was used for the sliders.

The Tone Control board before capacitor replacement is shown below:

Given the 74 capacitors and additional components needing replacement, a de-soldering gun was essential:

With the replacements complete, the board now looks like this:

Like the first Beomaster 1900, the Balance slide control was in good condition and only needed cleaning. However, the Bass and Treble controls showed the typical broken tabs on the slider bridges. The following photos depict the Bass control’s removal and repair:

The Treble and Balance controls are shown in the next image:

The following image shows the fully repaired slider controls and some of the key tools used:

With these steps finished, the Beomaster 1900 is ready for reassembly and subsequent power supply testing.

item.title: A Pair of Beomaster 1900 Receivers for Restoration: Capacitor Replacement on Unit #2
item.description:
The first Beomaster 1900 receiver is fully operational and undergoing testing in a listening room. However, the second unit still requires restoration.

Initial assessment of the second Beomaster 1900 has already been completed, and now it’s time to begin replacing capacitors on the main circuit board.

The main circuit board houses most of the capacitors that need replacing. Unfortunately, it cannot be removed for servicing and must remain connected to the wire harness.

Replacing capacitors on this board requires flipping the Beomaster over repeatedly to desolder old components and solder new ones. While experienced restorers might remove multiple capacitors at once, a safer approach is to replace them one by one, carefully checking polarity and value.

To prevent damage from repeated movement, I desolder the transformer’s secondary power wires from the board before starting the recapping process.

Several screws secure the main board to the chassis and heatsink assemblies. Since the plan involves replacing the thermal material on the output transistors, I remove the heatsinks to clean off the old paste.

With that done, the main board is ready for servicing. I use a simple foam block jig to support and protect the board during this process.

Next, I replace the +15 VDC power supply filter capacitor and apply new thermal paste, using a Sil-Pad for the chassis-mounted transistor.

For the ±31 VDC power supply filter capacitors, I rearrange and reattach terminals with heat shrink for a secure connection.

The rest of the capacitor replacements on the main board are straightforward, although time-consuming.

With the main board completed, only the Volume PCB and the Tone, Filter, and Tuning PCB remain to be recapped.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Complete Restoration and a Test Spin with Oscar Peterson
item.description:
I recently obtained a Beogram 4000 turntable from Sweden in very corroded condition. To address the extensive corrosion, I chose to use another 4000 unit as a donor for parts. The donor unit, while missing some components, was free of corrosion.

My restoration process started with the carriage. I disassembled and cleaned the arm lowering system, damper, carriage rods, and spindle in an ultrasonic bath. Additionally, the sensor arm assembly was removed to lubricate the damper-to-arm linkage pivot point. A loose skid plate under the arm’s upper limit adjustment screw was reattached with epoxy after removing the old tape. The tracking sensor light source was replaced with an LED version, and I replaced the aperture’s sheet metal screw with a more durable stainless steel one.

With the carriage disassembled, I took the opportunity to restore the corroded solenoid-actuated switch contacts. After removing the switches, I electroplated the oxidized terminals with nickel and then 24-carat gold. The same process was used on the corroded terminals of the carriage position switches. While accessible, I also replaced the solenoid transistor.

After reassembly, I turned my attention to the main capacitor and AC motor. The capacitors were removed, and the motor was disassembled for bearing lubrication. New capacitors were installed using a 3D-printed fixture.

The main PCB was then rebuilt, which involved replacing all electrolytic capacitors, the RPM relay, RPM trimmers, solenoid transistors, and sensor arm transistor and bias resistor.

Next, the keypad cluster was restored by disassembling and electroplating the oxidized switch terminals. I also replaced the original light bulbs with LEDs and reattached the strobe mirror using epoxy.

For the sensor arm, the bulb was swapped with an LED circuit designed to match the original bulb’s current draw to avoid triggering the turntable’s burnt bulb protection. The tonearm, transferred from the corroded unit, had its cartridge adapter replaced with a 3D-printed replica. I also added a switch to the output terminal to allow signal and system ground connection if needed.

The plinth from the original unit required repair. I removed the misaligned metal brackets and reattached them correctly after baking the plinth to soften the adhesive. New guidance washers were also installed.

Finally, I calibrated and tested the turntable: motor voltage, sensor signal, RPM stability, sub-chassis alignment, platter height, tracking weight, arm lowering limit, and tracking feedback were all adjusted.

After a final cleaning and polish, the Beogram 4000 was tested with a vintage record and performed excellently. It will undergo a period of further testing before returning to Sweden.

item.title: A Pair of Beomaster 1900 Receivers for Restoration: Finishing up Unit #1
item.description:
The restoration of the first Beomaster 1900 receiver is finished.

The final testing involved measuring the Total Harmonic Distortion (THD) and Frequency Response. Using a dummy 8Ω speaker load, the THD was measured at 1KHz with a 20-watt output. An image of the test setup with the dummy speaker load is provided below.

At the maximum rated power of 20 watts across the dummy speaker load, the THD measured 0.068% using a 1kHz sine wave input to the Beomaster 1900’s Tape input. This is significantly lower than the service manual’s specified maximum THD level of 0.2%.

The frequency response was then assessed from 20Hz to 20kHz with a 260mV input to the Tape input and a power level of 20 watts.

The outcome showed a ±1 dB variance across the 20Hz to 20kHz frequency range. This result aligns closely with previous measurements taken on a restored Beomaster 2400 receiver.

These measurements are highly satisfactory for an amplifier from this Bang & Olufsen series.

The Beomaster will now be placed in a listening room while the second Beomaster 1900 unit undergoes restoration.

A few final pictures from the workbench are included below. This Beomaster 1900 receiver should not require further workbench time for another five decades.

item.title: A Pair of Beomaster 1900 Receivers for Restoration: Unit #1 Reassembly for Testing
item.description:
Following a slight weather-induced pause, it’s time to resume the Beomaster 1900 restoration.

The Beomaster has been functioning well in the workshop for over a week. It’s now safe to reassemble the casing and begin performance testing.

Before I can replace the touch button control and the tone/FM tuning panels, the three display masks for Bass, Treble, and Balance need to be reconnected.

Reinstalling the touch button control panel requires precision. Each touch button post on the main PCB corresponds to a copper activator with a notch that must be aligned. Occasionally, aligning these notches is challenging.

However, this time the alignment was effortless, with the notches fitting perfectly onto the posts without the need for any tools.

This image highlights two of the copper activators.

When reinstalling the tone control and FM tuning panel, it’s essential to ensure the slider control buttons align with their corresponding sliders. To facilitate this, I position all three slider controls at their lowest point before attaching the panel.

I also apply a small amount of Nyogel damping grease to the hinges of the tone control and FM tuning panel before installation.

The photo above showcases the refreshed appearance of the Beomaster 1900’s wood trim, achieved through light sanding, cleaning, and the application of boiled linseed oil.

Tomorrow, I will connect the Beomaster 1900 to dummy speaker loads for audio measurements.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of DC Platter Motor and Main PCB
item.description:
I recently obtained a main PCB and DC platter motor from a Beogram 4002. I began with the motor refurbishment, a process that often requires several days for the bearings to become saturated with oil.

The motor is depicted here:

Disassembly was necessary to access the bearings, visible as two small rings on the black component in the front:

The motor’s interior was noticeably oily, suggesting prior tampering. This was supported by a damaged commutator brush that was bent out of its intended form:

I submerged the bearings in motor oil and applied a vacuum, resulting in immediate and intense bubbling:

This reaction signifies that the vacuum is drawing air out of the bearing pores, allowing the oil to penetrate.

While the bearings were undergoing this process, I shifted my attention to the main PCB. Evidence of previous work on this PCB was apparent due to the presence of two trimmers soldered onto the copper side in the upper right corner:

Here is the component side in its original state:

A detailed view of the sensor arm amplifier (TR3):

All electrolytic capacitors were replaced. I also replaced the RPM relay and trimmers with modern, encapsulated versions. Additionally, I installed a new transistor for TR3, as these tend to drift from their specifications, leading to problems with the record detection mechanism.

A close-up of the refurbished RPM section:

Upon completing the board rebuild, I installed it into one of my Beogram 4002 units. I set the bias of the new TR3 to the required 4V at the collector:

The bias trimmer was then moved to the component side:

Next, I assessed the sensor response. The trace below illustrates the measurement taken with the empty platter rotating beneath the sensor:

Each downward spike represents a black ‘rib’ on the platter passing by. The amplitude, exceeding 5V, indicates a strong signal.

After approximately 72 hours, the bearing bubbling ceased, and they were removed from the oil:

I then straightened the brush to the best of my ability

and cleaned the motor parts using an ultrasonic bath. This step removes any remaining oil from the previous repair attempt, as these motors are susceptible to instability if the commutator or brushes are oily. Finally, I reassembled the motor for an RPM stability test. I used my BeoloverRPM tool, which records the RPM at 10-second intervals over a prolonged duration:

The resulting curve from the measurement is displayed below:

This level of performance represents the optimal outcome for the 4002 DC platter motor. Both the motor and PCB are now fully restored and ready to be put back into service.

item.title: A Pair of Beomaster 1900 Receivers for Restoration: Unit #1 Power Supply Checks and Adjustments
item.description:
After making some adjustments according to the service manual, everything on the Beomaster 1900 tested out perfectly.

I began by verifying and adjusting the +15 VDC power supply.

While there’s no adjustment for the ±31VDC rail voltages, I always check them to ensure everything is as it should be. It’s best to identify any issues early on.

To easily measure these voltages, I connected probe wires to the collectors of output transistors IC200 and IC201 underneath the Beomaster. Thankfully, both measured within the acceptable range.

Next, I moved on to checking and adjusting the No-Load Current in the output amplifier section. Following a similar method, I attached probe wires underneath the Beomaster 1900, connecting two wires across one of the emitter resistors for each channel.

As instructed in the service manual, I set the No-Load Current trimmers to 12mA for each channel, with the volume at zero and no speakers connected.

Here’s a look at the right channel setup:

And here’s the left channel:

Eager to hear the results of my work, I decided to test the Beomaster 1900 before proceeding.

I connected my workshop’s Beovox S-55 speakers to the output and used an iPod Nano as an input source.

The sound quality was fantastic! Hearing music flow through a restored amplifier is always a rewarding experience.

Successfully playing music marked a significant step in the restoration process.

I took a break to enjoy the fruits of my labor, listening to music for about an hour.

My next task is to remove the wood trim pieces for easier access. I prefer working with them detached from the frame.

item.title: A Pair of Beomaster 1900 Receivers for Restoration: Unit #1 Power Restored
item.description:
The first Beomaster 1900 unit is ready for testing after restoration. Testing always starts with powering it on and checking the voltages.

This Beomaster wasn’t powering on. Based on my previous observations, I suspected the +15 VDC fuse and the fuse holders. I also found a wire exposed on the main power switch.

I repaired the power switch wiring. The Beomaster 1900 has a secure yet easily accessible wire connection for the line voltage. A simple clip releases the wire.

I replaced the damaged section of the wire with a fresh piece and reconnected the main power switch.

The wiring now looks significantly better. I proceeded to replace the fuse holder for the +15 VDC supply.

Despite these efforts, the unit remained powerless. While the transformer was delivering the correct voltage to the bridge rectifier, there was no DC voltage output. I decided to replace the bridge rectifier because it had been assembled from separate diodes and showed signs of previous electrical issues. Although functional, I wanted to restore it to its original configuration.

After installing a new fuse holder, bridge rectifier, and smoothing capacitor, the issue persisted.

I rechecked my work, focusing on the new bridge rectifier. While testing for continuity, I discovered two damaged solder pads for the bridge rectifier leads on the underside of the main circuit board. These pads weren’t making contact with the board’s traces, preventing the flow of electricity.

One of the damaged pads was for the AC voltage connection. The +VDC pad was also faulty, even though the damage wasn’t immediately visible.

After repairing the bridge rectifier connections, the issue seemed to be resolved.

You’ll notice a jumper wire on one side of the new fuse holder leads. This was necessary because the original two-pin holder acted as a jumper. Initially, I believed this was the root cause of the power issue, but the +15 VDC remained absent. The two damaged bridge rectifier solder pads were the real culprits. This experience highlights that multiple issues can often contribute to a single malfunction.

Finally, with all the connections fixed, the Beomaster is receiving +15 VDC power. The transformer delivers approximately 18 VRMS to the bridge rectifier, resulting in a DC output of around 23 VDC, as measured across the smoothing capacitor. This voltage then passes through a +15 VDC regulator.

With the power supply restored, I can now proceed to test it and make the necessary service manual adjustments.

item.title: A Pair of Beomaster 1900 Receivers for Restoration: Unit #1 Reassembly for Testing and a Power Problem
item.description:
Before testing the Beomaster 1900, I needed to reinstall its four output transistors, which are located on the rear heatsinks. I had previously removed the heatsinks and their old thermal paste. For this reassembly, I prefer using modern SIL-Pad thermal insulators. They are much cleaner to work with than thermal paste and provide excellent thermal transfer.

Here are the components prepped for reassembly.

Bang & Olufsen designed a clever mounting system for these transistors. Curved, metal spring clips secure the transistors to the heatsinks, effectively sandwiching the thermal insulator between them.

The output transistors are shown reinstalled below.

With everything back in place, it was time to begin testing the Beomaster 1900.

As soon as I connected the variac and dim bulb tester, I knew there was a problem.

The Beomaster 1900’s +15 VDC power supply wasn’t working. The Standby lamp remained unlit. I tried cycling the main power switch in case of a poor connection, but nothing changed.

I disconnected the power cord and inspected the +15 VDC power supply. There was no voltage across its fuse.
