While the fuse holders showed heavy tarnish, the unit had powered on before the restoration began. I removed the fuse and confirmed it was still good, but I still couldn’t get a reading from the fuse holders.

The following photos show the fuse holder clips and their position on the board.

These fuse holders have deteriorated with age. I then remembered that the original bridge rectifier had been replaced and that there was significant scorching on the board underneath it. It’s possible a major electrical surge occurred at some point.

In any event, I need to order replacements for the +15 VDC power supply fuse holders. If I order from Mouser today, they’ll be here on Tuesday.

This power supply issue made me consider the Beomaster 1900’s overall power input. I had previously encountered a faulty power switch on a Beomaster 2400, so I decided to examine this one closely.

I’m glad I did. The switch itself tested fine, and I cleaned it with Deoxit. However, I discovered damaged insulation on one of the main power wires supplying the Beomaster. It might not have caused any problems, but I prefer to avoid exposed wiring.

I’ll repair the power switch wiring while waiting for the new fuse holder clips to be delivered.

The following picture shows the power switch after cleaning and preparation.

item.title: A Pair of Beomaster 1900 Receivers for Restoration: Installing New Lamps (Unit #1)
item.description:
Today, I replaced all the indicator lamps in the Beomaster 1900.

I switched out the original incandescent Bass, Treble, and Balance indicator lamps with LED/resistor lamp assemblies. This is because incandescent lamps produce more heat, which can be seen in the white spots on the red lamp lenses. LED lamp assemblies generate less heat.

The board shown here originally housed the Bass, Treble, and Balance lamps. Anticipating future needs, I created more LED replacement lamp assemblies than the required three for this project.

The newly installed Bass, Treble, and Balance LED lamp assemblies are shown here. Since polarity is important with LEDs, I indicated the positive lead’s placement on the board.

I replaced the other twelve indicator lamps with new incandescent lamps from Beoparts. These specific lamps are required for these indicators to ensure the proper operation of the underlying Beomaster 1900 circuits.

The volume control board uses two lamps, while the selected source and FM tuning indicator board uses ten.

The lamps are shown in the “before” photo below. These appear to be replacements, likely installed when the Beomaster’s 15-volt power supply bridge rectifier was replaced.

The new lamps are shown here. All of them are uniform and of the same type.

This Beomaster is now ready to be put back together before undergoing power supply testing.

item.title: A Pair of Beomaster 1900 Receivers for Restoration: Recapping the Tone Control & FM Tuning Board (Unit #1)
item.description:
The final major task in the Beomaster 1900 restoration, detailed in the previous post, has been completed. This post covers the last board requiring capacitor replacements: the Tone Control & FM Tuning Board. Replacing the ten capacitors on this board is straightforward due to their accessibility. The true challenge lies in cleaning and fixing the three slider controls: Bass, Treble, and Balance.

Before images of the Tone Control & FM Tuning Board are shown below.

Work began by cleaning and restoring the slide controls.

Disassembling the Bass and Treble sliders revealed a prior repair attempt, likely performed alongside the main board’s bridge rectifier replacement, although the two are unrelated.

The slide controls have a design flaw where the control contacts attach to the sliding control bridge. The bridge’s small black plastic piece, which houses the contacts, is prone to breakage. A glue repair on the bass control bridge points to an attempt to address this issue.

The treble slider control is depicted below.

A reliable slider control bridge repair kit was likely unavailable at the time of the glue repair, which likely provided a temporary fix. Given the eventual failure of such repairs, the current solution involved using a replacement bridge sourced from Martin Olsen of Beoparts.

The photo below showcases the new Beoparts bridge alongside the original bridge intended for the bass control slider.

The image below shows the bass slider control contacts mounted on the new bridge.

Cleaning and lubricating the rails on which the contacts slide is another crucial step in the slider control repair.

Deoxit and conductive carbon grease were used. The bass control slider is now ready for reassembly and reinstallation on the Tone Control & FM Tuner Board.

The treble slider control is now ready for reassembly.

Anticipation to listen to this Beomaster receiver grows. However, some tasks remain.

The last slider control, the balance control, differs in style from the others. While visually similar, its design eliminates the need for repairs required by the bass and treble controls. This balance control slider style is preferable due to its enhanced durability.

Nevertheless, it still requires cleaning and lubrication.

Before-and-after pictures of the balance slider control cleaning are shown below.

Moving on to capacitor replacements, the electrolytic capacitors in this Beomaster, similar to others, were found to be out of tolerance.

Below is the one in the worst condition, a 2.2uF capacitor.

It measured a staggering 6.27uF.

Below is a photo of the fully restored Tone Control & FM Tuning board.

The final steps before testing involve replacing the Beomaster 1900 indicator lamps, a task scheduled for tomorrow.

item.title: A Pair of Beomaster 1900 Receivers for Restoration: Recapping the Main Board and Volume Control Board (Unit #1)
item.description:
The main board and volume control board restoration is finished.

Despite the Beomaster 1900 and 2400 receivers having a small footprint, their restoration is deceptively complex. Replacing the numerous capacitors always serves as a reminder of the intricate internal workings.

Upon arrival, the main board appeared as shown:

After replacing the electrolytic and tantalum capacitors, the main board looked like this:

Here’s a closer look:

Following my usual practice, I replaced electrolytic and tantalum capacitors with values of 4.7uF and below with red rectangular WIMA MKS capacitors. These are non-polarized, offering a suitable replacement.

For capacitors exceeding 4.7uF, I used high-quality capacitors rated at 105°C. Matching the voltage rating of the original capacitors was prioritized throughout.

As observed in previous Beomaster 1900/2400 restorations, a significant number of capacitors showed tolerance deviations ranging from 30% to over 100%.

I meticulously measured each removed capacitor. While not all measurements are pictured, these examples highlight the common findings.

An original 220uF capacitor, now significantly out of tolerance:

A 2.2uF capacitor exhibiting a similar issue:

Replacing these significantly deviated capacitors with new ones will greatly improve performance.

A new Nichicon 220uF capacitor:

A single 10uF tantalum capacitor within the FM tuner was the only one not replaced. Its measured value matched its rating, making replacement unnecessary.

As documented earlier, this Beomaster 1900 had a history of problems with the +15 VDC power supply’s rectifier bridge.

The makeshift rectifier bridge was replaced with a single unit. Additionally, the previously replaced capacitors, while still functional, were also replaced to ensure all electrolytic capacitors were new.

Typically, the two large reservoir capacitors for the output amplifier voltage rails remain within tolerance. This Beomaster was no exception; however, I opted to replace them due to the involved process. This proactive approach prevents revisiting this task later.

The existing reservoir capacitors:

And the replacements:

During the main board restoration, I noticed the +15 VDC regulator’s mounting appeared less than ideal. The dried-out thermal paste necessitated a more robust solution.

To address this, the old paste was removed, and the regulator was remounted using a SIL-Pad.

This modification, along with the added hot glue for the 2200uF capacitor of the +15 VDC supply, ensures better stability and heat dissipation.

The left and right channel 250Ω trimmers on the main board, responsible for the output amplifiers’ no-load current adjustment, were replaced with new, sealed, multi-turn versions.

With the main board complete, attention shifted to the Volume Control Board.

The board before any work:

And after capacitor replacement:

The reinstalled Volume Control Board:

This phase involved replacing sixty-four capacitors, two trimmers, and the four diodes of the bridge rectifier.

Removed components:

The second Beomaster 1900 receiver will undergo the same process.

Upcoming tasks include recapping the Tone Control/FM Tuner board and replacing the Beomaster 1900 indicator lamps. Once these are finalized, the enjoyable part begins: testing.

item.title: Beogram 4002: Restoration of DC Platter Motor
item.description:
I obtained a Beogram 4002 DC platter motor from the Netherlands, but couldn’t use it. The top bearing suspension was damaged beyond repair.

As a result, I refurbished a different motor I had on hand.

To lubricate the bearings, I took the motor apart and submerged them in oil.

A vacuum was applied to the oil-submerged bearings. This caused significant bubbling, signifying air escaping from the bearing material and creating space for oil to enter. I took the bearings out after roughly 48 hours when the bubbling ceased.

I put the motor back together and tested its RPM stability over 24 hours using a BeoloverRPM device in one of my Beogram 4002s.

The results are shown in the graph below.

These findings are excellent for Beogram 4002 DC motors. This one is operational again!

item.title: A Pair of Beomaster 1900 Receivers for Restoration: Initial Assessment of the Second One
item.description:
This is the second Beomaster 1900 receiver that needs restoration.

Similar to the first receiver, I started by inspecting the indicator lamps when powered on.

[Images of indicator lamps]

All the indicator lamps on this Beomaster are working.

Cosmetically, it’s missing the cabinet feet, a common issue with these models.

[Image of missing cabinet feet]

The control panel lid’s rubber bumpers have degraded.

[Image of deteriorated lid bumpers]

The cabinet trim veneer isn’t peeling, but the finish is quite dull. It might have been replaced before, but it’s hard to tell. I’ll try polishing it with linseed oil.

[Image of cabinet trim veneer]

The Bass, Treble, and Balance slide controls on this Beomaster 1900 are consistent with the first one. The Bass and Treble controls use a flat bar slide, while the Balance control has a round bar slide.

[Image of slide controls]

The indicator masks are in excellent condition.

The power supply bridge rectifier looks good and original. However, some electrolytic capacitors have been replaced.

[Image of bridge rectifier]

This Beomaster also has some electrical components mounted on the trace side. Mounting electrolytic capacitors on this side must have been done for ease of installation.

[Images of trace side components]

Unlike the first Beomaster 1900, this one’s display/button panel mounting screws match other Beomaster 1900/2400 units I’ve worked on. The front corner screws and the two longer side screws are brass-colored Phillips-head screws with washers.

[Image of display panel screws]

Both Beomaster 1900 units have been opened and inspected. They’re now ready for the restoration process.

item.title: A Pair of Beomaster 1900 Receivers for Restoration: Initial Assessment of the First One
item.description:
After a short break from posting on the Beolover Blog, I’m starting a new restoration project. An owner sent me two Beomaster 1900 receivers, which I completely understand as a Bang & Olufsen collector who owns multiple units of the same component.

Both Beomaster 1900 units appear to be in good cosmetic condition.

Let’s begin with the first one.

As previously mentioned, the Beomaster 1900’s exterior looks quite good. However, there are a few common issues present. Almost all Beomaster 1900 and BM2400 receivers exhibit deterioration in the cabinet feet, control panel lid bumper pads, and veneer peeling on the cabinet trim.

This particular unit has problems in all three of those areas.

As with previous Beomaster 1900/2400 projects, I have replacement cabinet feet on hand. I’ll need to create new lid bumper pads. To address the veneer issues, I’ll glue and clamp the affected sections.

Prior to opening the cabinet, I briefly powered on the Beomaster to determine which lamps are functional.

As you can see, the Treble and Balance indicator lamps are not illuminated.

It seems that only those two lamps have burned out.

Now, let’s disassemble the cabinet to assess the internal condition.

We’ll start with the top of the cabinet. Two screws secure the Beomaster control panel to the frame. The photo of these screws also reveals the deteriorated lid bumper pads.

Four screws on the back of the Beomaster 1900 need to be removed.

The cabinet’s bottom plate is secured by five or six screws, potentially depending on the serial number. Later Beomaster 1900 and Beomaster 2400 models have a longer screw located in the speaker/source connector cavity, which these early Beomaster 1900 units lack.

Additionally, this Beomaster unit’s cabinet base plate is missing a screw in the front left corner.

However, it does have the smaller, coarse-threaded screw with the lock washer.

Five screws need to be removed to access the button and display panel.

The two longer panel mounting screws on this early Beomaster 1900 model are simple slotted screws. Other Beomaster 1900 and 2400 units I’ve restored used identical brass-colored Phillips screws, similar to the shorter one in the picture. Since both sides of the cabinet are like this, I believe these screws are original. However, the brass screws on the front corners are missing washers.

With the panels removed, I can inspect the tone control and FM tuner select board located beneath the control panel and lid.

Interestingly, the Bass and Treble slide controls use a flat bar design for the plastic contact bridge, while the Balance control has a round metal slide bar.

I believe the Balance control’s style was a later design used in the Beomaster 2400 receiver. My previous Beomaster 2400 restoration project had this slider type for all three controls. These newer sliders seem less prone to the failures experienced by the flat bar versions. However, I’ve encountered Beomaster 2400 units with the flat bar design, so perhaps the Balance slider here was a previous repair.

Regardless, these three controls appear to be in good condition based on my initial visual assessment. I’ll examine them more thoroughly during the restoration process.

A visual inspection of the electrical components indicates that the electrolytic capacitors in this Beomaster are long overdue for replacement.

There’s evidence of a past repair on this Beomaster. Judging by the black residue on the main board, it appears the original rectifier bridge failed.

It has been replaced with a new bridge rectifier constructed from individual diodes. While functional, I’ll replace it with a proper, single-component bridge rectifier.

At least three capacitors near the bridge rectifier are not original and were likely replaced during the repair after the rectifier’s failure. The replacements appear to be of good quality.

Examining the underside (trace side) of the tone and FM tuning control board, I see that the board connectors are consistent with early Beomaster 1900 units.

These connectors are essentially small circuit boards with pins that plug into receptacles on the tone control board.

While functional, these require extra care when handling.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513: Restoration of DC Platter Motor, PCBs and RPM Panel
item.description:
I recently obtained the DC platter motor, circuit boards, and RPM panel from a Beogram 4002 (5513) located in California. I began with the motor, as is customary, because it requires a few days for the oil to fully permeate the bearings.

To begin, I took the motor apart to access the bearings. Then, I submerged the bearings in motor oil and created a vacuum. This process helps to remove air from the bearing material, allowing the oil to penetrate more effectively. While the oil infusion was underway, I shifted my focus to the other components.

The main circuit board was in its original state. I paid specific attention to the ‘RPM section,’ which consists of two RPM adjustment controls and the original Siemens 33/45 speed switch relay. Another area of focus was the sensor arm amplifier. Replacing the transistor and adding a trimmer for precise bias adjustment is crucial for any Beogram 4002 restoration.

After rebuilding the main circuit board, I turned my attention to the output board. I replaced the output relay (responsible for grounding the signal leads until the needle is safely on the platter). Additionally, I installed a switch to connect the system and signal grounds, which often resolves humming issues with RCA-based amplifiers. Finally, I replaced the capacitor that governs the relay’s timing during arm lowering.

The last step involved replacing the incandescent bulbs in the RPM panel. I replaced them with LED boards and, fortunately, I had a spare cover to replace the missing one. With the new LEDs in place, I adjusted the sensor arm transistor’s bias to achieve the desired 4V output.

After confirming that the sensor signal met the required specifications, I reassembled the DC motor and calibrated it for both 33 and 45 RPM. A 24-hour RPM stability test using the BeoloverRPM device yielded excellent results.

With all these steps completed, the components are now ready to be returned to California and put back into service!

item.title: Beogram 4000: A Very Corroded New Arrival from Sweden
item.description:
My initial assessment of the Beogram 4000 from Sweden is a mixed bag. Positively, the aluminum surfaces, platter, arm cover lettering, and panels are in good shape, though a thorough cleaning is needed to determine their true condition. The internal components appear original, and the red position indicator is intact. However, there are significant drawbacks.

The black enclosure parts have an unprecedented amount of corrosion, exceeding typical wear and tear. This corrosion is present even on the underside and has also affected the chassis’s leaf springs. The hood, while salvageable, has sustained noticeable scratches.

Given these observations, restoring this Beogram 4000 to pristine condition will be challenging and require sourcing parts from donor units. The extent of the corrosion necessitates a cautious approach before powering it on to avoid potential short circuits.

item.title: Beogram 4000: A Fun Evening with a Smoking Solenoid Resistor
item.description:
This continues my series “A Fun Evening with…” A Beogram 4000 turntable, which I had previously restored, was returned with a malfunctioning arm lowering mechanism and a burning smell.

I removed the turntable from its case and took off the aluminum plates to examine it. When I powered it on, it initially started up as usual, but the arm wouldn’t lower at the record’s starting point. Instead, there was a strong burning smell and a plume of smoke coming from the circuit board with the carriage switches.

I immediately unplugged the turntable and inspected the circuit board. I discovered a discolored resistor (7R1) and burn marks on the board.

My initial thought was that the power transistor (0TR4) regulating current to the solenoid might be faulty.

Even though the TIP41 transistor is generally reliable, it handles significant currents in this solenoid circuit. After testing the transistor, it seemed operational, which puzzled me.

Initially, I suspected a problem with the resistor (unlikely as it’s wire-wound) or the solenoid itself, but both tested fine.

During another test, the solenoid activated immediately upon powering on, indicating a worsening problem. Since the solenoid connects directly to the 24V rail’s rectifier, it seemed likely the transistor had short-circuited.

I installed a new TIP41C transistor.

Testing the original transistor again revealed it was acting as a voltage divider, confirming my suspicion. This highlighted the limitations of transistor testers, as they test at low currents, potentially masking issues present at higher currents.

With the new transistor in place, the solenoid no longer activated constantly. I powered on the turntable, and everything functioned correctly. As a precaution, I also replaced the solenoid resistor.

Additionally, I replaced the two transistors (1TR10 and 1TR11) that control the TIP transistor.

I chose to replace these transistors because, in a previous restoration, TR10 had insufficient gain. I’m now inclined to believe that replacing transistors crucial for gain or handling high currents should be standard practice when fully restoring a Beogram 4000 turntable. There’s always something new to learn. This is the essence of Beolove!

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513 - DC Motor, Main PCB and RPM Panel Restoration
item.description:
A Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable from Arizona was received for restoration, exhibiting the common issue of RPM fluctuations. To address this, the motor was prioritized, as revitalizing dry bearings with oil is a time-consuming process.

The motor was disassembled to access the bearings. These were then submerged in motor oil within a vacuum environment. This process, characterized by vigorous bubbling, facilitates the oil’s penetration into the bearings’ porous material by drawing out trapped air.

After a three-day soaking period, the bubbling subsided, indicating the bearings were thoroughly infused with oil. Subsequently, the motor was reassembled.

Attention then shifted to the main PCB. The “RPM section,” encompassing the 33/45 relay and speed adjustment trimmers, was the focal point.

To enhance performance, the original components were replaced with modern counterparts: a new encapsulated relay with an adapter board, and multi-turn trimmers for precise speed adjustment.

Furthermore, TR3, responsible for amplifying the record sensor signal, was upgraded to a 2N5089 high-gain transistor paired with a multi-turn trimmer for accurate biasing. This modification ensures reliable record detection, protecting the stylus from potential damage.

Additionally, all electrolytic capacitors were replaced due to their age-related degradation.

The RPM panel also required attention, as it exhibited “custom wiring.” To rectify this, the trimmer unit was swapped with a unit from a spare panel. This revealed heat damage to the original background label, a common issue when using modern bulbs with higher wattage.

LED replacement boards were installed to mitigate heat-related issues. LEDs generate less heat compared to traditional bulbs, ensuring stable operating temperatures for the RPM trimmers and preventing potential RPM fluctuations.

Following LED installation, black tape was applied to mask light seepage from the LED panels.

The system was then rigorously tested. The RPM panel, illuminated with a warm incandescent glow thanks to the red-green LEDs, functioned correctly.

Adjustments to TR3’s bias successfully achieved the desired 4V output at the collector. The sensor signal, as visualized on an oscilloscope, indicated proper functionality. The turntable accurately identified 7" and 12" records, as well as the absence of a record.

Finally, a 24-hour RPM stability test was conducted using the BeoloverRPM device, measuring RPM at 10-second intervals. The results were exceptional, showcasing remarkable RPM stability.

With all repairs and adjustments completed, the Beogram 4002 is now performing optimally and ready to return to its owner in Arizona.

item.title: Beogram 4000 (type 5215): replacing sensor arm photo cell with modern one
item.description:
I recently had two Beogram turntables (a BG4000 and a BG4002) in my workshop with malfunctioning photocells in the detector arm. Usually, these photocells have a long lifespan, but the light bulbs can experience broken wires. While a pre-existing LED replacement for these bulbs exists (see sensor arm light bulb replacement), in this instance, the photocells themselves had broken wires and even a fractured cell, rendering repair impossible. Finding replacements proved futile as well.

The damaged photocell is shown below:

The Beogram 4000 series utilizes a BP100 photovoltaic cell, which generates DC voltage upon contact with light, similar to a miniature solar panel. Unable to locate a photovoltaic cell of the same size, I explored alternative solutions.

After testing various options like photodiodes and photoresistors, I settled on a phototransistor due to its superior sensitivity and reliability for this purpose. While integrating it into the detector arm presented a challenge, an “Osram opto sensor” proved to be a perfect fit, requiring no modifications.

The sensor measures 4.6 mm x 5.8 mm with a thickness of 1.7 mm and is an OSRAM LPT 80A.

To install, remove the light bulb, bend and insulate the sensor wires, and then carefully snap it into the black detector housing. Ensure the sensor makes contact with the brown PCB, aligning the sensor’s lens with the detector unit’s larger lens.

Insulate the wires using heat shrink tubing.

Bend the wires for seamless insertion into the housing and PCB holes.

The new sensor is now in position and soldered.

The light bulb is back in place.

The updated schematic with the additional resistors is shown below.

Here’s a breakdown:

The OSRAM phototransistor is an NPN type with an open base, meaning it has only two terminals (collector and emitter) and relies on incoming light to trigger conductivity. To establish a functional circuit, a power source is necessary. Through trial and error, a 22K resistor (R1) connected the 6V DC power supply to the collector.

Due to the phototransistor’s function as an on/off switch, the output pulse measures around 5V peak-to-peak, significantly higher than the 20-30mV delivered by the original BP100 photocell. To address this discrepancy, a voltage divider (R2 & R3) was incorporated to ensure the pulses after transistor 1TR14 remained around 2.5 VDC, consistent with the service manual’s specifications.

Note: As this sensor is an NPN transistor, confirm the correct wiring from the sensor to the PCB: the phototransistor’s longer lead corresponds to the collector, while the shorter one is the emitter.

An oscilloscope reveals well-defined pulses generated by the phototransistor at the collector:

…and those measured at the collector of 1TR14, closely resembling the service manual’s values.

Given the need for only three additional resistors, I directly soldered them onto the PCB and the incoming detector arm wire connectors. Surprisingly, a spare, unconnected connector was present, its purpose unclear. However, it proved quite useful in this situation - as if B&O engineers anticipated this very modification.

These photos are from the Beogram 4000. While a Beogram 4002/4004/6000 would require different wiring, the fundamental principle remains consistent.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of DC Platter Motor, Main PCB and RPM Adjustment Panel
item.description:
A Beogram 4002 turntable, experiencing RPM fluctuations, recently arrived from a customer for repair. The restoration process involved addressing issues with the DC platter motor, the main PCB, and the RPM adjustment panel.

The platter motor was disassembled to lubricate the bearings. After immersing them in oil and applying a vacuum, the bearings were left undisturbed for two days to ensure proper saturation. Once the bubbling ceased, indicating full replenishment, the bearings were extracted and the motor was reassembled.

The main PCB underwent a comprehensive restoration. Electrolytic capacitors were replaced, along with the RPM trimmers, to enhance RPM stability and adjustment precision. Additionally, transistor TR4 and its associated biasing resistor were replaced to address potential issues with the record detection circuit. A new 2N5089 high-gain transistor and a 5MOhm biasing trimmer were installed, allowing for precise bias adjustment to achieve a 4V collector DC voltage.

Next, the incandescent bulbs in the RPM panel were swapped with LED replacements to ensure long-lasting illumination.

Following the component-level repairs, the system was thoroughly tested. The sensor signal, specifically the collector signal of TR4, was examined to confirm proper record detection. The troughs in the signal, corresponding to black ribs on the platter passing through the sensor, reached zero, indicating the circuit’s functionality.

A 24-hour RPM stability test was conducted using the BeoloverRPM device. Initial results revealed RPM drops, suggesting potential problems with the motor’s spark snubbers. Consequently, the motor was disassembled again, and the original spark snubbers were replaced with modern unidirectional TVS devices.

A subsequent 24-hour test with the new spark snubbers demonstrated consistent RPM without any drops, confirming the effectiveness of the repair.

With these meticulous repairs and comprehensive testing, the Beogram 4002’s components have been fully restored and are ready for years of reliable performance.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5503): Full Restoration
item.description:
This document details the restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5503) turntable originating from California. The restoration process commenced with the reconstruction of the carriage and arm lowering mechanisms, encompassing meticulous cleaning and lubrication of components like the solenoid and damper.

Following the mechanism restoration, focus shifted to the linkage connecting the damper to the tonearm. This involved addressing a common issue: a detached copper pad on the sensor arm assembly. The pad was reattached using epoxy to ensure smooth operation.

Subsequently, the tracking sensor’s incandescent light source was replaced with a modern LED assembly. This upgrade offers improved accuracy and longevity for the turntable’s tracking system.

A cracked plastic pulley in the carriage mechanism was then replaced with a durable, precision-machined aluminum counterpart, enhancing the system’s reliability.

Next, the turntable’s motor underwent a thorough revitalization. This involved replacing the motor and reservoir capacitors and re-lubricating the AC motor bearings. The motor was carefully disassembled, cleaned, and reassembled, ensuring optimal performance.

Attention then turned to the main PCB, where all electrolytic capacitors were replaced, and modern 25-turn encapsulated RPM adjustment trimmers were installed for precise and lasting RPM calibration.

A crucial step involved replacing a specific transistor (TR9) responsible for amplifying the record detection sensor signal. Often found out of spec in older models, it was replaced with a 2N5089, along with a new trimmer for accurate biasing.

Further enhancements included replacing the sensor arm’s light bulb with a custom-designed, flex-PCB-based LED replacement. This upgrade provides a warm white light, faithfully illuminating the B&O logo.

The output PCB, housing the output relay and its delay circuit, also underwent restoration. This involved replacing the relay and incorporating a switch for connecting system and signal grounds, mitigating potential hum issues.

The final stages involved replacing the remaining incandescent bulbs in the RPM adjustment panels with custom-designed LED boards. Additionally, a wavy background sticker in the 33 RPM trimmer section, a common issue caused by heat from the original light bulb, was replaced for a pristine appearance.

The restoration concluded with the replacement of cracked cabinet guidance washers with new 3D-printed parts. Degraded transport lock bushings were also replaced with 3D-printed replicas. Lastly, the original corroded DIN5 plug was upgraded to a new all-metal plug with gold-plated contact pins for superior connectivity.

Following a comprehensive series of adjustments, including sub-chassis leveling, arm height calibration, and tracking weight adjustment, the Beogram 4002 was treated to a test run using a meticulously cleaned vintage vinyl record. The turntable, now restored to its former glory, delivered a remarkable listening experience. After a period of further testing and enjoyment, this refurbished Beogram 4002 is ready to return to its California home.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5503): Unit Switches Immediately to 45 RPM After Pressing Start
item.description:
The Beogram 4002 (5503) turntable being restored exhibited a peculiar issue during initial testing. Upon starting, the tonearm moved as expected but the speed immediately switched to 45 RPM. Pressing the 33 RPM button temporarily resolved the issue, but the speed reverted back upon release.

This unusual behavior pointed to a potential problem with transistors TR3 or TR2. Examining the circuit diagram, we can see how speed selection operates:

The speed control mechanism utilizes a flip-flop circuit with transistors TR3 and TR4. Resistors 5R1 and 5R2, along with indicator lights IL1/2, function as pull-up resistors, ensuring operation even with a burnt-out bulb.

When the 45 RPM switch is activated, or the tonearm triggers TR2 while moving, TR3 turns off momentarily. This action changes the state of TR4, grounding the base of TR3 and enabling 45 RPM operation by altering the Wien Oscillator frequency.

Conversely, pressing the 33 RPM button reverses this process, turning TR4 off, TR3 on, and activating TR5. This sets the oscillator to a lower frequency for 33 RPM.

Testing TR3 revealed a fault, behaving like a voltage divider instead of a transistor:

Replacing TR3 with a BC547B transistor successfully resolved the speed issue.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacement of Broken Off MMC Cartridge Mount with 3D Printed Replacement Assembly
item.description:
I recently obtained a Beogram 4000 tonearm with a common issue: a broken MMC cartridge mounting tab due to the aging plastic. Fortunately, this tonearm had an older design allowing for easy disassembly.

The plastic piece meant to hold the cartridge was broken, leaving only the circuit board behind. The broken piece was glued in, requiring careful heating in boiling water to soften the glue before removal.

Thankfully, a crucial part with the grounding tab remained intact and was reusable. A replacement part was then assembled. New contact traces were glued into a 3D-printed replacement part and wired.

Next, the insert was assembled using a damaged cartridge for alignment, ensuring the grounding tab was flush. The back part with spring contacts was then glued to the 3D-printed piece.

The final step was carefully inserting the assembled piece back into the tonearm, aligning the mounting screw and ensuring the cartridge sat snugly against the tonearm tube.

The end result closely resembles the original and the tonearm is now ready for use again.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Motor: Spark Snubber Replacement
item.description:
I recently had a Beogram 4002 DC platter motor on my workbench that I had previously worked on in November 2016 due to a broken brush and a severed pickup coil lead.

The motor recently began experiencing RPM fluctuations again.

This pointed to a problem with the spark snubbers. To access the rotor, I opened the motor:

The spark snubbers, marked with red dots, are located around the commutator. The replacements are on the black pad.

I took out the old spark snubbers:

And soldered in the new ones between the coil terminals:

I then used the BeoloverRPM device to test the RPM stability for approximately 24 hours:

These are my findings:

It appears that this motor is now ready to be put back into service!

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5503): A New Arrival from California
item.description:
I recently acquired a Beogram 4002 (Type 5503; AC platter motor) turntable for restoration. The unit arrived in remarkably good shape. The dust cover is practically flawless, and the aluminum panels and platter are in fantastic condition.

However, there is a hole drilled into the top left corner of the aluminum plate surrounding the platter, meaning this part will need replacement. Thankfully, beneath the plates, the turntable appears to be in pristine, original condition.

This originality is a positive sign, as it usually means fewer unexpected problems during restoration. The turntable has the orange plastic transport lock bushings, which, as expected, disintegrated during shipping. Thankfully, the plinth corners are in perfect condition – a rarity!

Upon plugging in the turntable and pressing start, the carriage moved slowly to the LP setdown point and attempted to lower the arm. This is a good indication of the turntable’s overall health. A thorough cleaning and re-lubrication of the carriage and arm lowering mechanism should address the slow movement. This test also showed that the 33 RPM trimmer backlight bulb is out and the carriage pulley is cracked, both relatively easy fixes.

Overall, this Beogram 4002 is a great candidate for a complete restoration. With some work, it should return to like-new functionality. Stay tuned for updates on the restoration process!

item.title: Beogram 4000: Completing the Restoration and a Test Spin with Weather Report!
item.description:
This Beogram 4000 restoration project is complete, and it’s time to review the work. Two previous posts covered specific repairs: addressing a missing transistor insulator and a faulty motor driver transistor, and creating a 3D printed replacement for the fragile MMC cartridge mounts.

This post summarizes the remaining restoration work.

Typically, the process begins with a complete overhaul of the turntable’s carriage. This involves disassembling and cleaning all moving parts, such as the arm lowering mechanism.

The linkages, carriage rods, and spindle are removed for thorough cleaning in an ultrasonic cleaner, removing old lubricant and grime. Once cleaned, the parts are ready for reassembly.

With the carriage inverted, it’s an ideal time to re-plate the solenoid activated switch terminals with nickel and gold, ensuring optimal conductivity and longevity.

Next, the tracking sensor light bulb is replaced with a modern LED and trimmer for precise adjustment of the tracking feedback. The old plastic carriage pulley, prone to cracking, is switched out for a durable machined aluminum replica.

Attention then shifts to the electronics and AC platter motor. The reservoir, motor capacitors, and the motor itself are removed. The motor is disassembled, cleaned, treated with fresh oil, and then reassembled using 3D printed parts to replace the original rivets.

The 24V Zener diode near the motor is upgraded from a 1W to a 5W model for improved voltage stability. New, high-quality capacitors are installed using a 3D printed fixture for secure placement.

Next, the switch terminals, often heavily oxidized, are addressed. The carriage position switches and keypad cluster terminals are carefully removed, plated with nickel and gold, and soldered back in place.

The four light bulbs within the keypad cluster are replaced with LEDs for enhanced illumination. The frequently loose strobe mirror is secured with adhesive.

The main PCB receives attention with replacement of all electrolytic capacitors, the RPM relay, and RPM trimmers. TR14, responsible for sensor signal amplification, is also replaced, and its biasing resistor is swapped for a 25-turn trimmer for fine-tuning the collector voltage.

The sensor arm light bulb is upgraded to a warm white LED setup, providing a realistic red-orange glow for the B&O logo. The sensor signal is checked for proper function.

A 24-hour RPM stability test using the BeoloverRPM device confirms excellent motor performance.

To enhance the signal path, a switch connecting signal and system grounds is added, minimizing hum, especially with non-B&O amplifiers. A new, gold-plated DIN5 plug replaces the existing RCA connection for superior EMI shielding.

Cosmetically, the turntable’s plinth, which had a separated corner, is repaired. After heating the plinth in an oven to soften the adhesive, the metal fixture is removed. Old contact cement is cleaned from the metal, and the wood sections are rejoined using wood glue and custom assembly braces. Finally, contact cement secures the metal fixture to the wood.

New cabinet guidance washers replace the old, cracked ones, and the corroded hood hinge is restored. The hinge is removed, sanded, and resprayed with satin black paint. A crack in the plexiglass hinge area is reinforced with stabilizing patches. Lastly, the repainted hinge is installed, and the trim sides are reattached with contact cement and custom clamps.

With all repairs completed, the restored Beogram 4000 is ready for a test run with a meticulously cleaned vinyl record. The turntable performs beautifully, demonstrating the success of the restoration project.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacement of an 'Old Style' MMC Cartridge Mount with a New 3D Printed Assembly
item.description:
The Beogram 4000 restoration involved addressing a frequent problem: a broken MMC cartridge mount. This issue arises because the plastic used in older models becomes brittle over time. Thankfully, later models like the Beogram 4002 and 4004 utilized a more durable plastic, reducing this issue.

To begin the repair, the tonearm was removed to allow access to the cartridge mount assembly. Unlike later models where the mount is glued, this older version is bolted to the arm’s aluminum frame. After detaching the arm, a small PCB connecting to the MMC mount assembly became visible.

Accessing the screw securing the cartridge mount assembly was achieved by turning the arm around. Pushing the plastic assembly out from the rear of the arm with a smooth 8mm rod allowed for its removal without damage.

The assembly comprises three parts: a cartridge-holding ‘carrier’ with a grounding tab, a separate grounding tab component, and a piece connecting to the PCB at the arm’s back. Due to damage, this repair necessitated designing a replacement grounding tab. A Molex-style connector terminal’s “ammo pack” strip provided a suitable metal piece for the grounding tab. After plating with nickel and gold, the strip was cut, bolted to the 3D-printed plastic part, and formed into the correct shape.

The next steps involved attaching a new, plated flex PCB strip with coil contacts to the carrier and carefully transferring the wiring. Following the soldering, the insert was reassembled using the original back end part and contact cement.

The critical moment arrived: would the new assembly align with the arm tube’s screw hole? Fortunately, it was a perfect fit. Even better, the cartridge fit snugly against the aluminum profile. With the new cartridge mount in place, it was time to reinstall the arm and prepare the Beogram 4000 for its inaugural spin.

item.title: Beogram 4000: A Fun Time with a Suddenly Activating Solenoid, an Anemic Carriage Motor, and an AC Motor Driver with a Weak Driver Amplitude
item.description:
I’m repairing a Beogram 4000 turntable and encountered some unusual problems. After rebuilding the boards and motors, I noticed the carriage moved slowly. The 24V rail was only reading 21V, significantly lower than the expected 23.8V.

Then, the arm lowering solenoid began activating erratically when the carriage was touched. It turned out the chassis had a 30V potential relative to the system ground, a dangerous situation.

I found a short circuit between the 24V reservoir capacitor and ground. Tracing the short, I discovered a missing insulator on transistor 0TR4. This meant the transistor’s collector was directly connected to the chassis.

Replacing the insulator solved the solenoid problem, but the low voltage and slow carriage persisted. The AC motor signal was weak, only 2.5V instead of the normal 5.5-7V.

One of the motor driver transistors, 0TR2, was shorted. Replacing it with a BD437G power transistor restored the motor signal and the 24V rail.

As a final precaution, I also replaced the complementary transistor, 0TR3, with a BD438G. This ensures even load distribution and prevents future issues. Now the Beogram 4000 is ready for final adjustments and its first spin after restoration!

item.title: Beogram 4000: A New Arrival from the UK
item.description:
A Beogram 4000 turntable recently arrived from a UK seller for restoration. This report outlines its pre-restoration condition.

Upon arrival, the unit was quite dirty but in good overall shape. The dust cover showed typical scratches from storage, many deep enough to feel with a fingernail. However, it can be polished back to good condition. Positively, the dust cover features an aluminum strip instead of the less durable plastic type, and the hinges appear to be intact. The hinges do show typical corrosion, but this can be fixed by sanding and repainting.

With the dust cover removed, the aluminum surfaces showed no serious damage and just need a thorough cleaning. The plinth is also in good condition, with corners that are almost pristine.

Encouragingly, there were no signs of previous repair attempts under the hood, which simplifies the restoration process. As is common, the carriage pulley had detached during shipping. Thankfully, the carriage was secured, preventing damage to the red position indicator, which remains in good condition.

Before powering on, the UK plug was replaced with a standard US plug and the voltage selector switched to 110V. Initially, the unit would not power on, and inspection revealed that the fuses had degraded – a common issue with Beogram 4000 turntables. The fuse box cover was also cracked and needs replacement. After installing new 500mA slow-blow fuses, the strobe light lit up, indicating power. The carriage began moving slowly towards the record placement point, but hardened lubricant prevented the arm mechanism from fully engaging. The unit was powered off to avoid potential damage to the solenoid, which controls arm movement.

Further inspection revealed that several solenoid-activated switches were corroded. These switches are critical to the Beogram 4000’s operation and typically require attention during restoration.

In conclusion, this Beogram 4000 is a good candidate for restoration, with the potential to be returned to near-new condition.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Completing the Restoration
item.description:
During the summer of 2019, I had the opportunity to work on a Beogram 4002 turntable from Virginia, specifically restoring its DC platter motor. I recently received the entire unit for a complete overhaul. The arm lowering mechanism had been previously restored and was in excellent condition. My attention turned to the remaining areas needing restoration.

To begin, I tackled the main PCB. The first photo illustrates its original condition:

My restoration efforts included replacing all electrolytic capacitors, installing a new RPM relay, and adding new 25-turn RPM trimmers:

Next, I addressed the record detection circuit. Based on recent experiences with similar restorations, I’ve made it a practice to replace TR4, the transistor responsible for sensor signal amplification. The original transistor (BC183C) is shown here:

This transistor is prone to being out of spec, often exhibiting low gain, which can be risky for the stylus. If amplification fails, the record detection circuit becomes unreliable. I replaced it with a modern high-gain 2N5089 transistor. I also installed a 25-turn 5 MOhm trimmer as the bias resistor. To facilitate adjustment with the board powered, this trimmer needs to be initially placed on the solder side:

Following the manual’s recommendation, I adjusted the collector voltage to 4V. With the voltage set, I moved the trimmer to the component side, placing it next to the new transistor:

With that, the main PCB restoration was complete:

I then replaced the main dual capacitance reservoir capacitor. Two modern single capacitors, secured with a 3D-printed fixture, replaced the original:

Accessing the output PCB required removing the keypad:

On the output PCB, I replaced the output relay and the capacitor that dictates the relay’s timing. Additionally, I incorporated a red switch to connect the system and signal grounds, addressing potential hum issues:

With the keypad already removed, I took the opportunity to replace the light bulbs in the RPM trimmer panel with LED boards. The panel is pictured here with the original bulbs:

And here with the plug-in LED boards:

The panel in operation:

The chosen red-green LEDs provide an incandescent-like glow. Red indicators are properly illuminated thanks to the red component. Orange LEDs would result in grayish indicators because they lack red photon emissions.

Next on my list was replacing the tracking sensor’s light bulb. The original black bulb housing is shown here:

Here’s the replacement part alongside the original assembly:

The LED is positioned where the original light bulb’s filament was located. Here’s the LED assembly during the tracking feedback calibration:

Fine-tuning the tracking feedback is made easier with the blue trimmer, which adjusts the LED’s brightness.

This particular Beogram 4002 still had its original plastic pulley. These pulleys are known to become brittle and break:

I replaced it with a durable, precision-machined aluminum pulley provided by a fellow B&O enthusiast in Vienna:

It looks fantastic! If you’re interested in one for your Beogram, I’d be happy to connect you with the supplier. Feel free to email me or use the contact form.

The transport lock bushings are another set of plastic components susceptible to deterioration in this Beogram 4002 model. A telltale sign of their degradation is an “orangish” appearance. This Beogram exhibited this same issue:

All three bushings were removed:

And I replaced them with robust nylon bushings, 3D-printed using SLS technology. The bushings are designed in two parts. One part is inserted from the bottom:

And the other from the top:

The left bushing installed:

And the top retaining plate secured:

With the transport locks rebuilt, I moved on to the last remaining incandescent bulb in the sensor arm:

The bulb was replaced with an LED circuit on a flexible PCB designed to fit within the bulb compartment. It draws a current similar to the original bulb, ensuring the circuit recognizes a functioning light source. Here’s the installed assembly:
