This sensor’s signal needs to function correctly and at the appropriate level.

The sensor is producing pulses exceeding the required 6 volts, ensuring the tonearm won’t lower onto an empty platter.

Before checking the end groove and run-out stop circuit, I wanted to complete some mechanical checks and adjustments to prepare the Beogram for playback. I was pleased to find the platter-to-tonearm height was already at the required 23mm.

The arm lowering limit needed setting to ensure the stylus tip is approximately 1mm from the top of the first platter rib. This safety measure safeguards the cartridge from damage if the record detection circuit fails.

Another mechanical adjustment involved checking the tonearm’s length and parallelism. By running a string tangent to the Beogram arm assembly, I could visually confirm the stylus followed the string’s path.

I had previously confirmed the 7.7mm distance and parallelism between the tonearm and fixed arm when disassembling and cleaning the tonearm assembly earlier in the restoration.

With those steps completed, record playback is getting closer. The remaining tasks include fine-tuning the tracking sensor sensitivity, verifying the run-off stop function, and calibrating the platter speeds.

Adjusting the tracking sensor was relatively smooth, though it involved several iterations to achieve the desired sensitivity where the tangential arm motor moves after the correct number of revolutions.

The run-off stop check on the oscilloscope showed good results. I successfully adjusted trimmers 1R14 and 1R15 on the main board to set the 33⅓ RPM and 45 RPM speeds using the Beolover RPM tool.

These Beograms require a lot of adjustments and checks, but their exceptional design makes them well worth the effort.

Now, it’s time for a break with food and fireworks – away from the Beogram, of course. Afterward, I’ll make a quick adjustment to the keypad cueing button, and then it’s time to relax and enjoy some vinyl.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Keypad and RPM Panel
item.description:
Slow response times from the Beogram’s control panel buttons pointed to potential oxidation on the keypad contacts. This was confirmed upon opening the keypad assembly, revealing dull key contacts.

The contact pads were unsoldered and removed for a closer look. While they seemed okay, the leaf contacts engaged by the actuators showed signs of oxidation.

To address the oxidation, a fiberglass brush and Deoxit were used, restoring the contacts to a shiny and clean condition.

The next electrical task involved replacing the RPM indicator lamps. This was crucial as LED replacements had proven to improve platter motor stability during testing. It’s important to note that the RPM indicator lamps are integral to the platter motor’s control circuit, and each speed indicator has a dedicated pitch (speed) adjustment knob.

Pictured below is the RPM indicator module with its original incandescent lamps.

And here’s the RPM indicator with the Beolover lamp replacement modules installed.

These Beolover modules are designed for compatibility with the pitch control circuit. Their SMD LEDs are calibrated to blend light colors, mimicking the original incandescent lamps.

The images below showcase the 33 and 45 RPM speeds illuminated by the new light modules. All control panel buttons now exhibit immediate responsiveness upon pressing.

With all Beogram functions now operational, the next stage involves meticulous checking and adjustment in line with the service manual’s guidelines. Once these adjustments are finalized and all checks are successfully passed, it will be time to enjoy the pleasure of vinyl playback once more.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Electrical Work and Initial Tracking Adjustment
item.description:
Let’s begin restoring the electronic boards. The main control board needs its capacitors replaced and the RPM relay (along with the RPM trimmers) need attention. Additionally, the output board requires inspection of its phono muting circuit. It’s worth noting that aside from wiring, the muting relay is the sole electrical part interacting with the phono audio signal. The turntable’s electronics mainly manage the platter motor, tangential arm, indicator lamps, and user controls, none of which are part of the audio pathway.

Here’s the main control board pre-recap. Notice the electrolytic and tantalum capacitors. Capacitors 4.7uF and above will be replaced with new 105°C Nichicon capacitors. For those below 4.7uF, I’ll use WIMA MKS polyester capacitors. While I prefer WIMA MKS for 4.7uF as well, their size makes them unsuitable here. Importantly, the 0.47uF 1C10 electrolytic capacitor will be upgraded to 10uF based on Beolover’s testing, which yielded optimal speed stability for this motor.

This is the main board after restoration.

Next, we have the output board before…

…and after restoration. A grounding switch has been added to allow for signal ground and chassis ground connection or disconnection, based on the user’s preference.

With mechanical parts cleaned and lubricated, and electrical components refreshed, it’s time for a test. As a safety measure, the tangential arm motor belt and platter have been removed to prevent unexpected movement if any issues arise. The arm position scale was also taken off the tangential arm transport for a closer look at the switches and position sensor lamp.

Upon connecting the Beogram to power, the main reservoir capacitor reads slightly above 30 VDC, which is positive. The fixed arm sensor lamp and the 33 RPM indicator lamp are both lit. The platter motor and tangential arm motors are running, an expected outcome since the position scale is detached, leaving the SO switch unable to turn off.

There’s one immediate issue: the tangential arm position sensor lamp is off.

Without this functioning lamp, the control logic cannot accurately pinpoint the location of the tangential arm assembly.

It has been replaced with an amber T-1, round LED.

This LED has a 591nm wavelength, 13000 mcd luminous intensity, and a 15° viewing angle. The key takeaway is that the sensor effectively detects the light and provides the correct voltage to the control circuit. A more thorough check of this sensor voltage will be conducted later during the service manual adjustments and checks.

Here’s the new position sensor lamp in place and operational.

Now’s a suitable time to pre-set the tangential drive tracking sensor. Disassembling the sensor components during cleaning means the tracking alignment likely needs recalibration. While visually centering the tracking sensor aperture was a reasonable starting point…

…fine-tuning is necessary. Using the aperture position adjustment screw, the aperture is set to allow the arm to pivot freely and prevent the tangential arm drive motor from unnecessary activation when the arm is lowered.

Next, the tracking sensitivity adjustment screw and aperture position are manipulated. The objective is to find a setting where the sensitivity screw effectively controls the arm’s forward movement when lowered. This ensures sufficient play in the tracking sensitivity screw for precise tracking adjustment later, during the service manual adjustments. Once achieved, the aperture position screw can be tightened.

Finally, it’s time to replace the original incandescent speed indicator lamps with Beolover’s LED board replacements—the final step toward optimal platter speed stability.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Floating Suspension, Reservoir Capacitor & Platter Motor
item.description:
This project is nearing completion. This post details the remounting of the floating chassis within the cabinet, replacing the reservoir capacitor, and installing the refurbished platter motor.

Here are the parts needed for mounting the floating suspension system back into the cabinet.

The threaded pin’s longer section is positioned at the bottom. When attaching the wing-nut, ensure it sits at the very beginning of the thread. I personally position it to allow enough thread for securing the nut while keeping the nut’s outer edge aligned with the topmost thread. This maximizes clearance for the floating chassis when the lock is disengaged. Rotating the threaded pin adjusts the distance between the two lock nuts, effectively locking or unlocking the suspension system.

Many Beogram 400x turntables have worn-out transport lock bushings. To address this, Beolover has created replacements using 3D printing technology. Pictured is a set of Beolover’s 3D-printed transport lock bushings, totaling six pieces, designed for the three Beogram suspension mounts.

The remaining suspension mount components can now be attached. As with the first wing-nut, I aligned the top of each nut with the start of its respective thread.

Next, we reinstall the reservoir capacitor in the cabinet. The original reservoir capacitor is a dual unit. However, not all Beogram 400x turntables utilize the same type, so careful identification of your 400x model is essential.

I removed the existing wires and installed Beolover’s replacement capacitor assembly.

It looks fantastic. Now, let’s install the platter motor that Beolover refurbished for this project.

A final inspection of the reassembly thus far shows everything is in order.

The next stage involves working on the main and output boards.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Tangential Arm Assembly Oil Cleanup and Restoration
item.description:
This Beogram 4002 restoration project continued with a thorough cleaning of the cabinet’s interior, focusing on removing oil residue. The tangential arm assembly was detached to access and clean the oil contamination found throughout the unit.

The oil had spread extensively, affecting various components from the arm’s mechanics to the switch contacts. The tangential arm position sensor assembly was entirely disassembled for cleaning.

With the old oil removed, the arm assembly restoration and adjustments could begin.

This Beogram project utilizes a different approach to lubrication. Instead of modern lubricants, the original lubricants specified in the Beogram 4002 service manuals were sourced, even though the instructions varied between different manual versions.

The tonearm damper was reassembled using Dow DC 200 fluid after a thorough cleaning.

The tonearm assembly spindle and tie-bar shaft were lubricated according to the service manual’s recommendations. Rocol MTS 1000, diluted with Esso NUTO H44 or H32 to achieve an oily consistency, was used on the spindle, while Molykote DX paste was applied to the tie-bar shaft.

Sourcing the Rocol MTS 2000 and Mobile NUTO H32 for the spindle lubrication proved challenging, unlike the readily available Molykote DX white paste. With lubrication complete, the tangential arm assembly was reinstalled on the floating chassis.

The tonearm lowering damper and tonearm to fixed arm parallelism were then adjusted. The tonearm counterweight was also calibrated for accurate tracking force.

The restored tangential arm assembly and floating chassis are now ready to be mounted back into the Beogram cabinet.

The next steps involve preparing the cabinet by installing new 3D printed transport bushings and a replacement reservoir capacitor assembly, also 3D printed.

Finally, the electrical restoration will be completed, including capacitor and relay replacements, and the installation of a rebuilt Beolover platter motor.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5501): Random Stop Issue Fixed - Defective Photo Resistor in the Spindle RPM Sensor
item.description:
A Beogram 4002 (5501) turntable, previously restored, began experiencing a problem where the OFF function would randomly activate during playback as if the button was pressed.

Prior to delving into the solution, the circuit diagram is presented for reference.

Transistor TR17, within the ‘Electronic Switch’ section, is responsible for initiating the turntable’s OFF function. When its base is grounded, the collector rises to approximately 18V, causing the arm to lift and return to its resting position. This can be triggered in three ways: through two mechanical switches – the “End Switch” (ES) located beneath the carriage and the “»” key on the keypad – or via the end groove detection system (“RUN-OFF STOP”). The End Switch activates when the carriage reaches its furthest left position.

The end groove detection mechanism utilizes transistor TR20. When the end groove is detected, TR20’s base is pulled high, grounding its collector and activating the OFF function.

An ‘analog rotary encoder’ forms the core of the end groove detection. It relies on light from bulb (OIL1) passing through four holes in the carriage pulley, creating fluctuations detected by a photoresistor (OR2). These light pulses briefly ground OR2, interrupting transistor TR21 and raising its collector voltage to around 19V. These voltage pulses charge capacitor C33, which, in conjunction with resistors R88/89, pulls up the base of TR20, activating the OFF function. Notably, bulb OIL0 only illuminates when the tonearm nears the record label, preventing premature RUN-OFF STOP activation between tracks.

The system avoids triggering RUN-OFF STOP during regular playback on the last track, even with OIL1 illuminated, due to the network of C34, R91, and D30. This network discharges C33 in the absence of light on the sensor. While the pulley rotates slowly during track playback, discharging dominates. However, rapid light flashes from the end groove tip the balance towards charging, activating TR20.

Returning to the random stop issue: After confirming the functionality of the ES and OFF switches, signal tracing from TR17’s base into the RUN-OFF STOP circuit revealed the following oscilloscope readings:

The traces represent:

  • Yellow: TR17 collector (trigger for measurement)
  • Blue: TR20 base
  • Green: TR21 collector
  • Red: TR21 base

These readings highlight random fluctuations in TR21’s collector voltage before the OFF event. These fluctuations correlate with the signal at TR21’s base, indicating its proper function. The conclusion: OR2 was randomly shorting to ground, causing voltage spikes sufficient to charge C33 and trigger TR17 when the voltage threshold was exceeded.

The diagnosis pointed to a faulty OR2 sensor. Since the specific B&O part was unavailable, a 3D-printed replacement for the entire bulb/sensor assembly was designed. Building on a previous LED bulb replacement, the new design replaced the encoder system completely.

[Image descriptions: A series of images showcasing the design and installation of the 3D-printed replacement part, including the LED, resistor, and photoresistor. The images depict the assembly process and the final installed sensor.]

With the new setup in place, signal measurements at TR21’s collector during LED illumination matched the expected behavior. Testing with records confirmed the repair’s success.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Second Unit From Houston
item.description:
A few weeks back, I completed the first of two Beogram 4002 (Type 5513) turntable restorations for a client in Houston. I’m now starting work on the second one. Both turntable platters had their motors removed before being sent to Beolover for refurbishment. He has since finished these and documented the process on his blog.

I believe that refurbishing the platter motor is an essential step in any Beogram 400x restoration project. Neglecting this would be similar to never changing the oil in a car. It’s crucial to prioritize this before tackling the electrical restoration of the Beogram’s main board. Beolover’s motor restoration service includes rigorous speed stability tests, which involve determining the correct capacitance value for the main board’s 1C10 capacitor.

Pictured below is the second Beogram 4002 (5513) unit, opened up. The empty space in the lower left corner of the cabinet is where the platter motor was originally mounted.

This unit, like the first, exhibited a significant amount of oil within the chassis. My initial step involves disassembling the Beogram for inspection and cleaning, followed by the restoration of individual components.

This particular Beogram has undergone previous repairs. A new phono cable was installed, enabling the use of preamplifiers with RCA inputs instead of the standard B&O DIN plug. The cable itself seems to be in good condition and is fitted with high-quality RCA jacks. However, I’m not entirely satisfied with how the new cable connects to the Beogram’s output board. I might need to modify this connection to bring the cable closer to the board’s plug before proceeding with the separation of the shields.

The previous Beogram 4002 I restored for this owner had its transport lock bushings in excellent condition. Since they were still pliable, I opted not to replace them, applying only a minimal amount of plastic/rubber conditioner.

In contrast, the bushings in this unit have deteriorated considerably. They have become brittle and crumble easily even with the slightest touch.

To effectively remove the bushing debris, I have extracted the tonearm assembly from the main cabinet.

The excessive lubrication of the tangential drive screw has resulted in a substantial amount of oily residue within the Beogram’s cabinet. This oil is flung off the spinning drive screw during operation, coating the interior.

The tonearm assembly is also visibly affected by this oil contamination.

While the tonearm assembly requires further cleaning, the Beogram’s cabinet is now completely clean and ready for reassembly.

The next steps involve completing the tonearm assembly cleanup and conducting initial mechanical inspections and adjustments.

item.title: Beogram 4002: Restoration of a Very Oily DC Platter Motor
item.description:
I obtained a Beogram 4002 DC platter motor from Berlin, Germany, for restoration. The motor’s exterior was noticeably oily, likely due to an attempt to improve its RPM stability through lubrication.

Disassembly was necessary to access and treat the bearings. The motor’s interior was also oil-coated. However, this is ineffective for the bearings, as they require vacuum oil infusion. This process removes air trapped within the porous Oilite brass material, enabling new oil to penetrate the bearing effectively. The bearings were submerged in motor oil under vacuum, with rising bubbles indicating air evacuation. This process typically requires 24-72 hours, depending on the bearing’s condition.

Once the bubbling ceased, the bearings were removed from the oil and placed on a paper towel to absorb any excess. The motor was then reassembled and installed in a Beogram 4002 turntable for a 24-hour RPM stability test using the BeoloverRPM device.

The initial test results, depicted by the unstable blue curve, were unsatisfactory, suggesting further issues with the motor. While the presence of downward spikes initially pointed to potential spark suppressor problems, the overall pattern suggested a different underlying cause. A similar issue had arisen during the development of the motor restoration procedure. Applying oil to the motor’s commutator, intending to reduce friction, had unexpectedly worsened performance. It appears that oil on the rotor creates an insulating layer, hindering current flow and impacting RPM.

Therefore, the motor was disassembled again. The rotor, brush carrier, and pulley – which was also oily, raising concerns about potential glueing issues – were cleaned in an ultrasonic cleaner with warm water and dishwashing detergent. The water became cloudy immediately after starting the cleaning process, indicating an emulsion forming between the oil and water. The water was replaced three times, running the cleaner briefly with each fresh batch until the water remained clear. A final cleaning cycle was performed using pure ethanol to ensure the removal of any remaining water from the rotor windings.

After reassembly and a subsequent 24-hour test, the motor achieved a stable RPM, represented by the red curve. With the restoration successful, the motor is ready to be returned to Berlin.

item.title: Beogram 4002: Final Tasks, Adjustments & Playing Records
item.description:
The final steps of a Beogram 4002 Type 5513 restoration project involved addressing corrosion damage and replacing the 5-pin DIN phono plug. Using a helpful audio path diagram, continuity checks were performed from the cartridge connector to ensure proper signal flow.

The replacement phono plug, a REAN model with gold contact pins, was installed, though the tight fit of the rubber boot on the cable posed a minor challenge. As an improvement, a grounding switch was added to the output board, eliminating the need for an external grounding wire.

To enhance the DC platter motor stability, the incandescent RPM indicator lights were replaced with Beolover LED replacements. After patching hairline cracks in the mounting clips of the RPM indicator panel, the final reassembly commenced, following service manual guidelines.

Platter height was adjusted, followed by the tonearm lowering limit and pickup arm length. Next, vertical and horizontal arm parallelism was ensured, and the tangential arm sensor was calibrated.

The deck panels and platter position were meticulously aligned before proceeding to the platter speed adjustments. With the platter belt temporarily removed, the 33 and 45 RPM trim pots were fine-tuned for accurate speed control.

After successfully completing these adjustments and a final listening test, the Beogram 4002 is now ready to return to its Houston home.

item.title: Beogram 4002: From Oil Cleanup to First Operational Test
item.description:
The Beogram 4002 restoration hit a snag. Although the main board was restored, the presence of rust and corrosion discovered earlier took priority. Addressing rust requires applying neutralizer and paint, which involves drying time between coats, thus delaying the planned reservoir capacitor and output board work.

Images highlighting the most severe rust spots are included.

Despite the significant rust, the turntable’s overall condition is good. To combat the rust, three coats of rust neutralizer were applied.

After a 24-hour drying period, the parts were painted with black oil-based paint.

Interestingly, the turntable, while heavily rusted, is otherwise in good condition.

The disassembly process revealed oil accumulation within the Beogram. This is a common issue stemming from using an improper type of oil on the turntable’s moving parts. Excess oil can be flung onto other components. The next step involved a thorough oil cleanup.

The floating chassis had to be removed to address the initial oil spill.

The tangential arm assembly, due for attention, was prioritized.

The spindle bearing nut showed clear signs of lubrication with thin oil instead of the correct grease.

This inappropriate oil, when subjected to the spinning of the tangential arm drive, splatters onto surrounding areas.

While oil was found on the floating chassis’s surface, the tangential drive sensor housing contained the largest concentration.

Such oil presence could disrupt the sensor’s function. After a thorough cleaning of the area, the tangential drive sensor assembly was reassembled.

This ensures the sensor’s proper functionality during the record tracking adjustment.

The arm lowering damper, found to be in good condition, was nonetheless cleaned and re-lubricated with light grease.

As is common, the tangential drive pulley exhibited hairline cracks, causing deformation when tightened to the spindle shaft, resulting in instability.

Remarkably, the Beogram’s transport bushings were in excellent condition, a rare find.

A new aluminum pulley, sourced from Nick, was installed.

With the assembly removed, an initial tonearm tracking force calibration was performed.

The installation includes a Beolover modification: a locking nut added to secure the tonearm counterweight in its calibrated position.

This concludes the initial mechanical restoration of the tangential arm. Focus can now return to the electrical system, specifically, replacing the reservoir capacitor.

A 3D-printed housing containing the new reservoir capacitors, a favored Beolover replacement part, was used.

This setup, a significant improvement over gluing the capacitors to the cabinet floor, utilizes the original Beomaster clamp.

Operational testing is nearing. The output board’s capacitor and muting relay have been replaced. A grounding switch will be added later.

Reassembly commenced with reinstalling the rust-treated chassis components in preparation for the floating chassis. The Beolover-restored DC platter motor was also reinstalled.

The Beogram is regaining its form. After installing the sub-platter, belt, and top platter, a test run can be conducted.

Seeing a successful first-time operation is always satisfying.

However, a thorough service manual check is necessary before risking a record.

item.title: Beogram 4002: New Project From Houston
item.description:
My next project takes me away from Beomaster restorations and back to Beogram turntables. It’s great to work on both, so I’m excited regardless. A gentleman from Houston entrusted me with two Beogram 4002 Type 5513 turntables he acquired some years ago. As time took its toll, they stopped functioning properly.  Like many Beogram 4002 owners, he realized he missed listening to his vinyl records and decided to have them restored.  I’m fortunate to have the opportunity to bring these back to their full glory.

But one step at a time.

The turntables were in decent condition, having been operational until recently. Here’s a look at the first Beogram turntable opened up.

Back in March, I removed and sent the DC platter motors to Beolover for a complete restoration. Now that they’re back, I can finally continue with the rest of the restoration process.

Some areas within this Beogram show significant rust, which I’ll clean and treat to prevent further damage. 

The Beogram’s phono DIN plug is also severely corroded and will need replacement.

Below are images highlighting the rusty chassis components.

This Beogram 4002 is a rare find; its plastic transport bushings around the floating suspension locking screw are still intact, soft, and in excellent shape. Most units I come across have brittle, cracked bushings that have crumbled inside the Beogram. I’ll apply a plastic restoration fluid to these bushings to prevent them from drying out.

The main circuit board appears to be in excellent condition, with no visible signs of heat damage or corrosion.

Similarly, the tangential arm assembly also appears to be in good shape. 

To restore this turntable to its former glory, I plan to recap the main board, replace the relays, speed trimmers, and clean and adjust the tonearm mechanics. The restored platter motor, new trimmers, and Beolover’s LED replacement modules for the speed indicator lamps will make this Beogram spin vinyl records better than ever.

Time to get started.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Final Adjustments, a New Solenoid, and Test Drive with Christoph Spendel & Wolfgang Schlüter Group on MPS
item.description:
The final steps of restoring a Beogram 4002 (5513) involved replacing the sensor arm light bulb with an LED assembly and performing standard adjustments. These included calibrating the tracking feedback, platter height, level, sub-chassis height, and arm lowering limit, which prevents stylus damage.

To ensure accurate tracking weight calibration, the C-clip securing the counterweight adjustment screw was replaced with an M3 nut and washer for permanent fixation. This guarantees that the calibration remains consistent during shipping.

An issue arose where the tonearm wouldn’t return to its resting position after playing a record. A misaligned copper slip pad under the arm level adjustment screw was identified as the culprit. Reattaching it with new adhesive tape resolved the issue, allowing the arm to move freely.

However, another problem surfaced: the arm wouldn’t lift after playing a record, dragging the needle across the surface. Though the arm lift functioned correctly when using the up/down button, the problem persisted after extended use.

Disassembling and lubricating the arm lowering mechanism did not solve the problem. Measuring the solenoid coil voltage during carriage return showed the correct voltage change, but the solenoid failed to release, indicating a fault. Replacing the solenoid with one from another Beogram resolved the issue.

Finally, an MMC20 EN cartridge was installed, and the Beogram 4002 underwent a successful test run with a record from the MPS label. After a period of extended use to ensure no recurring problems, the Beogram 4002 will be ready to return to its owner.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of the Main PCB and Installation of a Biasing Trimmer for TR3
item.description:
After getting the Beogram 4002 (5513) operational again, I focused on fully restoring the main PCB. This involved installing a trimmer to correctly calibrate TR3, the transistor responsible for amplifying the signal from the record detection sensor. The board’s condition upon arrival is shown below:

The RPM relay and trimmers had already been replaced by the owner. I finished the restoration by replacing all electrolytic capacitors

and adding a trimmer to enable bias adjustment at the base of TR3. To make adjustments with the board powered on, the trimmer was temporarily placed on the back, as pictured here:

After adjusting the collector DC voltage to 4.0V, I fixed the trimmer to the component side:

The original design used a fixed resistor, often causing insufficient amplification due to inconsistencies in the TR3 transistor’s current gain. Adequate amplification is crucial to avoid needle damage if the turntable is accidentally started without a record in place.

Next, I improved the installation of the replacement reservoir capacitor assembly, which had been installed previously:

Moving on to installing an LED in the sensor arm…

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): First Contact and Two Dead Transistors
item.description:
I recently acquired a Beogram 4002 that was already being repaired but needed further troubleshooting. The unit is in good cosmetic condition with minor wear. Upon inspection, the platter motor ran when turned on, but the carriage remained static.

Further investigation revealed that transistor TR20, responsible for the carriage motor control, was faulty. Replacing this component restored carriage movement.

However, the carriage would move only slightly before returning to its starting position. Voltage checks indicated a problem with transistor TR13, which controls the stop function. Replacing this faulty transistor resolved the issue, and the carriage now moves correctly and finds the LP’s setdown point. The next step is adjusting the tracking feedback.

This Beogram 4002 is well on its way to being fully functional.

item.title: Beogram 4002 and 4004 DC Motor Restoration
item.description:
I recently acquired two DC motors from Beogram 4002 and 4004 turntables located in Denmark. My typical first step is an oil infusion process to address RPM fluctuations, a common issue.

The 4002 motor arrived in this condition:

Disassembly revealed the following:

The two small, donut-shaped brass bearings, visible on the black pad, were submerged in motor oil under a vacuum. Bubbles appeared immediately, indicating the oil infusion process was working. After 48 hours, bubbling ceased, and the bearings were removed:

The motor was then reassembled for testing, using this tool to press in the top bearing:

Installed in a Beogram 4002 turntable, the motor ran for 24 hours. Its RPM was monitored using my BeoloverRPM device:

The 4004 motor underwent the same procedure. The RPM measurements for both motors are shown below:

The top red curve represents the 4002 motor’s 24-hour RPM performance. With a 0.47uF capacitor (C10) in the motor control circuit, it performed well. The dark blue curve shows the 4004 motor’s performance, exhibiting some upward spikes. A second test of the 4004 motor with a 10uF capacitor (C10) resulted in a much smoother, nearly perfect curve. Replacing the 0.47uF capacitor with a 10uF one is recommended for 4004 motors that didn’t come with a factory-installed 10uF capacitor (some do).

The motors are now ready to be reinstalled in their respective Beograms, poised for another 35 years of service.

item.title: Beogram 4000: An Entertaining Afternoon Exploring the Record Detection Circuit
item.description:
During the restoration of a Beogram 4000 turntable, a problem arose with its record detection system. While it functioned correctly at the 12-inch LP position, it frequently failed to detect records at the 7-inch singles position. This malfunction was observed when the turntable, starting without a record on the platter, bypassed the LP position but stopped at the singles position.

An examination of the circuit diagram revealed the signal path of the detection system. The sensor signal, originating from BP100, undergoes amplification by TR14 before further processing into a digital output for the control system. This signal then passes through a series of transistors (TR15, 16, 17, 18) for filtering and inversion, ultimately resulting in a digital output from TR19’s collector. This output, known as “DR,” signals the control logic whether a record is present (6V) or absent (0V).

Initial measurements of the input and output signals pointed to a possible circuit issue. The amplified sensor signal at TR14 displayed expected oscillations as the platter ribs passed beneath it. However, the DR signal exhibited unusual oscillations and even momentary stretches of constant 6V, deviating from the expected steady 0V in the absence of a record.

It was theorized that TR19 wasn’t supplying sufficient current to the logic gates connected to the DR signal, potentially causing its collector voltage to drift towards 6V. The oscillations were thought to be a consequence of fluctuating BE current in TR19 as its collector voltage changed.

Further investigation revealed a 50k trimmer, not documented in the circuit diagram, added to the main board. This trimmer, connected between R37/C13 and ground, was consistently set to its maximum resistance in several Beogram 4000 units, suggesting an attempt to minimize its impact on the circuit.

Measurements at TR15’s collector, both with and without the trimmer, yielded similar results, failing to explain the observed behavior. However, measurements at TR18’s collector, which feeds TR19, showed significant differences. With the trimmer in place, large voltage spikes towards 6V were observed, contradicting the expected behavior. Removing the trimmer resulted in very small spikes, indicating that TR19 remained consistently on and could provide the necessary current to the control system.

The removal of the trimmer successfully resolved the record detection issue. Subsequent testing revealed that this particular Beogram 4000 could reliably detect both translucent and clear records, even without the trimmer.

It was later discovered that the trimmer’s inclusion was intended to address variations in sensor sensitivity caused by the emergence of transparent vinyl records. The varying translucency of these records could affect the sensor’s ability to detect the platter’s ribs.

However, the effectiveness of this solution is not universal. The analog amplification stages in the sensor circuit are biased using a single resistor, making the gain dependent on the specific current gain of each transistor. Given the potential for variation in transistor characteristics, even within the same production batch, this dependence can lead to inconsistent performance.

Therefore, when servicing a Beogram 4000, it’s crucial to verify the detection system’s ability to handle clear records. This verification should be a standard procedure in the restoration process. This experience underscores the intricacies of analog control systems and the ongoing need for careful observation and analysis in their maintenance.

item.title: Beogram 4000: An Entertaining Evening Exploring the Differential Stop Circuit
item.description:
Before returning a refurbished unit to a customer, we put it through rigorous real-world testing. This involves playing music for several weeks to ensure consistent functionality. This listening process is a delightful part of working with Bang & Olufsen equipment, as our workshop is always filled with music! A recent case involving a restored Beogram 4000 turntable highlights the value of this testing phase.

During playback, I noticed the arm occasionally failed to return to its resting position after reaching the record’s end. Typically, the Beogram 4000 detects the end groove’s spiral due to increased carriage speed, triggering the arm lift and carriage return. However, in this instance, the needle continued tracing the final groove repeatedly, creating an undesirable repetitive sound.

This problem occurred intermittently, making troubleshooting difficult. Initially suspecting the MV switch, a common culprit in 4000 issues, I had previously addressed its terminals with gold coating. Tests confirmed the switch’s reliability, leading me to investigate the differential stop circuit. This circuit generates the signal informing the control system to lift the arm and return the carriage.

Here’s how it functions: End groove detection relies on carriage motor voltage. As the groove typically accelerates carriage movement, the motor voltage surpasses that of standard track playback. Hence, the circuit’s name, “Differential Stop” (DS), as it identifies the end groove by velocity, not arm position. However, arm speed also increases between tracks and within the outer run-in groove. To address this, a carriage-activated “MV” switch activates the DS circuit exclusively near the end groove.

When the carriage nears the center, the MV switch closes, applying motor voltage across a transistor (TR24) via a resistor and trimmer. This trimmer fine-tunes the carriage speed threshold for triggering TR24, a critical aspect in this investigation. When activated by high carriage speed, TR24 triggers another transistor (TR23), enabling other turntable functions to override the DS circuit. Subsequently, TR23 activates TR22, grounding its output and causing the DS signal to drop, initiating carriage return. This action momentarily reverses motor voltage, deactivating the DS circuit, resulting in a brief pulse.

Returning to the intermittent DS issue, after ruling out the MV switch, I suspected an intermittent problem within the DS circuit. Its infrequent nature led me to employ an Arduino as an event logger, monitoring the DS signal for changes. The issue resurfaced while playing a particular record, revealing the DS signal remained unchanged. However, the system functioned correctly with a different record. This pattern persisted – the issue correlated with a specific record!

Comparing the problematic record’s end groove to a functional one revealed a difference in the number of turns before reaching the innermost groove. Consequently, the first record induced higher carriage speed, resulting in a larger motor voltage increase. The faulty record’s motor voltage failed to reach the threshold, preventing DS activation. Adjusting trimmer VR4 slightly enhanced sensitivity, enabling the mechanism to function with both records while ensuring complete track playback.

Interestingly, the service manual recommends a DS trigger sensitivity of 1.8V motor voltage. This seems overly sensitive, as normal voltage fluctuations reach approximately 2.2V. Such a setting would trigger DS during regular playback, highlighting the nuances of analog control systems.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Hood Restoration
item.description:
The final step in restoring my Beogram 4000 involved replacing the damaged dust cover with one from a donor unit. While the replacement had some typical scratches, it was in good condition overall.

I began by sanding the surface with 320 grit sandpaper to remove the scratches. The next step was to polish it back to its original shine and clarity. Here’s the dust cover after polishing with 800 grit:

Nearly finished! After several more stages of polishing, it looked great:

This Beogram 4000 is almost like new again! After a few more days of testing, it will be ready to ship to its new home in Hong Kong!

item.title: Beogram 4000: Cosmetic Items, Final Adjustments, and a Test Drive with George Duke on MPS!
item.description:
The Beogram 4000 restoration project, originating from Germany, is nearing completion. After adjusting the sub-chassis and arm height, I set the arm lowering limit, a crucial measure to protect the stylus from potential damage if the record detection fails.

Next, I calibrated the tracking weight, opting to enhance stability by replacing the original locking washer setup with an M3 nut and washer to secure the counterweight position.

Following that, I calibrated the arm weight using a digital scale and fine-tuned the feedback by adjusting the tracking sensor LED with a blue potentiometer.

The final adjustment involved setting the motor voltage, confirmed by achieving smooth sine curves on the oscilloscope for both 33 and 45 RPM.

To complete the restoration, I replaced the damaged main aluminum platter and arm cover with pristine parts from a 4002 5501 Beogram and a donor 4004, respectively. I specifically sought an early 4002 arm cover to match the 4000’s aesthetic.

Finally, I tested the restored Beogram 4000 with a George Duke record, “Liberated Fantasies,” a personal favorite from the MPS label. Witnessing this turntable perform flawlessly after its initial damaged state was incredibly rewarding.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Glueing a Delaminated Platter Back Together and Installation of New Cabined Guidance Washers
item.description:
The Beogram 4000 I’m currently working on was unfortunately damaged during shipping due to inadequate packaging by the seller. Because the platter wasn’t secured, it moved around and ultimately split into two pieces. The images show the separated top and bottom sections of the platter.

Examining the platter’s interior reveals interesting details about its construction. The heavier bottom section of each platter was individually balanced, much like car tires. This involved drilling away small amounts of material from the heavier side, as evidenced by the red pen marks near the drill holes.

Marks on the lower platter’s ribs indicate that the two halves were originally glued together. Based on this, I used a slow-setting epoxy to reattach them, applying it at the original glue points.

After carefully aligning the top section, I used a 4002 platter as a weight to hold the pieces together during the 24-hour epoxy curing process.

While the epoxy set, I focused on replacing the old, damaged cabinet guidance washers with new 3D-printed ones. The original center washer, located at the front of the enclosure, has an unusual design.

The original flat Teflon washer lacks any guiding features, making it a good candidate for replacement with a 3D-printed version. A black material is preferable as white ones are visible through the gap between the cabinet and the aluminum panels.

The complete set of five 3D-printed guidance washers is shown in the final image. These are available for purchase through the Beolover Shapeways store, accessible via the link under “pages” on the right.

item.title: Beogram 4002: DC Motor Restoration and Dependence of RPM Performance on the Value of C10
item.description:
I recently obtained two DC motors from Beogram 4002 turntables that are being refurbished. One of the motors is pictured here.

The first step in restoring these motors is addressing the brass sleeve bearings, which are often dry after more than 35 years of use. I do this through an oil infusion process, which requires complete disassembly, as shown.

The bearings, visible on the black pad in the front, are submerged in oil and placed under vacuum.

Air bubbles escaping the bearings indicate that the oil is being drawn into the porous material, restoring their ability to lubricate the motor shaft. This process usually takes 24-48 hours. The photo shows the bearings reinstalled in the motor.

After reassembly, the motor undergoes a 24-hour stability test using a BeoloverRPM device, which records the revolutions per minute (RPM).

The BeoloverRPM device is available to other enthusiasts - feel free to reach out via email or the contact form if interested.

Achieving optimal speed stability in these DC motors has been a focus of my research. Their analog control system is sensitive to friction and temperature variations, with capacitor C10, responsible for feedback response, significantly impacting RPM stability. Over time, B&O used three different C10 values: 0.33uF, 0.47uF, and 10uF. My findings indicate that each motor tends to have a “preferred” value. Currently, determining the optimal value requires testing with each capacitor and analyzing the results. The graphs below show the results of this testing.

The top graphs illustrate the RPM performance with a 0.47uF C10 capacitor. The red line, representing motor #1, reveals significant spikes, suggesting the feedback system is overcompensating. However, with a 10uF capacitor (light red line), the same motor stabilizes significantly. Motor #2 also benefits from the 10uF capacitor but shows decent performance even with the 0.47uF value.

The reason for these variations remains unclear, as the motors share identical electrical characteristics. I suspect mechanical friction within each motor influences the control system’s response. Until further research provides more clarity, the most effective approach is to determine the ideal capacitor value empirically and enjoy the music!

item.title: Beogram 4000: Upgrade of Signal Path with New DIN5 Plug and a Grounding Switch
item.description:
The DIN5 plug on the Beogram 4000 being restored was heavily oxidized and needed replacement. A new, fully metal plug with gold-plated terminals was installed.

To improve the signal output, a switch was added to connect the signal and system grounds. This feature is beneficial when using a DIN5 to RCA adapter, as RCA cables lack a system ground. Connecting the system ground to the signal ground on the Beogram can reduce humming.

The Beogram 4000’s open output terminal assembly design simplified the switch installation. The switch’s illustrated position connects the two grounds, while flipping it would disconnect them.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacement of Sensor Arm Light Bulb with an LED
item.description:
The last incandescent bulb in this Beogram 4000 restoration project was replaced with an LED. Located within the sensor arm, this particular LED presented the biggest challenge due to the tight space. The solution involved creating a custom flexible PCB equipped with a current limiting resistor and a bypass to mimic the higher energy draw of a traditional light bulb. This was necessary because the control system relies on the current to confirm the bulb’s functionality. The image highlights the bulb compartment removed from the sensor arm.

The next image shows the removed bulb alongside the folded LED assembly, ready for installation.

Following that, the picture displays the flex PCB successfully installed and illuminated within the bulb compartment.

The chosen warm-white LED emits enough red light to illuminate the B&O logo effectively, replicating the original bulb’s effect.

A crucial step after replacing the sensor arm light source is testing the record detection circuit. This ensures the system accurately detects the absence of a record. The oscilloscope image showcases the signal measured at the collector of transistor TR14. This transistor amplifies the sensor’s response for interpretation by the control system.

The signal behaves as outlined in the manual, showing a 2V amplitude ranging from 0.2V to 2.2V, confirming the sensor is operating correctly.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoring the Carriage Position and Solenoid Driven Switches
item.description:
Following the keypad cluster rebuild on this Beogram 4000 turntable, the next step was to address the mechanical switches that control its operation. These switches are grouped into two clusters: one set located under the carriage that dictates tonearm positioning, and another positioned near the solenoid. The solenoid-activated switches are critical for engaging the tracking mechanism, initiating output when the stylus is in the groove, and regulating the solenoid power upon the arm’s descent.

Accessing the carriage position switches is best accomplished by moving the carriage inward and removing the red position indicator assembly. This action provides complete access to the board.

The board can be detached by unsoldering the two wires supplying power to the carriage motor and removing two screws. This allows for flipping the board over to reveal the component side.

Examination of the terminal tabs on the back often shows some oxidation. Interestingly, the carriage position switch terminals tend to be less affected by oxidation compared to the switches located under the keypad and next to the solenoid. The terminals were then carefully removed for further treatment.

To combat oxidation, the terminals were treated with a gold coating. This helps to ensure good electrical contact and long-term reliability.

After the gold coating was applied, the terminals were soldered back into place. The plastic plungers responsible for activating the switches were then cleaned to remove any hardened grease accumulated over their 40 years of service.

Next, the focus shifted to the switches adjacent to the solenoid. The switch assembly responsible for controlling solenoid power is readily accessible by removing its two retaining screws.

With the screws removed, the terminal was extracted, followed by the assembly containing the output and tracking activation switches.

Disassembling this delicate assembly requires careful handling to avoid damaging the thin wires that connect the switches to the control system.

Once disassembled, the three terminals within the assembly were carefully removed. A visual inspection of all four extracted terminals revealed a significant amount of oxidation.

To address the oxidation, the terminals were meticulously cleaned using a combination of 2000 grit sandpaper and a fiberglass brush. Following the cleaning process, a gold coating was applied to enhance conductivity and provide long-term protection.

With the terminals cleaned and coated, the entire assembly was carefully reassembled. An initial test of the system brought encouraging results: the carriage accurately positioned the arm at the 12-inch mark, and the solenoid functioned as intended. This successful step marks a significant achievement in the restoration process.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of the Keypad Cluster
item.description:
Following the repair of the Beogram 4000’s electrolytic capacitors and AC motor, the focus shifted to restoring the keypad cluster. The circuitry underneath the keypad forms the Beogram’s control system, a pioneering digital system utilizing TTL logic chips. This system relies heavily on inputs from numerous mechanical switches within the turntable to make decisions. The keypad itself houses eight of these switches, allowing user interaction.

The keypad was held by a single screw, which was missing, hinting at previous tampering. Opening the keypad revealed two PCBs. The upper board contained logic chips and bulbs for the position indicator and RPM trimmers, while the lower PCB housed eight keypad switches and a logic IC. As expected, the switch terminals showed significant corrosion.

To address this, the PCB was detached, and the switch terminals were removed. After cleaning the corrosion with sandpaper, the terminals were gold-plated and soldered back onto the PCB. The final step involved replacing the light bulbs with LEDs. Custom-designed LED boards, emitting an incandescent-like glow, replaced the position indicator scale lights. Standard red LEDs, with current limiting resistors, replaced the RPM trimmer backlights.

Reassembling the keypad presented a challenge: the center key had become detached. To avoid scratching the other keys during reinsertion, 3D-printed tools were used to pre-bend the key’s spring. This made it easier to position the key correctly and avoid damage.

With the keypad fully reassembled, testing confirmed that all keys were functioning correctly. The next phase of the restoration will focus on gold-plating the remaining switches located beneath the carriage and in the arm lowering mechanism.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of the PCBs and the AC Platter Motor
item.description:
Following the refurbishment of the arm lowering and tracking mechanisms on the Beogram 4000, the next stage was to substitute the electrolytic capacitors, the RPM control relay and trimmers, and the AC platter motor. The initial setup, including the original reservoir, motor capacitor, and AC platter motor, was documented before removal.

After removing the existing components, new capacitors were installed in a custom-designed 3D printed holder, designed to fit the original strap. The motor was then disassembled for an oil infusion under vacuum. This involved extracting the motor, drilling out the rivets holding it together, and placing the enclosure parts and bearings in motor oil within a vacuum environment.

During the 24-hour oil infusion, the main PCB was rebuilt. This involved replacing all electrolytic capacitors, the RPM switch relay, and the RPM trimmers for speed adjustment. The new blue 25-turn trimmers were strategically installed to allow adjustment from the solder side of the board, enabling adjustments while the board is in place.

Next, the small power supply board was rebuilt. During this process, a common issue was encountered – a broken fuse within the yellow tubing. A new fuse was installed and secured with shrink tubing. The motor was then removed from the vacuum, reassembled using 3D printed parts to replace the drilled-out rivets, and implanted back into the unit along with the new capacitor assembly.

Measurements taken from the old capacitors showed that one was non-functional. Replacing all electrolytic capacitors at this stage is a recommended practice to avoid dried out, leaky, or shorted capacitors, which can lead to further damage. Despite these replacements and repairs, powering on the Beogram 4000 revealed a potential issue in the control system, indicated by the arm lowering unexpectedly when the « or » keys were pressed.

item.title: Beogram 4000: From German Ebay to Tampa via Hong Kong Poorly Packaged
item.description:
I recently obtained a Beogram 4000 turntable that was poorly packaged during shipment from Germany to Hong Kong, resulting in significant damage. It’s unfortunate because the unit appeared to be in excellent condition before shipping, which is uncommon for Beogram 4000s these days. For tips on proper packaging of a 4000 turntable, please refer to our instructional video on our dedicated 4000 page.

The unsecured platter caused damage during transit, resulting in deep scratches on the underside of the plexiglass hood, potentially beyond repair. Additionally, the tonearms are now misaligned due to impact.

The aluminum panels have black streaks, but I am hopeful that they can be cleaned with specialized cleaning pads. The platter itself detached into its two separate parts upon arrival.

Beneath the turntable’s cover, I observed that the spindle pulley had become dislodged, likely due to the platter colliding with the tonearms.

On a positive note, the delicate red position indicator remained intact. However, there is evidence of previous repair work.

A replacement supply capacitor was poorly installed, with the original capacitor’s contact tab cut off and a new, incompatible capacitor soldered in its place.

After setting the voltage to 110V, the strobe light is functional, which is encouraging. However, the AC platter motor is barely operational. This could be due to a faulty capacitor or improper calibration of the AC oscillator amplifier.

The good news is that the turntable’s plinth is in excellent condition, with the front corners notably well-preserved.

In conclusion, this damage could have been avoided with proper packaging. While the Beogram 4000 can likely be restored to near-original condition, some parts may need to be sourced from a donor unit for a complete restoration.

item.title: Beogram 4000: A New Arrival From New York
item.description:
A Beogram 4000 turntable recently purchased on eBay was shipped using a specialized container to protect it in transit. Thankfully, the seller mostly followed the provided packing guidelines, resulting in no damage during shipping. Upon opening, the turntable was in good condition, with only minor issues.

While the blue tape used on the aluminum surfaces didn’t cause any damage to the lettering, there were a few scratches on the platter. These were likely caused by attempts to remove it improperly. Additionally, the otherwise pristine hood had a glued corner.

Positively, the plinth was in excellent condition, with both front corners appearing well-maintained. Internally, the unit seemed untouched and original. The red position indicator, a crucial component that is difficult to replace, was in good shape.

However, the carriage pulley was damaged during shipping due to a crack, causing the carriage’s linear bearings to detach. Despite these problems, the turntable powered on successfully. The strobe light functioned correctly, the carriage moved, and the AC motor rotated, indicating a potentially straightforward restoration process.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Motor Restoration - The Influence of C10 on RPM Stability
item.description:
Another Beogram 4002 DC motor was prepped for restoration.

The process began by removing the bearings for an oil infusion.

The small brass bearings were submerged in motor oil, and a vacuum was applied.

Bubbling indicated that the oil was being drawn into the bearings. These bearings took longer than usual, approximately 48 hours, for the bubbling to cease.

After the bubbling stopped, the bearings were taken out of the oil

and the motor was reassembled for testing.

The motor was then installed in a Beogram 4002, and the Beolover RPM device was used to assess performance.

The Beolover RPM device records the RPM over time, allowing for the detection of inconsistencies. The initial measurement (blue curve) was taken with a 0.47uF capacitor (C10) in the motor control circuit. The fluctuations in the blue curve pointed to issues in the motor control feedback. Increasing the capacitance of C10 to 10uF resulted in a steady RPM, as seen in the smooth curve. Notably, this issue doesn’t occur in all motors. The varying performance might clarify why B&O used both 0.47uF and 10uF capacitors in their production. It’s possible that B&O’s engineers were also puzzled by this inconsistency during the 1970s.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Motor Restoration
item.description:
I recently obtained a Beogram 4002 DC motor from France that needed some repair. My typical first step is to rejuvenate the oil-impregnated brass bearings by submerging them in oil. This process is usually successful in restoring motor function. This image displays the motor in its initial condition upon arrival:

To access the bearings, I took the motor apart:

The bearings are the two small ring-shaped components on the black surface.

I submerged the bearings in motor oil and created a vacuum. The appearance of bubbles confirmed that air was being pulled out of the bearings, creating space for fresh oil:

After a day, the bubbling ceased, and I reassembled the motor. I used my custom-made 3D printed tools to correctly position the upper bearing:

Here, both bearings are shown back in their proper positions:

Next, I conducted a 24-hour RPM stability test using my specialized Beolover RPM device. This tool is vital for identifying any fluctuations in RPM as it records the RPM over a period of time:

The Beolover RPM device is accessible to other enthusiasts. You can reach me through the contact information provided on my website. The following graph presents the RPM readings collected over a 24-hour period:

These outcomes are optimal. The motor is now fully restored and ready for use.

item.title: Bemaster 6000 (2702) restoration: the FM preset board
item.description:
As part of the equipment restoration, cleaning is essential. After over four decades, units accumulate a substantial amount of dust, as depicted in an earlier post. The FM preset board was no exception, exhibiting both dust and corroded trimmer contacts. These open trimmers are situated beneath the front panel, where gaps allow dust infiltration.

[Image]

To remove and clean the trimmers, desoldering their three contacts is necessary. They can then be slid out of the main black plastic housing.

[Image]

Disassembling the trimmers is straightforward once they are extracted. After removing a small retainer clip on the back, the components separate easily.

[Image] [Image]

Using a fiber pen and Deoxit GOLD cleaning & coating, the old grease, carbon, and slider contacts were cleaned.

[Image]

The remaining four trimmers underwent the same cleaning process after reassembling the first.

[Image] [Image]

The final step involved soldering the trimmers back onto the board, ensuring they were flush for proper alignment before soldering.

[Image]

A job well done!

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Final Adjustments and Test Drive with Freddie Hubbard's Liquid Love
item.description:
Following the installation of the Beolover 4002 Commander remote control and internal RIAA pre-amplifier, it was time for final adjustments before testing the turntable. The first step was tracking feedback adjustment. A blue trimmer on the tracking sensor LED light source simplified the fine-tuning of the feedback after the coarse mechanical adjustment of the sensor housing.

Next, the subclasses and platter height were adjusted, followed by the arm lowering limit. The lowering limit ensures the needle can descend below the record surface without hitting the platter ribs if the record detection fails. The tracking weight was then set to 1.2g. The fragile circlip securing the counterweight screw was replaced with a more durable M3 nut and washer to withstand shipping. Using a digital scale, the weight adjustment mechanism was calibrated with most B&O cartridges requiring a 1.2g tracking weight.

Finally, the worn keypad was swapped with a pristine original. With all adjustments made, the restored Beogram was ready for its first listen. A recently acquired Freddie Hubbard record from 1975, “Liquid Love,” was selected. While not his most acclaimed work, it’s a growing favorite, particularly the track “Lost Dreams.”

Playing a Beogram with the 4002 Commander remote is always a pleasure. For those curious about the IR signal transmission, the IR receiver is subtly integrated beneath the plinth, ensuring seamless control without compromising the turntable’s aesthetics. A truly elegant solution.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Installation of Beolover Commander MkII Remote and Internal RIAA Pre-Amp Board
item.description:
The owner of the Beogram 4002 (5513) requested the installation of a 4002 Commander remote control and an internal RIAA pre-amplifier module. The Commander enables complete control of the 4002 using an Apple remote, while the RIAA provides a strong output signal, allowing direct connection to modern amplifiers via CD/DVD/AUX inputs.

The first image displays the RIAA board and its mounting adapter, which elevates it above the output PCB headers.

The second image shows the installed board, soldered in place of the output relay. The RIAA board incorporates a second output relay for bypassing amplification, enabling signal routing through the original headers by connecting two plugs. Further details on the RIAA board’s design and functionality are available in the provided link.

The third image showcases the Commander MkII receiver unit. The right extension houses the IR receiver, passing between the plinth and enclosure to the deck’s exterior. The MkII features an auto-repeat function, indicated by a red LED on the left extension. A solid LED signifies one-time repeat, blinking indicates up to 10 repeats, and off denotes no repeat. This LED is positioned beneath the CD-4 indicator on the RPM adjustment panel, as seen in the fourth image.

The Commander board connects to the keypad connector, with the keypad plugging into a header on the Commander. One of the main PCB’s securing screws also fastens the Commander PCB on top.

Finally, adjustments and testing will be conducted.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacement of Degraded Transport Lock Bushings and Missing Cabinet Guiding Washers
item.description:
The Beogram 4002 restoration involved addressing the common issue of fragile orange transport lock bushings and missing cabinet guiding washers. Many Beograms used plastic washers, which are prone to cracking and falling apart. This was evident in the restoration project, as some washers were missing entirely.

To rectify this, five new 3D-printed washers were installed. For aesthetic purposes, using a black washer for the front-center position is recommended to avoid visibility through the gap between the aluminum panel and the plinth. Replacement washers are available for purchase.

Accessing the transport lock bushings requires disassembling the locks. The degraded bushings can then be removed. Vacuuming out any remaining fragments, especially beneath the floating sub-chassis, is advisable to prevent interference with its movement. The old bushings were replaced with new 3D-printed ones.

Each replacement bushing consists of two parts, inserted from the top and bottom. These parts are available for purchase. With the bushings replaced, the chassis can be reinstalled. The project concluded with the replacement of a corroded DIN5 plug.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of a Cracked Hood - Another Process Improvement
item.description:
The Beogram 4002 I’m currently working on has a cracked hood around the hinge attachments. The left side was entirely detached, and the right side had a crack extending around one of the holes.

The right side had a crack going all the way around one of the attachment holes:

To begin, I glued the broken pieces back together using Weld-On #4 acrylic solvent. This low-viscosity solvent is ideal for injecting into cracks, as capillary action draws it in. This created a strong initial bond between the broken parts.

While this already creates a fairly strong bond, I reinforced the repair by applying thin patches to the cracked areas using Weld-On #16. These patches, made from 20 mil PETG sheet, were chosen for their thinness and compatibility with acrylic.

To ensure even clamping pressure, I used 3D-printed clamping parts. These parts, along with metal components to prevent bonding with the plexiglass, allowed for a secure fit while the glue dried.

Once the glue cured, I trimmed any excess material and reattached the aluminum trim using 3M 300LSE laminating tape. Locking pliers held everything securely in place for a day, ensuring a strong bond.

The final result was a nearly invisible repair, with the patches blending seamlessly into the hood.

To address scratches on the hood’s surface, I performed a multi-step polishing process, starting with 320-grit sandpaper and progressing through increasingly finer grits.

This restored the hood to a like-new shine.

Lastly, I replaced the worn rubber bumpers with sections of a 2mm O-ring.

These new bumpers ensured the hood sat level when closed. With these repairs, the hood is now restored to excellent condition.
